summary: 10 denarii: Trajan – Marcus Aurelius (AD 162).
disposition: NPÚ-ÚOP Pardubice, Náchod Castle collection, Czech Republic (inv.nos. 2.920, 3.016-3.023).

summary: A hoard of 197 denarii (Mark Antony to Trajan), found in a 'rude earthen vessel', while ploughing a field in 1874 near Lavenham Lodge. Of these, 184 were examined and 183 published, the others were dispersed.

A hoard of 2000+ silver coins (mainly Cappadocian didrachms, drachms and hemidrachms; two Lycian drachms; c.100 denarii) deposited c. 185 and found in four bronze pots in the village of Sor, near Kayseri. It was dispersed in several batches in the art trade. A large portion was published by W. Metcalf (932 coins) and another by W. Weiser (178 coins, the 'Münchner Fundkomplex'). In addition, 140 coins were recorded in Paris in 1980 (RPC III, p. 376). They consisted in 26 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius), and 114 coins from Caesarea (Vespasian - Commodus)
21 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 1 AE (copper or brass) found in the neighborhoud of a Roman building next to some clay sources.
The hoard(?) comprised a "cluster" of 7 silver coins - 4 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 1 drachm - deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Large hoard of Roman denarii found in two ceramic vessels. Only 3 have provided some information on the issuers: Trajan 2, Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius caesar) 1.

The find comprised 65 coins of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius, 7 copper-alloy figurines, a stone figurine of Sucellus, some copper-alloy and glass plates, a scythe, some knives, an amphora, moulded glazed cups, bells, an incense burner, a triangular stone pediment and some carbonised cereals.
10 coins found compacted together during excavations in Tofts Field in 1974. Recovered from surface of first re-metalling of Dere Street, to the east of the later fort, in Tofts Field.
Ten denarii (Vespasian - Commodus), found in 1872 during peat digging. Two thereof arrived in the Oldenburg archive; an additional three were noted in 1905 in private possession.
Originally 30 denari, 29 preserved: Nerva - Commodus (AD 179-191); silver weight: 78.54 g.
14 denarii: Claudius I – Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).
disposition: National museum, Prague, Czech Republic (11 coins)

summary: 3rd century. "Six coins, a small mid-3rd century AD hoard, found in soil (751A), 3 sealed by east wall (763) of Structure Y [a trapezoidal stone-walled enclosure appended to inner wall face of the round]. Another coin found in (728), the surface of Structure Y, & 2 more in overlying soil (785). These 3 coins of similar date & condition, & formed part of scattered hoard.

A small hoard of 21 Roman imperial denarii (from Domitian to Commodus) and three bronze artefacts was found by a treasure hunter in March 2016 somewhere in Central Ukraine, probably in Cherkassy region. On March 10, 2016, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity was published information about the hoard and a photo of the coins and items from it (the finder identified the deposit as a “purse of denarii”). There is no information about the conditions of the find. The coins have heavy wear, one of the coins has strong oxide traces. The bronze items are rectangular in shape and are most likely belt plate: two measure 4.5x0.7cm and one (with six rivets) measures 4.3x1.3cm. In March 2016 the hoard was sold at the Violity auction, and the further fate of the coins is unknown.
A hoard of 74 denarii (Republic- Hadrian), found in 1854 approx. 1 km north of the place, 100 m from the street next to Dahnsdorf behind a hill in a ravine.
35 bronze coins: medallions and coins: Nero, Vespasian, Titus, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

The 22 coins (sestertii, Trajan - Marcus Aurelius) are the remnants derived from a hoard of at least five pounds from a meadow (Eckenweiher) where Roman villas have been found. The find is labelled as 'Kollektivfund' in FMRD.

18 denarii of which two imitations (one hybrid) found as a lump: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). The imitation denarii were struck with the same dies as other two denarii found in Ukraine (Dymowski 2017)
33 bronze coins found together in one insula of the former Roman city of Baetulo.

A hoard of about a 100 Roman bronze coins, found on the estate of Carstairs house (= Monteith House). Nero, Trajan, Faustina, Germanicus, M. Aurelius, M. Antoninus are mentioned. To this hoard belonged 13 coins presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland in 1781 (Trajan, Hadrian, the Empress Faustina, and Germanicus, are mentioned; the coin with Germanicus probably refers to an emperor Germanicus in its titles, e.g. Nero, Domitian or Trajan). No coins from this hoard have been located in NMAS, Edinburgh, or in Hunterian Museum, Glasgow. There is, however, in the University archives a letter from Mr. W. Fullerton, Carstairs House, dated 20 Oct. 1781, to Dr. A. Stevenson stating: "I send you a small box containing a dozen or more bronze medals intended for the College. About a hundred or more of them were found together by some workmen in repairing a road to a miln near this place [i.e. Carstairs House]. {...} They are cheifly [sic] Trajans Hadrian Antoninus Pius two or three Faustinas and one Marcus Aurelius Caesar and several others which from the inscription being much worn out their age cannot be so easily ascertained tho' on comparing them with Vallaint's [Vaillant's] Numismata they seem to be of Domitian. The place where they were found is about a quarter of a mile from an old Roman encampment or station [i.e. the Roman fort at Castledykes] of which part of the vallum remains still partly intire."

A hoard of 420 denarii, ranging from Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius, found near Alma Wood, Londonthorpe, together with fragments of the base of a small grey flagon which judging from its size and the marks of corrosion on the inside had originally contained the whole hoard. –A.J. White, in Lincs. Hist. and Arch., 12 (1977), 81; 13 (1978), 85
disposition: British Museum (part); Lincoln City and County Museum (part); Belton Trust (part); rest returned to finder

summary: A hoard of around 270 copper coinage, only 229 were recovered and identified: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-161).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Split, Croatia; partly dispersed

summary: Six coins found while extracting stone: Antoninus Pius 2, Faustina I 1, Commodus, 1 uncertain. No further information.

The hoard comprised a total of 1,133 coins, including 1,031 sestertii, 68 dupondii, 26 asses, 3 dupondii or asses and 5 imitations: Gaius - Commodus (AD 188-189). They were found during the excavation of building C in a Gallo-Roman vicus.
(c. 3000-3500) 474 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168)
300 denarii, found with a ceramic vessel 237 coins were recovered: Otho – Septimius Severus (AD 195).
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (227 coins); National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (10 coins; inv.no. 361)

summary: (3043) denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 1453 1-349; 1466 1-8; 1468 1-25; 1470 1-352

summary: 188 bronze coins fund in a ceramic vessel: 151 sestertii, 16 dupondii, 4 dupondii/asses, 17 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).
Four coins of Bar Kochba (AD 132-136).
14 denarii: Domitian 3; Nerva 3; Trajan 6; uncertain (Domitian or Trajan) 1; Hadrian 1 (AD 117-138).
Unknown originally number of denarii. 25 coins were seen: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192). Possible, part of the hoards with Strunga I and III.
11 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 105).
Hoard of 120 denarii. Among issuers, Trajan and Marcus Aurelius. No further details.

Four gold coins found in a stone sarcophagus during excavations: Vespasian, Titus, Hadrian 2. Together were found four denarii: Augustus, Trajan, Hadrian, Faustina I. Together were found gold and silver jewellery, vessels, glass objects.
109 coins: 105 bronze coins, 4 silver denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163). Also part of the deposit were the head of a hair pin and a ring. Considered as a votive offering.
Originally, 78 denarii, 14 preserved: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 189); silver weight: 36.63 g. (14 coins).

The 16 coins listed here (14 sestertii and two dupondii, ranging from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius) were found in the area of the Dampfziegelei in 1897 and 1898. All coins have the same patina and corrosion, so it could be a hoard. Further particulars about the circumstances of the find are undetermined.
Possibble hoard of unknown number of silver and bronze coins found within a cemetery. The only preserved coins are two denarii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120210: 1-2

summary: 51 denarii: 16 republican, 35 imperial: Republic - Hadrian (AD 119-122). Together was found a Dacian silver bracelet.
Around 350 denarii found in Duurzerdiep near Balloo. Only 85 denarii are known: Nero - Commodus (AD 180).
disposition: Drents Museum, Assen (84 coins), RMO, Leiden (4 coins), KPK, Leiden (1 coin); most disappeared PMD 84 coins; RMO 1 coin; [KPK 4 coins]; PMD: 80 coins: 58 in collection van der Feltz, 3 bought in 1871, 4 bought in 1873, 3 bought in 1881, 12 in the Frisian

summary: About 40 AR denarii found during construction of Bowers Fold redevelopment in 1963. The hoard was unreported and dispersed, two coins of Hadrian bought by Doncaster Museum.
Hoard of unknown original number of coins found with a ceramic jug. 96 denarii: Trajan - Clodius Albinus (AD 193).
disposition: Museum of History, Kyiv, Russia (50 coins; inv.nos. AR/9256-9304); Local History Museum, Chernovitsy, Ukraine (46 coins)

summary: Over 1,000 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 186-191).
Seven denarii found under a pile of Roman bricks: Trajan – Septimius Severus (AD 197).

Several hundreds coins (principally of Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, and Faustina), found in 1842, while removing some sods from the surface of a piece of moss land. Three publications (see under references) list groups of coins belonging to this hoard. Some coins had marks indicating that the hoard had been buried in a bag of coarse cloth. One further denarius of Trajan in HCC, p. 34, no. 207, Glasgow.
Three Roman bronze coins (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius Caesar) were found together in a field, inside an old foundation wall.
Two aurei were found on the banks of the Paleru river.
Unknown number of denarii. V. Haralanov studied 52 pieces: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

Råmosen, the numerically largest denarii hoard in Denmark, was found in 1782. The hoard consists of 428 denarii. There are two lists of coins for the hoard; one lists the end coin as a Marcus Aurelius, but there are contemporary letters mentioning coins with a portrait of Crispina.
Hoard of around 1,000 silver coins: 999 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-211).
disposition: Poltava Local History Museum (954 specimens; inv.nos. 4919-4920, 5090)

summary: 16 denarii found by metal detecting: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-163).
disposition: East Fife Museums, St. Andrews, United Kingdom (5 coins)

summary: A concealed hoard of 22 aurei of 'Nero, Hadrian and the Antonines' found c. 1888. It is believed that the hoard was from Wanborough / Durocornovium, but this is not certain.
764 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 103-111). Together were found four silver earrings and 3 silver bracelets found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Regional History Museum Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos M II 3331-4094 (764 coins)

summary: Some coins, unknown denomination, of Nerva, Trajan and Marcus Aurelius
58 denarii to Antoninus Pius (plus a probably unrelated IA stater) (not connected with the siliqua hoard from same parish)
102 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms found during excavations in the foundation of a house: Claudius I (Messalina) - Antoninus Pius (AD 149-150).
Four asses found during the excavations. To be checked whether were found together.
212 denarii found with a box: Nero - Septimius Severus (Cludius Albinus Caesar) (AD 194-195). Together were found 1 bronze box, 2 gold bracteates, 1 spiral rod and 1 gilt silver ring.
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.nos. 5204 coins; 4877 objects)

summary: Hoard of 47 Roman aurei documented in the archives of the Real Academia de la Historia - Antonio Delgado Fund: Nero - Antoninus Pius for Faustina II (AD 145-161).
60 denarii: Galba/Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
28 sestertii: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Collection E.C. Lefèvre, Brugge, Belgium, in 1851 (28 coins)

summary: 50 denarii found in the debris from a house foundation: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169).
disposition: Kärntner Landsmannschaft, Klagenfurt, Austria (46 coins); private collection (2 coins), lost (unknown number)

summary: Found close to the Brotonne forest on the property of Thouzé, which was once part of the park of the Château de la Mailleraye, demolished in 1857. The hoard was found under a tree.

Over 112 denarii found on the top soil scattered. Only 8 coins could be described: Vespasian, Trajan (Marciana), Hadrian (Sabina), Hadrian (Aelius), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla), Commodus, Commodus (Crispina), Spetimius Severus (AD 194). Circa 25 m from Jerzmanowice 2006 hoard. Most likely one owner.
Unknown originally number of coins. 86 bronze coins: Tiberius - Hadrian (AD 119-120).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain; private collections of M. Taborda and X. Taborda

summary: 14 denarii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 177); silver weight: 38.41 g.

The hoard originally comprised 1,305 Greek/Roman imperial/Roman provincial silver and bronze coins together with gold and silver ancient jewellery. Nowadays 1043 bronze coins and two couple gold earrings are kept in the Archaeological Museum of Shahat. According to the 1934 find report, the missing silver part featured 32 Greek silver coins (280-50 BC, including 16 coins from the Achaean League and four Rhodian drachms), 39 Roman imperial denarii and quinarii (Otho-Trajan, AD 69-116, mint of Rome) and 45 Roman provincial drachms and hemidrachms struck under Trajan (RPC III, 1-3, AD 100). These, as well as 89 sestertii, 77 dupondii, and 128 asses, were probably made in Rome for circulation in Cyrenaica.
Around 600 denarii of which only 17 provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Two denarii: Antoninus I (Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius.
NA
5, or possibly up to 8 aurei, from Nero to Diva Faustina I (AD 161). 5 aurei are listed here, and the other 3 ones (Bland/Loriot 343-5) are listed separately as single gold finds.
disposition: Harris Museum, Preston (part); Blackburn museum (2 coins)

summary: "About 100 tetradrachms and denarii together with a few dozen Roman coins (the latest being a fresh Hadrianic denarius...)" (Mildenberg 1984, 55).
14 bronze coins: 10 dupondii, 4 asses: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 164-169).
4 asses found during excavations: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144).
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 45373-45376

summary: 52 aurei ranging from Nero (AD 63/66) to Marcus Aurelius (AD 164), found at the Stephansgasse, in the foundations of a stone building. This hoard could be connected with the Marcomannic wars.
The hoard comprised approximately 200 'small Roman bronzes' of the Antonine period, most of which were well preserved. Unfortunately, an acid bath rendered them indecipherable.
7 denarii, ending with Marcus Aurelius AD 176. No further information.
Hoard of 104 denarii (317.79g): Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192). There is no information on the no. of coins per issuer.
278 denarii found with an small amphora: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca; Town Museum Gherla (20 coins), Romania

summary: 12 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 125-127).
In 1857/8 at least 11 denarii ranging from Vespasian to Hadrian were found during building work in the basement of a house.
80 denarii from Mark Anthony to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 165.
Eight denarii found at Testrup Teglværk with fragments of a clay pot. One additional denarius was found nearby also with fragments from a clay pot. The finds may represent a series of sacrifices.
10 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius) found corroded together with a bronze fibula and a clasp. They might have been contained in a purse.
2 aurei: Nero, Antoninus Pius .
Hoard of unknown number of denarii. Only two pieces are known: Trajan, Hadrian.
Around 142 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Friends of Science Society, Poznań, Poland (143 coins)

summary: 13 denarii from a discovery in the surroundings of the city: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
The hoard comprised 13 silver coins dated between AD 62/3 and AD 123.
Some aurei. Only five are presented from Nero to Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar).
Several hundred denarii found with an iron jar. Only six provided data on the issuers: Hadrian - Commodus.
6 denarii found on the construction site: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
Circa 50 denarii, kept in a belt? 49 documented: Galba – Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II) (AD 161-180).
disposition: National Museum, Prague, (inv.nos. H5-27.066–27.073); Museum of Poděbrady (inv.nos. 15.566–15.574, 15.576–15.577, 15.579–15.591) (inv.nos. 15.575, 15.578 were stolen), Czech Republic. Some of the coins are missing today.

summary: The hoard comprised Roman gold and silver coins: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Originally, 47 coins. 33 denarii were described: Vitellius - Trajan (AD 103-111).
272 coins found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 119-122).

This hoard was found in three ceramic pots and contained more than 4000 silver coins from which H. Ceka has published a total of about 3900 Roman Imperial coins in 1958. According to the publication of the hoard, which refers to the inquiry held by the Albanian Institutions at the time of the discovery, the hoard was constituted by silver coins and gold jewelry (rings, necklaces) but the latter was dispersed immediately after the discovery. Also, more than 100 coins were dispersed after the discovery. The coins are mostly Denarius dating from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (54-175 AD). Based on the numismatic data (there is no archaeological excavation that can help at the precision of the hoard's burying date), it should have been buried around or short after 170 AD.
disposition: The hoard is actually part of the collection of the Coin Cabinet, Institute of Archaeology, Albania

summary: 7 aurei: 6 Hadrian, 1 Sabina (AD 132-134)
disposition: Museum of Iron Gates Region Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania

summary: A hoard of 10 aurei and 120+ denarii, found in 1878 near the Roman fort. The closure date of this hoard is AD 192. However the penultimate coin is an issue of 185 and a seven year gap between the terminal issues is unusual. In the event the hoard is listed as closing with RIC 241, with the caveat that the last coin may be a site find rather than a hoard item (P.J. Casey).
70 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Hadrian.

A hoard of about 400 Roman silver coins, found at Torfoot, 7 miles south-west of Strathaven, in a glass bottle, while cleaning a drain. Coins of Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina, wife of Antoninus, Crispina, wife of Commodus, and various other Emperors and Empresses, &c., all in good preservation, are mentioned. About fifty of the coins were so much verdigreated and adhering together, that they were broken with a hammer by a rude and unskillful hand, in order to separate them. J. Lindsay, View of the Coinage of Scotland (1845), 265, added Hadrian, Marcus, Caesar, Pompey and Crassus to the list of emperors etc. represented. The three last names may have been due to a misunderstanding of the legends on some coins. True Republican den. would be unusual in a hoard as late as the reign of Commodus.
215 denarii: Nero to Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
Unknown number of denarii. Only two of them are known: Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius for Lucilla (AD 161-180).
1,268 coins: 7 aurei, 1,261 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 136-138). Total weight: 4,023.93g.
disposition: Historischen Museum der Stadt Wien (Karlsplatz), Austria

summary: Eight sestertii found in Pot Ridings Wood.
The hoard of 175 gold and silver Iron Age coins, and 23 Roman denarii, ranging from from c. 50 BC to the latter half of the second century AD, uncovered on a field at Waltham St. Lawrence.
In 1853 not far from the Oste river during earthworks three bronze coins (Marcus Aurelius) were found at a depth of 10 feet. Pit holes and other remains indicate a settlement.
53 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Circumstances of discovery are unknown.
42 denarii, ranging from Nero to Didius Julianus. It is unsure whether three antoniniani (1 Gallienus, 2 Probus) and 1 denarius of Elagabalus were part of the hoard as well.
Hoard of 340 denarii were found with a bronze cauldron. Together was a silver ring.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: 37 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927 and 1928, now, in a private collection: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 101.03 g.
disposition: Private collection Axel O. Larsson, Stockholm

summary: Grup of three denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius. Found in a plundered grave dated in the second half of the 6th century AD.
Unknown originally number of coins. 52 denarii were found with a hand-made ceramic vessel: Mark Antony – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised 57 dupondii and asses from Augustus to Antoninus Pius with a tpq of AD 150 to 151.

A hoard of at least 50 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver and gold buckle were discovered by a treasure hunter no later than 2021, probably in Zhytomyr region. Information about the hoard and general photo of the coins with the buckle were published in one of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting on November 1, 2021. One of the group members (Vasyl Ugrynchuk of Volodarsk in Zhitomyr region) reported that the hoard was discovered by his acquaintances (possibly also from Zhytomyr region). On the photo denarii of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus can be recognized. The buckle is quite massive (ca. 5-7 cm), on the clip there is a gold plate with ornamentation. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
7 sestertii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) found in a building from the military vicus.
disposition: Centrul de Studii de Istorie și Arheologie, Timișoara, Romania; inv.no. 237/2005

summary: The hoard comprised several hundred Roman coins (the majority being sestertii) contained in a wooden box. The hoard was found 2 or 300 metres from the conciergerie of the Hypogeum on the left towards the water tower.
The hoard comprised 11 bronze coins, dating between AD 79/80 and AD 119/120.

A mixed hoard of 18 coins (Vitellius - Diva Faustina II) was unearthed in the southern area of the civilian town. The date of the latest coin is given as AD 145/161 in FMRD, but the reference of that coin (RIC 1383) is dated to AD 163-164.
The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel hidden under a stone and comprised 3 coins including a sestertius of Nerva, a denarius of Trajan and an as of Hadrian.
Hoard of 300 denarii found with a vessel. 130 pieces are known: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: At the beginning of the 20th century, in the collection of the industrialist Hertig in Łódź.

summary: 45 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Examined and photographed December 1962 in Athens by Hackens at a dealer of antiquities, who reported the hoard to have been found near Aswan.'
A hoard of 121 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), found at the edge of the gravel pit northeast of Schwepnitz, approx. 0.3 km east of the Schwepnitz - Gottschdorf road.
9 denarii and 2 aes (Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius) found in Room 28.
21 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
6 sestertii were found at a gravel pit close to Eisenfeld.
Hoard of circa 350 silver coins. 26 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). A tetradrachm of Thassos (intruder?) were documented.

Three denarii (1 of Trajan and 2 of Septimius Severus that share the same obverse die) from the same context (C/26/34), that may represent a small hoard, found at Kifrin, a large fortified settlement with Parthian and Roman phases of the 2nd and 3rd c. AD, on the east bank of the Euphrates.
A hoard of 52 denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius) and 1 drachm of Amisus, found during the breaking up of soil in Lausitz. The hoard might have been associated with a series of 7 cremation graves.

Portions of this hoard were acquired by the ANS in 1911 and 1912, totaling 783 coins. 451 of these could be identified in the museum's collection, including 448 denarii, Vespasian to Commodus (AD 183-184) and 3 Cypriote didrachms of Vespasian. This hoard is said to have been discovered in Larnaka, though no details are available.
The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing 100 Roman coins including denarii, sestertii and dupondii, nearly all issues of Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and Faustina II.

A hoard of 49 denarii (Mark Antony - Commodus, including a Lycian drachm of Trajan), found while digging for peat in the vicinity of Dellstedt (Nordermoor). The coins were found in a cavity, reflecting the size of the original container (leather bag or wooden box). Eight coins have been lost.

c. 1400 coins, mostly aurei, of which only 45 specimens were recorded, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius (43 aurei, 1 denarius of Nero and 1 of Galba), found during illegal excavations in Kuşakkaya.
disposition: Adıyaman museum; Kahramanmaraş museum; private collection in Ankara

summary: 154 denarii found with a small ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: According to W. Łonak, the coins were kept by the Provincial Heritage Department for Cultural-Historical Soil Alterations in Racibórz.

summary: 103 denarii (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found near a large stone building and a series of ditches identified by a geophysical survey in 1999 and described as a farmhouse. The site has turned up building debris, pottery, and a series of other metal finds, including at least 46 other denarii that might have come from the coin hoard (Treasure report SS 91 69).
Hoard of 125 denarii. The large majority belong to Trajan including the title DACICVS. The hoard was found with two silver vessels embedded each other.
307 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Maramureș, Baia Mare, Romania

summary: Around 600 denarii; Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: In 1906, there were 355 coins in the Coin Room of the Royal Academy in Königsberg, 16 copies in the Museum of Prussia, Königsberg. The fate of the rest is unknown. Approximately 250 denars were melted down. Lost

summary: 30 denarii: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 140-144). Found near the Roman villa.
101 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175).
Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 63 coins were recovered, 62 denarii, 1 drachm: Vitellius – Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).
368 aurei: Nero to Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
Around 100 hundred Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii/asses): Domitian - Didius Julianus (AD 193)
disposition: Museum of Chambéry, France (partially). private collections: Conte, Faudrain, Fivel etc.

summary: 11 AR denarii to AD 122. Latest coin is type of Hadrian-Fortuna referring to the departure of the emperor on his great expedition, AD 121-5. RIC assigns date range of AD 119-122.Addenda of 3 AR denarii to 117 in 2014 included here.

15 Roman gold coins described in the Madras Museum Accessions Register as 'purchases through individuals through the Collector of Canara'. It is unclear whether rhey represent a genuine hoard. Possible part of the cache of Roman coins dating from the first and second centuries A.D. was reportedly discovered some 600 kms. further to the north, on Kadmat Island in the neighbouring Laccadives group (Indian Union Territory of Lakshadweep) during 1948
A hoard of ancient coins, including a tetradrachm of Thassos and a denarius of Faustina I found with a ceramic vessel.

Unknown originally number of denarii. 5 coins are kept in the History Museum in Bacău: Trajan 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) 1, Marcus Aurelius 2, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II) 1.
12 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 178). Some doubts have been expressed as the coins are now in a private collection.
A 'valuable find of gold and silver coins', of which one coin was a denarius of Antoninus Pius (broken and much defaced), found on Dewsbury Moor, near remains of two Roman querns.

Two groups of coins, discovered in May 1989 while metal detecting on building ground at Elphinstone Road, Hastings. The first group of coins (92 bronze coins, Nero - Hadrian) were found with the remains of a pot and the second group (52 denarii found 'in a lump', with 7 later addenda, Republic - Hadrian) was about 40 to 50 feet away from the first. This may suggest successive deposits but they were treated as one find at the time. They have been split here. This record is for the silver coins.
13 denarii found with a money-box: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 153-154).
(ca.30) 12 sestertii and dupondii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; auxiliary fund, inv.no. 693

summary: A hoard of one denarius of Divus Antoninus Pius and one Roman Provincial coin of Marcus Aurelius minted in Edessa, found in grave 22 in the western cemetery in Pella.

A hoard of 757 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver ingot was discovered by a treasure hunter on January 11, 2018 in the Lviv region. Information about the find, the silver ingot and a general photo of the bunch uncleaned coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on 11 and 12 January 2018. According to the finder, the hoard was discovered in the forest at a depth of 30-40 cm. Initially a few slipped coins were found, and then the rest of the hoard. Among the coins, a silver ingot (ca. 8.7x1.5 cm) and a fragment of pottery were found. Only photos of 17 coins and the silver ingot were published separately. The further fate of the hoard is unknown, however, most probably it was sold at the Violity auction. Coins: Nerva (1), Hadrian (4), Hadrian (Aelius) (1), Hadrian (Antoninus Pius) (1), Antoninus Pius (3), Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (1), Marcus Aurelius (3), Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (1), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (1), Commodus (1), no information (740).
Some silver coins found in a garden. Only one denarius of Hadrian and one of Commodus were documented.
Four coins found in Jülich, during the construction of the technology center.
7 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) found in an Iron Age warrior grave.
200 bronze coins: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
204 aurei found with a ceramic vessel, 97 pieces studied: Nerva - Commodus.
A hoard of 3-400 aurei. 42 coins were recovered. They are all issues of Lucius Verus, 3 types (Coh. 157, 247, 248).
disposition: Royal Coin Room, Amsterdam, Netherlands (3 coins since 1894); 1 coin in Berlin

summary: 30 sestertii found stuck together in a Roman edifice: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD162-163).
disposition: Museo de Arqueología de Álava, Spain

summary: Hoard of 89 gold stateri of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates I - 3, Cotys II - 6, Rhoemetalkes - 11, Eupator - 69.
A farmer in 1864 found over 60 specimens of Roman silver coins during plowing on a small hill in the vicinity of Erfurt. 29 coins were described (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius).
Unknown number of denarii hoard. 4 coins entered museum collection in Yambol: Vespasian 2, Nerva 1, Trajan 1.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2924-2929

summary: Unknown number of denarii found in two small ceramic vessels placed 100 m from each other. 38 pieces are known from one of the vessels: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 163-164).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1600 44-81

summary: The hoard(?) comprised a "cluster" of 13 silver and bronze coins deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

An ensemble of 6 denarii (incl. Vespasian, Hadrian with Clementia on the reverse, 2 Antoninus, 2 Crispina), found during excavations at the broch of Lingro, 1870-71, in different parts of the outbuildings [i.e. of the broch], that may have come from a scattered hoard.
271 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 268 handed to the National Museum in Bucharest: Nero - Marcus Aurelius. One denarius may depict Julia Domna?
disposition: National Museum of History, Bucharest, Romania; Museum of History and Archaeology, Piatra Neamț, Romania (the vessel)

summary: 39 Roman imperial denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Seven bronze coins (asses): Trajan – Antoninus Pius (AD 140-144). The coins were placed in a cooking pot with lid together with seven clay lamps, type FORTIS.

Three denarii of Hadrian, found around 1896 on the Debra, a plateau approx. 1.5 km northeast of Rudolstadt, near Debrahof, on Rudolstadt-Teichweiden road; the coins could form part of a larger hoard of denarii.
22 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194).
The hoard comprised 5 gold coins, 15 silver coins, and 4 bronze coins dated to the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Report in BM file with information from Suffolk county Council on a group of 7 or 8 coins, only three readily identifiable. Details of the latter only were received.
Unknown initial number of coins. 244 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-175)
The hoard comprised approximately 250 sestertii dating to the second century AD and weighing between 5 and 6kg.
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 400 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Vespasian to Commodus. Most were very worn.
5 AE (2 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius and 2 unidentified)
26 bronze coins: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 183).

summary: (8-900) 52 aurei: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 172-175).
disposition: Collection Rockox (37 coins), in 17th century; collection Van Gestel (1 coin), in 17th century; collection Christine de Suède (non-identifiable)

summary: The total number of coins is apparently 1067 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 152-153).
Five aurei found in grave no. 6: Nero, Galba, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found 11 drachms of Gotarze and 3 denarii of Augustus.

33 denarii (Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius) found by a party of schoolchildren among rubble in a chamber of the prehistoric and Roman mine workings beneath the hill fort at Llanymynech Ogof. The coins were fused together before being separated by a local antiquarian. A piece of black pottery picked up on another occasion close to the site of the discovery may possibly indicate that the hoard has been disturbed at some time.
disposition: National Museums Wales, Cardiff (part); Oswestry Museum (part)

summary: Hoard found with an amphora: 2 aurei, 2,804 denarii, 2 bronzes: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166). Together was found a ceramic lamp.
disposition: Private collections: A. Ancona,F. Gnecchi (365 coins), M. Anti (1,080 coins) (in 1887)

summary: Date of discovery is date of publication, so might be one year earlier. Uncertain number of bronze Tiberius and Marcus Aurelius coins, thus at least 2, found during dike reconstruction found together with glass, bronze objects, terra sigillata, jars, urns and rough earthenware. A bronze purse in the shape of a boat was found in or around 1939 in the same village and might be connected
38 bronze coins found in a small sewer found as one block: Vespasian - Commodus (AD
2 denarii found on manor field: C. Porcius Cato, Hadrian (119-122).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic

summary: The deposit was found at the major Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary site at comprised three asses from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 164.
The hoard comprised 6 Roman Provincial coins: Dion (2 Trajan, 1 Hadrian), Thessalonica (1 Trajan, 1 pseudo-autonomous Antoninus Pius), found in grave 7 in Sevasti.
4,418 tetradrachms of Alexandria and three bronze coin: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus). Three large amphorae, filled with coins, dug out of the cellar of a house.
disposition: Type set of 519 coins in Oxford. 114 in London. 80 billon coins, presented to Glasgow in 1902 by the Egypt Exploration Fund and now among the duplicates, probably belong to this hoard. The rest dispersed. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: 2 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Trajan, Antoninus Pius; silver weight: 5.57 g.

summary: 26 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 176-177).
Four Roman bronze coins, excavated in shell sand north of the island Süderoog. The find depth was approximately 6 m.
Hoard of 17 aurei. Only two are known: Pertinax, Septimius Severus.

summary: Hoard of circa 60 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only 18 denarii were documented.

171 coins: 169 denarii,1 sestertius, 1 dupondius: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-159).

summary: The hoard comprised a double deposit within a single room of a building. In one corner of the room, there were four coins, including one of Marcus Aurelius, 1 of Lucilla and 2 of Commodus. In the opposite corner, there was an identical deposit.
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 30 bronze coins of Antoninus Pius. A bronze bell was found at the same findspot.
Group of six denarii found on the same area of an ancient settlement (?): Mark Antony - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161/post). Similar structure with RATENICE 2002
21 denarii: Galba - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 91 denarii in the Regional History Museum in Pleven: Otho - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

summary: A hoard of two Antonine sestertii and several items of gold jewellery, found in grave 23 in the western cemetery of Pella.

110 denarii. Only 79 were recovered: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193); silver weight: 202.4-323.4 g.
Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 304 coins were recovered together with the vessel's sherds: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
102 bronze coins found with an amphora and dispersed in the coin trade: Tiberius - Marcus aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard originally comprised 21 bronze coins found with an amphora: Vespasian-Antoninus Pius (73-145 AD). Only 18 coins are still available.
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto, Padova, Iatly

summary: 160 denarii, 80 recovered: 41 republican, 39 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 102-103).
disposition: National Museum of Union, Alba Iulia, Romania

summary: A hoard of denarii, found while digging sand in a sand-pit, between the Lion Foundry, Kirkintilloch, and Barley Bank houses. 24 coins were first published in 1894, followed by a more complete list in 1911 (42 coins). 5 more coins were found since, giving a total of 47 denarii (Vespasian - Faustina II) that were published.
The hoard comprised 22 aurei (70 ca.-158-159 AD) found most likely between the West Bank, Upper Galilee and the Golan.
Two denarii of Hadrian (AD 134-138).
Unknown originally number of coins. 59 bronze coins are known: 51 sestertii, 9 dupondii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
A hoard of 54 bronze coins (Tiberius - Diva Faustina II) found during excavations in the Roman vicus; it was unearthed in stages, in 1983 and then 1986.
60 denarii found, probably, with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
81 denarii found with a ceramic vessel while building a new house: Otho - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-180).

The hoard was discovered in 1850 by a private person during a search quarry stones. The coins lay concealed without a discernible container in the wall aperture of a Roman cellar (Quintan- obere prätorische Straße)). The hoard is thought to have comprised 360-370 denarii. 280 of them are now in the collection of antiquities from Nassau, in Wiesbaden. Coins range from Nero to Antoninus Pius.
Unknown original number of coins. 15 pieces are known: 14 denarii, 1 dupondius: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic (7 coins); Collection Červinkova (8 coins)

summary: (200) 38 denarii: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

A small hoard of six Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian — Hadrian (AD 117-138) was discovered by treasure hunter in 2014, possibly in Rivne region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on November 28, 2016, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the find was discovered about two years ago before publication in a ploughed field. The coins were collected from a small area, but he did not probe to sondage on the place of find, assuming that he would find new finds after each ploughing. However, he has not found any new coins at the site in two years. All coins are equally well preserved (minimal worn) and close chronologically, which allows them to be considered as one deposit. In December 2016 and January 2018, the coins were sold on Violity auction. Coins: Vespasian (Titus) (1), Titus (2), Hadrian (3).
The hoard comprised 16 denarii dated between AD 98/99 and AD 128/129.
Five denarii: Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Augusta) (AD 172-173).

177 denarii with portraits of emperors from Vespasian to Trajan and two denarii of Mark Antony's 'legionary' series. The denarii were found with a ceramic vessel. The metal analyses, fresh minting loo-alike state of preservation for the large majority of the coins as well as the overweight for most of the coins reveal a 'hoard' of ancient counterfeited coins. The dating of coin type is based on the genuine prototype, otherwise, it looks that they were all minted in/after AD 116.
disposition: Museum of National Union, alba Iulia, Romania

summary: Five denarii (Vespasian - Commodus Caesar), found together on the premises of the Pipinsburg (a megalithic hillfort of Viking times), close to Sievern.
Five denarii found together: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

28 bronze coins found near a skeleton: 27 provincial coins minted on Cyprus (uncertain mint under Augustus and Tiberius; Koinon of Cyprus for Claudius, Vespasian, and Trajan) and 1 sestertius of Trajan (AD 114-117).
32 bronze coins found glued to each other: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
646 denarii layed in the ground: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195). 152 coins of this find disappeared between 1907 and 1975.
1243 silver coins: 1241 denarii, 2 drachmas: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 164)
Around 2,000 denarii found on the surface after the river outflow. Only 8 denarii were known: Trajan 2, Hadrian 1, Faustina I 3, Commodus 2.

The denarii (Vespasian - Trajan) were found together with a bronze brooch in the main building of a villa rusticate, located between Altdorf and Jülich-Kirchberg, on the site of the Inden open pit mining site (Braunkohletagebau Inden).

A hoard of at least 160 Roman imperial denarii was found by a treasure hunter in 2009 or 2010 near the village of Baikivka. According to his information, the hoard was partially ploughed, but the main part of it was at a depth of ca. 50 cm together with fragments of a vessel (pot?). The coins had traces of bronze oxides. Photographs of the deposit have not been preserved, but it is known that most of the coins date from the Nerva-Antonine dynasty, including coins of Antoninus Pius and Commodus. The fate of the coins is unknown.
15 of the sestertii from a larger hoard were identified by S. Bottin. The hoard was originally located in Bellaing in error.
1,055 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (1,042 coins; inv.no. C 706); History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (8 coins); private collections (5 coins)

summary: 4 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus (Crispina) (AD 178-188); silver weight: 10.25 g.
A hoard of 24 denarii, found on the Dwoberg in 1795. Of these, 22 (Hadrian - Commodus) were found to be in the Oldenburg state museum.
50 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 137.84 g.
Five denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), found while digging for peat in the vicinity of the Buchow-Karpzow estate, probably only part of a larger find.
Unknown originally number of coins. 11 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).
162 sestertii and 1 as. The origins of this hoard is doubtful. It is also possible that it contains 2 sestertii from Marcus Aurelius and 2 imitations of a double sestertius from Postumus.
13 denarii found in a mound next to ceramic vessels: Antoninus Pius - Commodus(AD 180).
disposition: Frisian Museum, Leeuwarden (FML A 1129-1141), 2 coins lost.

summary: 13 bronze coins: 9 sestertii, 4 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius Aurelius (AD 166).
24 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius I to Commodus (AD 180-183).
129 bronze coins (1 provincial) unknown denomination: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-158)
76 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Otho - Marcus Aurelius (AD 179).
Hoard of 6 Roman coins, most likely denarii, including: Vespasian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Five 2nd century AD bronze coins, found in the area of the town hall.
135 denarii found by metal detecting: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195). Together were found: Flint pendant; an iron chain; a ceramic spindle.
Over 600 denarii found while digging up a grave. Only 6 pieces provide information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 179-180).
70 imperial bronze coins of poor state of conservation. Among them, issues of Antoninus Pius 12, Faustina I 1.
10 coins, a finger ring and a fibula in a wooden case with 3 hinges preserved
disposition: Musée communal des Beaux Arts et d'Archéologie de Nivelles

summary: 16 sestertii: Trajan 13, Hadrian 3 (AD 121-122).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 13625-13640

summary: The hoard comprised 171 aurei and 1 denarius from Nero to Marcus Aurelius.
disposition: União de Bancos Portugueses. Fundação Millenium, Oporto, Romania

summary: 1 silver + 4 bronze coins: (1st century -2nd century AD), Augustus - Commodus (AD 192) found during archaeological excavations.
11 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
HER record of a first century hoard found on Sheringham Beach along with remains of a ceramic container, exposed through cliff erosion. Only 5 coins were examined but the hoard was much larger.
112 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
Around 700 denarii found with a ceramic vessel, of which 167 provided information on the issuers: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
disposition: Museum of History, Lwow, Poland; private collection

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 840 well-preserved sestertii, of which 808 were identified by Auvray. The composition of this hoard varies slightly in lists compiled by Ledru and Cauvin. L'annuaire l'An VIII mentions coins of Septimius Severus and of Caracalla from the same parish. It is possible that these were also a part of the hoard, although they have not been added to the database record.
70 denarii: 69 Rome issues, 1 imitation: Trajan - Commodus (AD 187-188). Together, it was found a ring made of a silver-coloured metal.
20 sestertii and 1 as: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Several hundred Roman silver coins (coins of Galba - Antoninus Pius / Marcus Aurelius are mentioned), found during building working in Minden, in or before 1844. The coins were lost.

469 (or more?) silver coins of Caesarea in Cappadocia found with a ceramic vessel. These range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). The hoard also included one denarius of Augustus and a barbarous imitation of a stater of Lysimachus.
disposition: National Museum of Georgia; National Museum of Abkhazia (91 coins); Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow, Russia (104 coins)

summary: 5-6 silver and bronze coins. Among them one piece of Antoninus Pius.
Hoard of unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 13 coins were bought: Trajan, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 4, Marcus Aurelius 2, Lucius Verus, Faustina II, Commodus 2.
16 coins of Hadrian (AD 117-138). No further information.

The hoard comprised 116 silver coins: 111 denarii, 1 denarius serratus, 2 quinarii, 2 drachms: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-158). Found in a ceramic vessel with a terra sigillata bowl serving as a lid.
15 sestertii as a foundation offering: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
16 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 192).
119 Alexandrian billon tetradrachms: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 155-156) Found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935), inv.no. 445

summary: The hoard was found in a female burial and contained a box or casket containing 18 Antonine coins, earrings, brooches, a belt buckle and a terracotta figurine in the shape of a small horse.

Unknown original number of coins. 184 denarii of which two imitations: Vespasian - Didius Julian (AD 193). Found together with a "belt set of one massive silver buckle for a sword belt and two buckles for a girdle. The find also contains eighty-four silver belt plaits. This belt set, dating to the latter half of the 5th century AD (phase D2 of the Great Migration Period), is a girdle for bladed weaponry."
disposition: The State Museum of Military History and Natural Preserve “The Kulikovo Polye”, Tula, Russia (inv.no. BX 1823/1-184)

summary: The coins were found in a block, stuck together with corrosion products and comprised 151 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Trajan to Commodus. The coins were found during gravel extraction in the river and may represent a hoard washed out from a riverbank or a votive deposit.
24 denarii found ina lump of earth: Domitian – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A hoard of 161 aurei and 4 denarii was discovered on the site of 29 Klagenfurter Str. in Villach. Four aurei were initially discovered before a supervised excavation at the site uncovered the rest of the coins. Of the 161 aurei, only 100 issues dating from Nero to Septimius Severus have been properly catalogued. The four denarii have all been catalogued: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 194-197).
disposition: Museum Der Stadt Villach (115 aurei and 4 denarii); private collection (42 aurei)

summary: A hoard of 304 silver coins (303 denarii and 1 drachm), ranging from Nero to Commodus, found in summer 2019 (with 6 additional coins found in 2020) on the Adlerberg, near Pratteln.
The hoard comprised 20 denarii from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 180-192) and was found inside an ostrich egg.
The hoard comprised 461 bronze coins, including 4 dupondii and asses and 457 sestertii of Galba to Marcus Aurelius, with a tpq of AD 172 to 173.

46 denarii (Vitellius to Antoninus Pius) discovered in a farm yard. Wynn Williams (1875) observed that the hoard was discovered at ground level, having been exposed by traffic and other activity in the farm yard: "The surface was very hard, and they were actually sticking out of the ground on their edges. Judging from a pen and ink sketch sent me, they must have been closely packed together side by side... evidently the road had got scraped and worn down by wheels, and thus exposed them; but they had been noticed before any one took the trouble to pick them up."

The hoard comprised 65 sestertii from Domitian to Commodus (AD 180-192). All the coins were very worn. Fragments of a ceramic vessel were found in association with the coins suggesting it was originally placed inside a pot.
2 denarii: Trajan, Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).
16 coins: 1 denarius, 15 bronzes were found as "cast bronze core" of 570g.

Over 40 Roman bronze coins, nummi of the Constantius II and the Houses of Valentinian I and of Theodosius I. Unearthed in 1888 by villagers digging a grave. No further details were reported. Bell, the then Archaeological Commissioner, was able to secure 40 pieces. The coin types were: Constantius II: fel temp reparation (falling horseman). House of Valentinian I: concordia auggg (Roma or Constantinopolis). House of Theodosius: salus reipublicae (victory/captive); virtus exerciti (emperor/victory); gloria Romanorum (two emperors).

West Parade site Area III, Roman interval tower. In late Roman period, interval tower became derelict, & much of upper part prob. demolished/ robbed. Lower part of tower infilled with demolition debris, incl. ceramic tile frags. & mortar, animal bone waste from food consumption, & bird & animal skeletons, incl. ravens & dogs, frogs & toads, & remains of owl pellets. 3 silver denarii in fine condition also found amongst demolition debris, of Trajan, Hadrian & Faustina, minted in early to mid 2nd C. before tower even built; & it is likely that they were hidden & subsequently lost, poss. as part of a larger hoard, whilst tower was still in use.Gilmour, B. 1999. Excavations. In C. Colyer, B.J.J. Gilmour & B. Jones The Defences of the Lower City. Excavations at The Park and West Parade 1970-2 and a Discussion of Other Sites Excavated up to 1994. The Archaeology of Lincoln VIII-2. CBA Res. Report 114, pp. 191.
The hoard comprised around 200 tetradrachms and 1,000 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
The hoard was discovered in 2013 within the boundaries of Vaukavyski County. Consisted of at least 140 denarii (Nerva-Commodus). The circumstances and exact location of the find are unknown.
Hoard of unknown number of denarii. Only for 7 cois is given Information on the issuers: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 172-192).
c. 300 sestertii from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No further information about composition of hoard.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia; dispersed; Ervin Meixner coll.

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Most likely there is just one hoard found here and 36 denarii are known: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
IARCH record for a hoard of five denarii of Septimius Severus in a small conical lead-alloy container.
99 denarii: Otho - Commodus (AD 182-183).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale, Ancona, Italy (inv. nos. 7395/22336 - 7493/22434)

summary: The hoard comprised 23 sestertii struck for Trajan, Hadrian, and Antoninus Pius. Discovered at a depth of 4 metres when a drainage ditch was being dug during road improvement works to the south of the railway station in Kiesen.
10 denarii found on a field: Trajan - Commodus (AD 186-187); silver weight: 26.87 g.
65 Roman silver coins found a small urn or earthern vessel, while removing the root of a tree near the house of Mr. Burke, at Beaconsfield. The coins ranged from Vespasian to Faustina.
20 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 188-189). Among them two imitations. Together it was found an iron axe typical for the Chernyakhov culture (4th-5th centuries AD).
Hoard of 100 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Hoard of 171 denarii, only 139 were recorded: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Museum Complex Iași, Romania (121 coins); National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (50 coins)

summary: 700 aurei and denarii found with a pot, probably ending with coins of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

In 1867 a hoard of denarii was discovered in a sand hill on the left bank of the Oste river two miles from the estuary. The six preserved coins run from Vespasian to Commodus. It is to be assumed that the hoard was composed of more specimens.
30 bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found 800 m eastward from the hoard Koropie 2008 2
disposition: Laboratory of Archeology, Historical Sociology and Cultural Heritage, Faculty of Sociology, St. Petersburg State University, Russia

summary: Originally, 1,500 denarii and a drachm found with a clay vessel. 1,391 coins preserved: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 3,924.6 g. (1.391 coins).
2 denarii of Hadrian (AD 117-138).
9 coins: 1 aureus, 3 denarii, 1 sestertius, 4 asses: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138)

About 40 aurei were found by a peasant while he was digging, he also found a Hindu temple. This is the earliest recorded find of Roman coins on Indian soil. The hoard seems to have consisted exclusively of second-century coins.
2 denarii: Commodus, 1 imitation of Marcus Aurelius; silver weight: 5.06 g.
A hoard of 296 denarii (Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius), found by a grave-digger in Allerton Bywater churchyard.
255 denarii found and sent to the Ministry of Finance. The coins were found with pieces of an urn during the removal of stones from a field.
Leather purse with 10 bronze rings and 11 bronze coins: Trajan - Antoninus Pius. Only one bronze coin of Antoninus Pius is known.
770 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Among issuers: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius.
10 coins found together in a tomb (purse?): Domitian -Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).
Group of 3 denarii: Nerva, Trajan, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard was found in a vessel containing coins of the Principate, including 2 coins of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius.
More than 188 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). 'Found at Avenue of the Sphinxes during clearance excavations.'
A hoard of approx. 35 gold coins (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), scattered within a small space in fire debris of a destructed Roman house, found during work on the canalisation in the Leostrasse.
Possible hoard of Roman denarii. Only two coins are known, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius.
disposition: History Museum, Riga, Latvia (entered in 1928) (inv. no. 120210/1-2)

summary: The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing approximately 50 sestertii of Trajan, Hadrian and Antoninus Pius. The hoard was found on the Mortrais farm.

A hoard of 427 silver coins (426 denarii and one Lycian drachm), of which the first lot was found in 1910 in a clay pot, while ploughing a field. It comprised 367 Roman denarii (Nero to Commodus), one Lycian drachm of Trajan and one contemporary cast forgery, also from Trajan. A further lot of 50 denarii (Mark Antony – Commodus) was found between April and December 1988 by members of the Chesterfield Metal Detector Club, in the vicinity of the first lot and can be regarded as a further portion of the same find. A further 8 denarii (Vitellius - Antoninus Pius) were found with the aid of metal detectors in November 2012.
disposition: Doncaster Museum (part); Newark Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 26 denarii are known at the moment: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
Heap of sestertii, 6: Trajan 4, Commodus 1, uncertain 1 (AD 180-192).

12 coins listed as 'loosely associated with the hoard' from Cadeby in CHRB (no. 2519) and said to have been found 60-80 yards away. These were treated as a separate Treasure Trove case so an additional entry has been created here. They may have been part of another scattered hoard.
Found during excavations, in an early medieval cemetery. Tomb 569B: inhumation, male; among grave goods 3 (?) Aes coins, part of the "Tascheninhalt".
It comprised 200 sestertii from Antoninus Pius to Commodus (AD 180-192) found with a ceramic vessel.

A very large find of Roman denarii, made in 1858 in the vicinity of Filsum. Around 1960, three further denarii (Domitian Caesar, Commodus) were found on a field, and can probably be connected with the same find.
124 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-189); silver weight: 43.80 g. (16 coins).
3200 silver coins found with bronze cauldron: 3197 denarii, 3 drachmas Lycia: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-161) . 10.8 kg
disposition: Museum ”Dr. Molnár István”, Cristuru Secuiesc, Romania (1965)

summary: 15 sestertii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174-175).
disposition: Groninger Museum (12 coins), private collection (3 coins)

summary: A small hoard of 4 Roman imperial denarii: Marcus Aurelius - Didius Julianus (AD 193) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early July 2023 somewhere in Cherkasy region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity July 3, 2023. The finder reported that the coins were discovered “in one small pit”. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
A hoard of five bronze coins (Philippi, Koinon of Macedonia, Topirus), found in grave T2 in Lithochori.
28 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-139). Probably a hoard, found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935)

summary: Lake Borresø surrounds the medieval castle of Lilleborg. During the draining of the lake in 1832 a mixed gold- and silver hoard was found. "Some" gold fingerrings, of which only one was recovered, and "several" denarii, of which sixteen were handed over to the later National Museum, were found "as if packed into something which had now disappeared".
Six aurei Possible part of a larger hoard.
Six denarii (Domitian - Hadrian), found in the estuary of the River Weser in 1842.
40 denarii found in a ceramic vessel. Majority belongs to Hadrian.
Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 95 coins provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Pertinax (AD 193).
235 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Clodius Albinus (AD 193-197).
The hoard was hidden inside the camp: 25 aurei, 610 denarii, 2 asses, 1 quadrans, as well as gold and silver jewelry in a bronze cauldron: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 165-166).
disposition: Historischen Museum der Stadt Regensburg, Germany

summary: 2 Iron Age gold quarter-staters, 18 denarii and 1 quinarius to Antoninus Pius and 6 copper-alloy votive objects.
68 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 150-151).
14 copper coins, reported as dated between possibly 69 and 117 AD, but inter alia Vespasian, Domitian, Hadrian, so 69-138 in any case.

Seven denarii (Trajan - Antoninus Pius), set on a goblet ('Pokal') dating to around 1830, which were part of a hoard found in a pot at the beginning of the 19th c. on the grounds of the mansion of Welsede.

In 1900 the Hanauer museum acquired 44 denarii from an antique dealer in Büdingen, which obviously belonged to a find. The coins were supposedly found in 1899 in Marköbel during the construction of a house. The coins are today no longer present in the Hanauer museum. Coins range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus).
Nine denarii placed in a cavity: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 185).

A hoard of 243 Roman imperial denarii and their barbarian imitations was discovered by a treasure hunter in late 2017 or early 2018 in the Sumy region. On January, 11, 2018, information and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the coins were allegedly found in his vegetable garden (a common formula of Ukrainians treasure hunters to conceal information about the place of discovery). Photos of the coins have not been preserved. Forum experts have identified the coins as “standard”, singling out only separate coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (incl. for Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius (for Faustina II and for Lucilla) and Didius Julianus. In January 2018, the coins were sold in several lots at the Violity auction.

100 denarii found in June 2008 (Oswestry Area I), followed by a further 23 denarii found in September 2008 (Oswestry Area II), both up to Marcus Aurelius. These were regarded as two separate groups, even if the date range is similar.
c. 20 denarii: Vitellius - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Hoard of around 1,600 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 573 coins were documented: Titus - Septimius Severus Severus (AD 193-211).

A hoard of at least 385 Roman imperial denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was allegedly discovered in the late 2010s in the vicinity of Ivano-Frankivsk. The hoard contained mostly coins of "early mintages", and the latest ones date back to the time of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius (10-15 such coins in total). No further information.
The hoard comprised 117 sestertii and 43 dupondii or asses from Vespasian to Commodus with a tpq of AD 190. It was found under the sixth step of a staircase discovered under a lime kiln.
The hoard comprised 41 denarii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus.
64 denarii from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Originally were 108 denarii. Nowadays, 80 coins: Otho - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 215.80 g. (80 coins). Found in a domestic building with bones fragments and an oval whetstone.
2 silver coins: Titus for Divus Vespasianus, Hadrian.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing more than 200 coins. 13 were shown to the local archaeological society: 6 were 'frustes', 6 of the Antonine family (including Faustina I and II) and one depicted a wolf. Bizeul states that they were all coins of the High Empire. Sanquer suggested that the coin depicting a wolf was a fourth century nummus, but reverse types of the Antonine period also depict the wolf. The three coins of Antoninus Pius and 2 of Faustina given to the museum by Gauja 'found in Rezé in 1851' are likely to come from this hoard. The hoard was found during the building of the east-west road through the city.

A group of 19 Roman silver coins (of the Emperors Nero, Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus, and the Empress Faustina), found while ploughing at Pitcullo in Fife, presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland in 1781. The 19 coins have not been located in NMAS, Edinburgh
4 coins: 1 denarius, 3 sestertii: Vespasian, Hadrian Marcus Aurelius (2)

72 aurei ranging from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (with Diva Faustina I and M. Aurelius Caesar) found in the vicus of Lousonna within a house. The coins had been divided in two concealments of each 35 coins, hidden in the floor. Two further coins were found nearby.
10 coins found in the bottom of a bowl in locus 29.
Seven aurei: Vespasian - Hadrian. No further information.
10 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Hadrian 3, Antoninus Pius 4, Faustina I 2, Lucilla 1.
A hoard of four aurei: Nero, Trajan 2, Antoninus Pius for Faustina I (Diva).
disposition: Madras Museum, Chennai except for Trajan coins

summary: Originally 3 denarii (Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, imitation) found within an Iron Age settlement together iron, earthenware, bone artefacts.
3,561 coins of Lucius Verus.
The hoard comprised 36 coins including 33 sestertii (1 subferratus) and 3 dupondii terminating with issues of AD 191-192. All coins are worn, so this is most probably a 3rd c. deposition.

A hoard of at least 24 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) and possibly a silver fibula were allegedly discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s nearby village Semaki in Vinnytsia region. The coins were found in an area of 15x15 m. The silver brooch was found on the same area. Based on a photo of five coins, three of which were denarii from the time of Titus, Antoninus Pius and Commodus, one cast copy of a denarius with a portrait of Hadrian and an anonymous quadrans with a portrait of Mars on the obverse and cuirass on the reverse. While the denarii have general preservation and similar bronze oxides, the cast copy of the denarius and the anonymous quadrans are probably not part of the hoard. The further fate of the coins is unknown to me.
181 denarii found in the foundations of a prehistoric house: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver weight: 491.23 g. Found together with sherds and animal bones.
Four denarii (Vespasian - Trajan), allegedly found in 1845 in or around Minden. It is not impossible that these belonged to the Minden I find, made in 1844.
4 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Diva Faustina I, Lucius Verus (AD 163-165).

After the war in a building excavation pit, 30 Roman denarii (Galba to Lucilla) were found in an amber-glazed jar from the sixteenth century, wrapped individually in a linen cloth. It is likely that a Roman hoard was unearthed in the Renaissance, and has now been found for the second time.

Four denarii, pressumably belonging to a hoard, found at the same place at different dates. ”The scientific literature has falsely perpetuated the locality of Mircești (situated 5 km to the west) as the place of origin for the coins.”
48 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) (AD 138-161).
disposition: History and Art Museum, Bacău, Romania

summary: Hoard of 314 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 85 sestertii, the majority of which were rendered illegible by oxidation. However, those that could be identified range from issues of Hadrian to Commodus.
35 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162).

Galba to Severus. The number of coins in the hoard is estimated and falls somewhere between 1200 and 1500 denarii and 1 drachm of Amisus for Hadrian. Found with a ceramic vessel and few silver ingots.
disposition: Odessa Archaeological Museum (64 denarii; 1 drachm of Amisus)

summary: The hoard comprised 4 copper-alloy statues and 2 copper-alloy vessels. One of the copper-alloy vessels contained 6 bronze coins of Marcus Aurelius and Divus Lucius Verus. One coin was lost.
A hoard of 20 denarii (Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius), found in a Roman house, in a room next to the furnace of the hypocaust.
A bronze jug containing 160 aurei, found on site 29 in Corbridge. Two bronze coins were found filling the narrow neck of the jug, where they had been placed, to act as a stopper to the narrow neck.
The hoard comprised a 'vessel containing 60 aurei, of which 17 were bought by the Cabinet des Médailles and 2 by the Musée de Rouen, although neither acquisition can be found today.'
4 silver denarii: Hadrian (Sabina), Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2562

summary: 31 denarii found in a silo at the site of the Cherniakyv Culture: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found two silver loops.
disposition: Institute of Archaeology of the Academy of Sciences, Kyiv, Ukraine (11 coins, 1 loop); School museum, Davydovka, Ukraine

summary: Hoard of 700 silver coins. 578 pieces were recovered: 577 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero - Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Pokrajinski muzej, Celje, Slovenia (578 coins); dispersed

summary: 3 denarii: Titus, Antoninus Pius, Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 148-149); silver weight: 7.90 g.
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. According to some incriptions the issuers were Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius (ANTONINVS PIVS, ANTONINVS ARMENIACVS). Six or eight denarii were noticed.

3,997 bronze coins recovered from a shipwreck on the bottom of the Garonne river. The coins were recovered in two stages: 939 in 1965, 3,058 in 1970. In total: 3,663 sestertii, 270 dupondii, 33 asses, 31 dupondii/asses: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (159-161).

The hoard comprised 60 silver coins from the reigns of Nero to Hadrian, deposited during the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-136). These coins were: 42 denarii (Vespasian to Hadrian), 10 tetradrachms and 1 tridrachm from Antioch (Nero to Trajan), 6 tridrachms and 1 drachm of Trajan from Arabia.

Five denarii found at different dates, between 2005 and 007, on the same field using metal detectors: Vespasian, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Augustus) (AD 171-172).
disposition: Private collection (4 coins); National Museum of archaeology, Warszaw, Poland (1 coin)

summary: Unknown initial number of denarii. Sixty-three coins were seen in the collection of the Friends of sciences Society Collection in Poznań: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Friends of sciences Society Collection, Poznań, Poland (63 coins)

summary: A hoard of 20 denarii (Antoninus Pius - Commodus, but no details known for 12 coins) was found between 1880 and 1890 in a glass bowl, between the city and the railroad, directly southeast of the confluence of the Horst- and Totengraben.
16 aurei: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 107-110).
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 9 coins were documented: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190). One nummus of Constantine I can be considered as an intruder.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Warsaw, Poland (donation R. Turkievich, 1936 )

summary: 92 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver bracelet.
Five denarii found during survey in small area. Interpreted as small disturbed hoard.
15 coins of unknown denomination and issuer. According to NUMIS the tpq is around AD 180.
The hoard comprised 301 Alexandrian tetradrachms. 300 were of Nero with a single coin of Hadrian. They were acquired in Egypt by Dattari.

Found in the garden of one of the villagers. Consisted of denarii (quantity unknown), which were in a pot. The coins were taken by villagers. V. Lyaskoronsky in 1926 saw only two denarii from this hoard (Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius). In 1964, L. Pobal examined the probable place of the find, but did not find additional information about the hoard.

The hoard comprised 4 sestertii ranging from Trajan to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1957) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. Only 2 coins preserved, but descriptions of all of them exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (2 coins); lost (2 coins)

summary: A hoard of ca. 460 Roman silver denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius for 344 of them, the others are lost), found in an earthenware container 1 1/2 feet under the soil while removing stones ('Steineroden') in the heather, at Wassermühle on the Wingstberg.

A cultic area with two temples was excavated southwest of the intersection of Groß-Umstädter straße/Aschaffenburger straße. One of the two temples had a quadratic cella, corresponding to the Gallo-Roman type. A small hoard of 5 bronze coins (Trajan to Antoninus Pius) and a complete set of cultic vessels was found in its immediate vicinity.
Originally, 222 coins. 133 denarii are documented: Nero - Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Iron Gates Museum, Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania (122 coins); inv.no. 562-683; private collection, Bucharest, Romania. (11 coins)

summary: 35 sestertii, 707.80 g, found on a field ranging from Vespasian/Titus to Commodus (AD 186).

83 bronze coins and (silver coins?) found in a marble rock. There is some information on 28 coins: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). The three denarii may not belong to this hoard (Dembski 1977).
disposition: Museum Carolino Augusteum, Salzburg, Austria (26 coins); Prähistorischen Staatssammlung, München, Germany (3 coins?)

summary: Unknown number of silver coins. One denarius of Trajan and one of Hadrian are kept in the museum in Ruse.
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 9, 553

summary: 41 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
130 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190-191); silver weight: 360.44 g. Together with the coins were found two bronze rings.

A hoard of at least 259 Roman imperial denarii was found by treasure hunters in 2016 in Cherkasy region. On October 4, 2016, a video of the process of sondage at the site where the hoard was found by seven treasure hunters was published on YouTube, on the “Sokrovische nacii” (“Treasure of the Nation”) channel. A few days earlier, another group of treasure hunters found a batch of denarii - 192 specimens - on the surface (up to 15 cm deep in an area of about 10x10 m) of a ploughed field. Then, on October 4, on this place was made several sondages (approx. 2-3x1 m), in which, at a depth of 40-50 cm was found another 67 coins (each of the seven treasure hunters took as many coins as they found). According to the assumption of one of the treasure hunters there may be more coins at this place. The video footage shows coins with traces of patina, among which can be distinguished denarii of Hadrian (incl. for Sabina), Antoninus Pius (incl. for Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius (incl. for Faustina II), Commodus. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
102 sestertii, 5 dupondii and 1 as ranging from Domitian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 179-180). Hoard was originally larger.

54 Republican and imperial denarii issued by M. Fonteius, L. Marcius Censorinus, C. Naevius Balbus, M. Cordius, L. Plautius, A. PLautius, P. Clodius Turrinus, L. Thorius Balbus, Sextus Pompeius, Julius Caesar, Mark Antony's legionary denarii (III, VI, VIIII, XII, XIX, XII) des denarii of Sex. Pompey (with reverses of Amphinomos and Anapias), Julius Caesar and emperors to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard comprised 1 dupondius and 5 asses terminating with issues of the period AD 178-183. The coins were found together, but without trace of a container.
The hoard comprised 83 silver coins from the Second Jewish Revolt dated between AD 132-135/6.
It comprised c. 500 denarii found with a vessel:Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised 25 coins (23 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 1 Provincial bronze of Trajan of the Koinon of Cyprus), ranging from Titus to Antoninus Pius.
36 denarii found in the military amphitheater: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
disposition: Museum Carnuntinum, Bad-Deutsch Altenburg, Austria (29 coins); 7 coins lost

summary: From 465 only 60 denari are known: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138). Found in a ceramic vessel.
Mr. I.L. Faingold may have inherited a hoard of 100 denarii from his father. 44 coins were documented: Galba - Commodus (AD 190).
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (44 coins until 1917)

summary: In 1884 a large hoard of Roman bronze coins was found in the area of Mindelzell. 30 specimens arrived in a private collection in Memmingen, of which 12 were later bought by the Memmingen museum. They are now lost.
15 sestertii of which Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina II 1, Commodus 1 were found by fishermen in a dune.
Around 300 denarii possible found with a leather bag. 134 coins provide information on the issuers: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Krakow (132 coins); private collection, Gnojni (2 coins)

summary: 2 aurei of Domitian and Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus).
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 29 denarii were documented: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-19922).
85 denarii: Nerva - Didius Julianus (AD 193).
Hoard of at least 62 denarii. Only 13 are known: 8 republican among which Julius Caesar 1, Augustus 3, Hadrian 2.
The hoard comprised 118 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Domitian-Commodus (90-183 AD). Most of the coins are kept in a private collection (Antonio Egger).
disposition: Museo Civico di Bassano (26 coins); Museo Bottacin di Padova (6 coins); private collection Egger family (86 coins).

summary: The hoard comprised 65 bronze coins dated between 294-283 BC and AD 117-138.
