A hoard of 86 Roman imperial denarii (from Vespasian to Commodus) was discovered by a treasure hunter in 2015 or 2016. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on 10 February 2016 on the treasure hunter forum Violity, but without specifying the exact location of the find. However, on May 25, 2017 on the YouTube channel “Poisk klada Alexander & Co” there was information about the location of the find, as well as photos of the coins previously published on Violity. There is no information about the conditions of the hoard discovery. The coins are of average preservation. In February 2016, the hoard was sold in one lot at Violity auction, the further fate of the coins is unknown.
Unknown originally number of coins, around 160-200 denarii. Only 90 were documented: Otho - Clodius Albinus (AD 195-197).
Hoard of unknown number of bronze coins. 1 coin of Antoninus Pius and 1 of Faustina I (Augusta/Diva) were seen.

The hoard was found in a niche in a wall structure and comprised an 'important assemblage of gold and silver Roman coins which were dispersed amongst the workmen. It appears that there were more than 2,000 coins, mostly silver issues dating up to the reign of Septimius Severus. There were two aurei of Commodus mounted in jewellery. Comarmond notes two aurei of Nero and a gold quinarius of Commodus. Issues of Septimius Severus and Julia Domna were numerous and well-preserved, but there were no coins of Caracalla or Geta. There were also numerous items of gold jewellery, weighing a total of 741g, which the brother supervising the works managed to collect together. The jewellery was the subject of a detailed publication by Comarmond. The hoard was found by workmen digging foundation trenches for a new boarding school run by the Christian Brothers.
Unknown number of initial coins. 20 pieces - unknown metal - are kept in the Coin Room of the Institute of Archaeology in Bucharest: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (Ad 138-161).
disposition: Coin Room of the Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 83 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
26 sestertii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 195).
32 coins: 1 republican denarius, 31 bronze coins: Augustus - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198).
A hoard of 300 Roman denarii ranging from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 74). Only 19 coins have been recorded. Based on the portrait style, the coins seem to be imitations of known genuine types.
disposition: Private collection A.A. Tarpi, Dushambe, Tajikistan

summary: Hoard discovered on the surface and during the archaeological investigations: Trajan – Septimius Severus (Clodius Albinus Caesar) (AD 193).
disposition: History Museum, Târgu Neamț (23 coins); History Museum, Piatra Neamț (7 coins); private collections (6 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 42 denarii: Otho - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 78.0-122.8 g.
62 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 127-128)
Around 500 denarii. Only three are known from Domitian and Trajan.
disposition: Muzeum Archeologiczne i Etnograficzne w Łodzi, Poland (3 coins)

summary: 50 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Group of 3 coins: Domitian denarius, Trajan denarius, Hadrian sestertius (AD 117-138).
55 bronze coins with unknown findspot except for the mention north Portugal
645 Alexandrian tetradrachms: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167) purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".
Two denarii found on a field by chance: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius for Antoninus Pius (Divus).

The hoard comprised 1 denarius (Diva Faustina I) and 8-9 aes coins ranging fro Hadrian to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 1/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. Only 5 coins are preserved today, but descriptions of the other ones exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (5 coins); lost (4-5 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of aurei. Forty-five coins from Nero to Trajan were recovered. Seventeen coins were studied in detail. Nine coins were acquired in 1937 by the mayor of Villeurbanne.
72 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Didius Julianus (AD 193).
79 coins: 6 denarii, 45 sestertii, 16 dupondii, 12 asses found with shreds from the ceramic vessel: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised 831 bronze coins from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Three aurei found at the bottom of "an old wall": Faustina I, Faustina II under Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar). The hoard was found by a farmer.

97 coins: 1 denarius and 96 bronzes found concentrated around an earthenware dish within a level of a building: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167). The coins were found together with a brooch, as well as several pieces of pottery and nails.
(?) 3 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174-175).
The hoard comprised a burned pottery vessel containing 6 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus.
Grave find of 5 denarii (1 plated) Vespasian to Hadrian (AD 134-138)
In 1867 west of Gräpel on the right bank of the Oste river coins were found 2 ft deep during the removal of sand from a ridge of hills. The find totals ca. 350+ denarii (Augustus? - Commodus).
49 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 141-161).
The hoard comprised a large number of Roman coins which were shared out between the finders. Fournier compiled a list, suggesting that 39 were of Nerva (and Trajan?) and 42 of Hadrian.
23 denarii: Republic (L. Thorius Balbus) - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

A hoard of 291 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian – Commodus (AD 180-192) and their imitations was found by two treasure hunters in early June 2016 in the Kyiv region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published by one of the finders on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity on June 21, 2016. The finder reported that the coins were collected from an area of 3 square meters. The first coins were found at a depth of 10-20 cm, although the pit for their search was dug about 1 m deep. Some coins have traces of bronze oxides. In general, the preservation of coins is good (weak wear). In August 2016, the entire hoard was sold at a Violity auction. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
Hoard of 49 coins and jewelry was found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Jewelry: bronze loop, bronze buckle, silver buckle, 7 silver rings, 39 pearls of amber, coral, glass.
disposition: Local history museum Cherkasy, Ukraine (inv.no. 190092 - vanished in 1941-1945)

summary: Around 200 denarii. The person who ppresented 46 denarii mentioned that in total may have found around 200 pieces. Only 28 coins could be described. One denarius of Antoninus Pius was found in 2010: Vitellius - Clodius Albinus (AD 194-197).
63 denarii found within the ruins of a Roman house: Galba - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161). The silver link found with the coins may suggest a bag as the container.
Around 400 denarii found with a clay pot. 338 coins are known: Nero - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
disposition: National Archaeological Museum, Warsaw (294 coins), Museum Sandomierz (8 coins), Museum Ostrowiec Świętokrzyski (12 coins), Poland

summary: Two aurei, Domitian (Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) found in sequential years, in the same forest. Close chronological range.

In 1931, 14 bronze coins (Domitian to Antoninus Pius) were found on the surface in front of the southern gate of the Roman fort, which were oxidised together in a clump. Some specimens show exposure to fire.
Circa 150 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 5 sestertii are known: Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina I (Diva) 1, 2 uncertain issuer.
The hoard comprised 8 bronze coins of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136) found with traces of a leather bag.
40 denarii: Titus - Pertinax (AD 193).
The hoard comprised 16 coins with the denominations not given. The hoard was found on the Barre farm, while making repairs to the farmyard.
(50-60) 13 bronze coins: 12 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 153-155).
disposition: Collection J. De Bast (13 coins), in 1808

summary: Unknwon number of denarii found with an iron vessel. Only 14 denarii were identified: Nero - Septimius Severus (Caracalla Caesar) (AD 196-198).

1,022 denarii: Republic – Commodus (AD 180-192). The first lot of coins was found in 1943, the second one it was pretended to have been discovered in 1970 at the same place and by the same person. In fact there was just one hoard.
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (537 coins)

summary: 180 coins ending with issues of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Trajan was the other issuer recognized among the coins of this hoard.
The hoard comprised 9 silver coins and 1 bronze coin dated to the second century AD.

A number (possibly 150) of Roman silver coins (possibly Nero - Antoninus Pius / Marcus Aurelius), found in the vicinity of the Herren-Holz, a quarter of an hour north of Spahn, lying on a mound of earth.

Four bronze coins (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius), found on the Dowe-See estate on the Bullenteich in Braunschweig, next to other small Roman objects (bronze fibula, bronze ring, glass pearls, spindle whorl, etc.).
(700) 612 silver coins: 610 denarii, 2 drachmas: Nero-Commodus (AD 184-185).
The hoard comprised more than 400 worn coins including issues of Nero, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and Crispina.
(c. 600) 300 silver coins: 299 denarii, 1 drachm: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180-183).

find_spot_name: VILLA DE LA FUENTE DE LAS PULGUINAS
summary: Five bronze coins found one next to the other: as Republic, 3 asses Hadrian, 1 dupondius Antoninus Pius.

The hoard comprised numerous copper-alloy vessels, a mirror, a folding seat, Samian ware cups and plates and six glass bottles, one of which contained 40 very worn sestertii and dupondii of Nerva, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina II.
15 denarii: Vespasian/Titus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Hoard of at least 46 denarii: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192). Possible, part of the hoard from Strunga.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (25 coins)

summary: In 1937 a small hoard of 9 sestertii (Trajan - Commodus) was found in the north of Faimingen in the foundation walls of a Roman building, between the Roman road and the contemporary road.
73 bronze coins: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Two denarii found together: Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius.
53 denarii: Galba - Antoninus Pius (AD 156-157).
disposition: Zemaljski muzej Bosne i Hercegovine (National Museum of Bosnia and Herzegovina) Sarajevo (32 coins) - 1981

summary: Penhallurick (2009, 245 no. 251) records a metal detector find of 9 sestertii found in an area of about 50 square metres in the same field. Considered to be part of a scattered hoard.

A hoard of denarii, found in an earthenware container, together with three silver bracelets, during the construction of the road from Kindelbrück to Weißensee, under an area of arable land. The content of the hoard was dispersed, but it could have amounted to more than 230 denarii.
A large hoard of denarii and a few bronze coins was found during construction works in 1957. Only 139 coins (Vespasian-Marcus Aurelius, 70-180 AD) were recovered but subsequently stolen in 1972-1973.
41 Alexandrian bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 164-165). Found during excavations .
disposition: Exhibited in London 1902, now in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: The hoard comprised 100 Roman coins, including one of Antoninus Pius.
5 coins found scattered near a disturbed grave within a cremation necropolis: Hadrian 1 as, Antoninus Pius 4 sestertii (AD 152-153).
7 denarii: Vespasian 3, Nerva 1, Trajan 1, Marcus aurelius 2 (AD 166-167).
The hoard comprised an unknow number of aurei, at least 12(?), from Vespasian to Hadrian (AD 136).

The hoard comprised 50 Roman coins which were thought to be bronzes. There is no further information on denominational composition. It was found on communal heathland and pasture, at a very shallow depth. The majority of the coins were collected together by M. Auvray, mayor of Aclou.
Hoard of 300-400 denarii. Only two coins are documented: Trajan, Antoninus Pius.
Unknown initial number of coins: 28 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166); silver weight: 54.2-84.4g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.no. M I 233-250

summary: The hoard comprised 11 bronze coins dated between 175-164 BC and AD 117-138.

The deposit was found under a second century occupation layer in the central part of the Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary and comprised 4 sestertii from Trajan to Antoninus Pius and two asses of Antoninus Pius with a tpq of AD 153 to 154.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 10 coins were seen: Vespasian 2, Trajan 4, Antoninus Pius 1, Marcus Aurelius 3. Possible, part of the same hoard with Strunga II and III.
500 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166). TR POT XX IMP IIII COS III
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; circa 250 coins, inv.no. 853 1-128

summary: 18 bronze coins: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius
Hoard containing, among others, an aureus of Antoninus Pius for Faustina I (Diva) and an imitation of Tiberius aureus.

Originally 17 denarii, 16 preserved: Trajan - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver weight: 44.65 g. (16 coins). Together were also found: 1 gold bracteate, 1 gold finger ring, 2 neck-rings of bronze with silver mountings, 2 somewhat smaller bronze rings, 1 bronze clasp, 1 bronze strap-end, several bronze spirals, 1 amber bead, 2 coral beads.
76 denarii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
disposition: Collection Baron of Senzeilles (76 coins), in 1890

summary: The hoard comprised 2 batches containing 24 bronzes from Trajan to Antoninus Pius for the first and 300 bronzes for the second.
Hoard of 21 sestertii. Among them coins of Domitian, Nerva, Hadrianus and Antoninus Pius (AD 138).
14 denarii found with ceramic vessel of which only 5 are known today: Trajan 2, Hadrian 1, Hadrian (Antoninus Pius Caesar) 1, Antoninus Pius 1 (AD 140-143).
Hoard of 50 denarii. Only 8 pieces are documented: Antoninus Pius 3, Marcus Aurelius (Antoninus Pius Divus), Commodus 4.
disposition: National Museum of History, Moscow, Russia (inv.nos. 14863, 14865-14869)

summary: 8 coins: 7 denarii, 1 sestertius found in a destruction layer caused by fire: Vitellius - Antoninus Pius (AD 159-160).
"1 litra" of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 2 denarii are known: Domitian, Trajan.
disposition: National Archaeological Museum, Warszaw (2 coins), Poland

summary: (c. 220) 151 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver weight: c. 367.1-588.9 g.

The hoard comprised 7 aurei terminating in an issue of Trajan dating to AD 106. From 1826 to 1908, 7 Roman aurei were found by chance in the fields, all in the same region (Salzbrunnen and Z'underst Wyler), at a maximum distance of ca. 150 meters. These could be single finds or rather a dispersed hoard? Found in 1826: Nerva; 1859: Nero; 1894: Vespasian; 1896: Trajan; 1899: Nerva; 1907: Galba; 1908: Trajan.
disposition: Kantonsarchäologie Schaffhausen (4 coins); Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (2 coins); Bernisches Historisches Museum (1 coin)

summary: A hoard of 5+ Roman provincial coins (Thessalonica: 1; Amphipolis: 4, Marcus Aurelius and Commodus), found in a grave in Amphipolis (Grave 1) in 1953. Archives in the Ephorate mention 18 further coins, but these could not be traced any more.
Unknown originally number of coins. 18 denarii are kept at the Institute of Archaeology ”A.D. Xenopol” Iași, Romania: Vespasian – Hadrian (AD 134-138).
disposition: Institute of Archaeology ”A.D. Xenopol” Iași, Romania (inv.nos. 2042-2059).

summary: (50) 25 denarii: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found together with a silver bracelet.
Three denarii found in a funerary urn together with an amber bead and a wire link ring: Domitian, Hadrian Marcus Aurelius (Divus) (AD 180).
13 coins (10 provincial coins of Philippi, 2 denarii of Trajan and 1 imperial bronze of Domitian) found in grave T45 in the eastern cemetery of Philippi.
36 sestertii, but only 16 are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-183).
14 Alexandrian coins: 13 tetradrachms, 1 drachm: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935)

summary: A hoard of 47 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius), found in a megalithic grave in an urn also containing ashes. The grave was located 20 m away from the mansion of Fickmühlen.
A hoard of Roman aurei and their imitations was discovered in an earthen pot: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161).
The hoard comprised 'a vessel containing 100 sestertii': Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
A hoard of 48 denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Commodus, discovered in the fortress of Gaṙni in 1955.
8 Roman bronze coins to Antoninus Pius plus 8 Durotrigan cast bronze coins
Circa 150 bronze coins. Only 2 sestertii and 2 dupondii of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius were seen.

A hoard of 138 Roman imperial denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 180-161) was discovered by a treasure hunter in 2017 in the Kyiv region. The first information about the hoard and photos of 60 coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity on January 6, 2017. Then the treasure hunter went to the hoard findspot nine more times and found a different number of coins: 24 January (2 coins), 25 January (7 coins), 24 February (8 coins), 15 May (1 coin), 12 June (1 coin), 3 August (1 coin), 4 August (19 coins), 14 August (38 coins) and 20 August (1 coin). According to the finder, the deposit was found in the forest, under the trees. In the photograph on forum a small pit in the sandy soil (up to 50 cm deep) located on a slight slope can be seen. A few coins were closer to the surface, the main butch was deeper. The hoard was in a reddish-colored pottery vessel, of which several fragments have survived (according to the finder it was a “pot”, but judging by the photographs it was a pottery bowl). The coins are in very good condition (minimal wear). The coins were sold one by one at the Violity auction.
Hoard of 320 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nerva - Pertinax (AD 193).

18 Cappadocian silver coins (didrachms, drachms and hemidrachms), sold to the museum of Zugdid by a farmer in the 1930s. The coins range from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161), with 10 specimens being illegible. The coins were examined by Zograf in 1937.
The hoard comprised approximately 15-20 tetradrachms and 70-80 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

A hoard of at least 595 denarii, ranging from Nerva to Crispina, found in the middle of the 19th century in the fortress of Krani in Cephalonia. The coins were given to the Numismatic Museum by the Phocas-Kosmetatos family (in 1970 and 1972).
14 coins ranging from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius (1 denarius of Trajan; 11 provincial coins: Dium, Koinon of Macedonia, Stobi; 2 uncertain), found in grave 5 in Sevasti.
The hoard comprised between 150 and 175 bronze coins 'mostly of the Early Empire'. One coin bears the effigy of Faustina II

The hoard (5 bronze coins ranging from Domitian to Faustina I) was found in 1964 northwest of the Jewish cemetery in house pit 27-29 of Ernst-Kahn-straße, in a depth of 30 cm. The coins lay in a varnished pot. The hoard remain in private possession.
A hoard of 10 aurei (Domitian - Antoninus Pius), found in the 1880s in Trier, in a small earthenware container; it was published in 1928 as part of the collection of Dr. Leopold Seligmann.

Approx. 200 Roman silver coins found by chance as a waggon had crushed the jar that contained them. One of the accounts relating to this find gives a list of emperors: Nero, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, the two Antonines, Faustina and L. Aelius Verus.
Unknown original number of coins. 36 denarii were recovered: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).

100 denarii found in June 2008 (Oswestry Area I), followed by a further 23 denarii found in September 2008 (Oswestry Area II), both up to Marcus Aurelius. These were regarded as two separate groups, even if the date range is similar.
The hoard was discovered after 1863 in the rubble from the excavation of the bathhouse. It comprises 21 aurei, ranging from Nero to Trajan.
Hoard of more than 200 denarii. Only 10 were documented: Hadrian (Aelius Caesar) - Pertinax (AD 193).

A hoard of 200-300 mainly gold coins (Claudius - Hadrian), found while digging peat in Gustorf in 1838/1839. Several finders are reported. Some coins were bought by the Berlin Münzkabinett (16 gold, 2 silver and 3 bronze coins).
Hoard of few kilos of denarii. Only 6 coins are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius 4, Lucilla.

HER record of a hoard of 32 Roman copper coins, "chiefly of the Middle Empire" found in 1772 at North End in Turville. Eight of the coins were said in 1797 to be in the possession of Col Innes of Ibstone House, of which there were 2 of Antoninus Pius, 2 "Faustinas", 2 "Vespasians", 1 Trajan and 1 "Aurelius". Source: Thomas Langley 1797 "History and Antiquities of the Hundred of Desborough" p.383.
514 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
17 bronze coins: 3 dupondii, 15 asses: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Six aurei found in grave of Asfagur: Titus, Trajan, Hadrian 4 (AD 117-138).
Large hoard of silver coins. Only 7 denarii are kept in the museum of Pleven: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1452 1-7

summary: Hoard of 34 bronze sstaters of an autonomous (Agrippia) city and Bosporan kings: Aspurgus, Gepaepyris, Rhescuporis II, Sauromates I, Cotys II, Sauromates II and one issue of the mint of Agrippia Caesarea (Phanagoria).
disposition: Museum of Anapa, Russia (labelled as the "Gunyaevsky Hoard"; inv.nos. AM 10750/1-34)

summary: Seven sestertii found sealing a child burial in one of the house of C. Iulius Silvanus: Domnitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 151-152).
31 denarii found in a ceramic vessel inside a mound: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
27 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

The hoard comprised 13 denarii from Mark Antony to Septimius Severus. They were found concealed in the belt of male burial interpreted as being that of a Roman soldier. The burial was found in the courtyard of a building situated at No. 12 rue des Fantasques
343 bronze coins: 337 sestertii, 6 dupondii: Galba - Septimius Severus (AD 193-196). Weight:8205.03 g.
disposition: Saint-Remi History Museum, Reims, France; inv. nos. B-C

summary: Two sestertii found together and recorded as a hoard in the HER. The coins could not be closely identified and were returned to the finder as they did not meet the criteria for Treasure.
40 bronze coins were discovered with a ceramic vessel. Only 24 have provided some information: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
A hoard of 18 denarii (Otho-Commodus) found during excavations at Dura Europos, in E4-15.
(260) 257 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Six coins of Alexandria: Nero 1, Vespasian 2, Hadrian 2, Lucius Verus 1. No information about site or circumstances.
Unknown original number of sestertii: Titus - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Town museum, Kaliningrad, Russia (inv.no. КГОМ 1.18842/1-119); Archive Rudau (in 1911) (inv.no. Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-150_2, Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-148_1, Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-150_1)

summary: Over 100 silver and bronze coins. 80 pieces were recovered: 1 denarius, 67 sestertii, 12 dupondii, 1 As: Vespasianus - Hadrian (AD 134-138).

A clump of at least 14 denarii molten together. The only reasonably identifiable coin is one of Antoninus Pius for Diva Faustina I, minted between 141 and 161 AD. Another denarius was likely issued under the authority of Marcus Aurelius.

The hoard comprised 2,077 bronze coins along with bronze implements and scrap from a bronze foundry. Mostly quandrantes and semisses but also including Greek provincial, Greek, Republican up to 5th century AD
disposition: Heberden Coin Room, AShmolean Museum, Oxford, Great Britain

summary: 29 denarii: Otho - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: Museum of Cultural History Stralsund, Germany (26 coins); Museum Szeczin, Poland (3 coins)

summary: 6 denarii, probably, part of a larger hoard: Antoninus Pius 3, Faustina I (Diva) 1, Antoninus Pius (Divus) 2
A small hoard of dupondii and asses was found during the excavation of Tomb 68 in excavations of the site: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Unknown number of bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus/Pertinax (AD 193).
Circa 300 denarii found with a ceramic vessel while metal detecting. At the moment, 17 pieces are available for description: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 151-160).
(circa 400) 22 denarii: 2 republican, 20 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 105-107)
Unknown originally number of coins. Circa 200 sestertii were seen From Flavians to Septimius Severus (AD 197). Only 29 were available for study.
15 aurei and 470 denarii, ranging from the Republican period to Marcus Aurelius, found by a labourer at work in Rudchester grounds, while digging up the foundation of an old fence in 1766.

320 D: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180): Discovered in an onion field after it had been ploughed. The finder carefully collected the coins together, but discarded fragments of the pottery container. Found whilst harvesting onions in a field in the north-western part of the village, next to the road leading to Gruia.

Funerary deposit of 5 denarii in a Late Roman grave: Trajan - Commodus (AD 192). In the same grave were found: a bronze brooch, an iron brooch, an iron bracket, one thorn, an iron firesteel and two knives.
Hoard of 1000 denarii of the Antonines and 6 aurei of Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina II.
The hoard comprised 14 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus and was found placed next to two greyware ceramic vessels.
(32) 2 denarii: Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
12 denarii found with a small ceramic vessel: Titus - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144).
Around 100 denarii, 27 were studied: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-175).
317 silver coins: 313 denarii, (2 copies and 2 Lycian drachms) with a ceramic vessel, ten meters from BIRNIE 2001: Nero - to Septimius Severus (AD 195-196).
Around 70-80 denarii, 53 were recovered: Republic - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Five denarii found together following metal detecting: Hadrian (Sabina) - Commodus (AD 190).
11 denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius ) (AD 181).
47 denarii: Vespasian - Didius Julianus (AD 193); silver weight: 87.1-137.5 g
The hoard comprised 5 drachms of Trajan minted in Bostra (AD 113).
The coins were found together, in a burnt layer 25 cm deep under Plattenstraße at Ritona.
107 denarii found with a bronze vessel: Republic - Trajan (AD 112-114).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Lugo, Spain

summary: 27 bronze coins (Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius) found in an ash layer covered by a stone and interpreted as a votive deposit.
The hoard comprised approximately 46 tetradrachms and 200-350 denarii of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
disposition: L. Hamburger (British Museum); Montagu Collection; J. Evans; Kelsey Museum of Archaeology in Ann Arbor, Michigan; Detroit Institute of Arts

summary: 403 denarii: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167-168); bronze and gold jewelry and bronze tweezers.
Hoard of 183 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
7 sestertii: Trajan 2, Hadrian (Sabina) 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) 2, Marcus Aurelius 2 (AD 161-180).
22 asses: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) .
240 silver coins: 228 denarii, 2 drahms found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 8

summary: The hoard comprised 26 bronze coins dated between 175-164 BC and AD 113-114 with four intruding coins.
30-40 denarii. Only 15 were seen: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192). No further details.
Four aurei (Nero to Antoninus Pius) recorded at 4 different points in time, between 1996 and 2002, clearly forming a hoard. Many other metal-detected finds from site, Roman-post-medieval.
Two denarii of Commodus (AD 186); silver weight: 4.66 g.
34 coins found by Caspar Reuvens in 1828: 2 denarii, 3 sestertii, 15 asses, 6 dupondii, 6 dupondius/as, others unclear: Nerva - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Originally 5 denarii, 1 preserved: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 186). Found together with 1 gold finger ring, 3 silver finger rings.

Accidentally discovered by schoolboy Leonid Ryshchuk in 1974. The hoard was found on the territory of the Lyshchitsy peat enterprise, on the northern edge of the peat bog, near the bridge across the ditch, 250 m south of the field, south of the cemetery of the village of Ogorodniki. According to the discoverer, the total number of coins ranged from 350 to 500 pieces. Most of the coins were taken by local residents and collectors, only 48 denarii have survived from this find (transferred to the Brest Regional Local History Museum). In 1974, at the hoard find spot, L. Pobol carried out excavations, another 63 coins were discovered (transferred to the Museum of ancient Belarusian Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus). 5 coins from the hoard are in the private collection of V. Pinchuk in Minsk. A total of 116 coins are known: 115 denarii (Nero-Marcus Aurelius) and one imitation of denarius.
disposition: Brest Regional Local History Museum (48 coins); Museum of ancient Belarusian Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus (63 coins); private collection of V. Pinchuk in Minsk (5 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 31 sestertii, stacked one on top of the other, suggesting that they may have originally been packed in a tube or similar which has not survived: Nerva - Commodus (AD 189).
8 sestertii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 191-192).

Iron Age British silver and copper-alloy coins, Roman Republican silver denarii, Roman imperial denarii, Roman copper-alloy coins, totalling 465 specimens. The assemblage seems to constitute continuous votive deposition rather than a hoard.
3,728 denarii: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2599-3353 (3626 coins)

summary: Hoard of 190 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Republic (?) - Hadrian.
The hoard comprised '20 coins of which the most recent was an issue of Marcus Aurelius' The hoard was discovered by peat cutters.
Hoard of 375 denarii. Only 7 coins were mentioned: Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Faustina II 3, Lucilla, Commode.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 9 pieces were recorded: 7 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Claudius I Commodus (AD 184).
Unknown originally number of coins. 78 bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus (AD 189).
disposition: Museu da Região Flaviense, Chaves, Portugal

summary: The hoard was found during the 1988 excavation in the southern part of the Roman vicus. The coins (26 denarii, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius) were corroded together in a clump.
Hoard of 500 coins of the Bosporan kings: Ininthimeus, Rhescuporis IV and V.
8 denarii, ranging from Vitellius to Marcus Aurelius, found on the north bank of the Tay at Inchyra, east of Perth.
Over 600 bronze coins found with ceramic vessel. Only 11 pieces are recorded: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 163-164).
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueología e Etnología, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: The hoard comprised 9 figurines, 1 patera and 7 bronze coins from Vespasian to Commodus.
A group of 27 coins, together with a further silver coin fragment. Addenda of 3.
The hoard comprised 86 sestertii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus, although the author proposes a deposition date in the reign of Postumus.
180 sestertii, for 109 the issuers are known: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Kärntner Landsmannschaft, Klagenfurt (95 coins); 5 in Prfratbesitz; Museum St. Veit an der Glan (12 coins); 5 private collection, Austria

summary: Two denarii of Antoninus Pius, the first 'found on the Laleston by-pass road behind (SE. of) the Mackworth Inn', the second 'found during road widening on the Cardiff-Swansea road, near the A.A. Box west of Laleston'. One might suspect that both coins came from the same hoard, scattered by workmen somewhere near Laleston.
378 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
Originally 16 denarii, 15 preserved: Domitian - Septimius Severus(AD 193-211); silver weight: 42.63 g. (15 coins).
The hoard comprised 77 silver coins dated between 32/31 BC and AD 125-128.
A hoard of sestertii of which 4 pieces are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II and Lucilla.
Hoard of two aurei - Claudius I, Trajan - and one imitation - Nero/Antoninus Pius.
236 aurei and denarii from the time of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Around 200 denarii. Among them issues of Nero, Vitellius, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Trajan and Hadrian.
The Cheshire HER lists "A small hoard comprising a silver denarius of Faustina II (AD 176), two unidentified Roman bronze coins and a bronze dolphin-type booch datable to 1st to 2nd century AD".
The hoard comprised six bronze coins dated between AD 70-81 and AD 117/118. It was deposited inside the hollow part of a door frame in the tepidarium of a Roman bathhouse. Votive role?
Five denarii, from the reigns of Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, and Commodus, discovered in a garden in Berlin-Lichterfelde in 1919.
The hoard originally comprised an undetermined amount of denarii. Only 12 coins are known: Trajan-Marcus Aurelius (114-175 AD).

A. Marsden writes: "Roman coin hoard of 17 coins, all asses or dupondii of the first or early second century. Many of the coins are corroded and in poor condition but the four coins of Hadrian appear to have seen relatively little circulation when they went into the ground. The earlier ones appear heavily worn. We might suggest a date of loss or deposition around the middle of the second century AD.1) Claudius, as, reverse Minerva advancing right, appears regular, weight 5.93g, AD41-542) Uncertain as or dupondius, perhaps Nero, ?AD64-83) Vespasian, as, reverse probably standing figure, AD69-794-6) Uncertain Flavian, asses or dupondii, AD69-96 (3)7) Hadrian, as, reverse female standing right, AD117-258) Hadrian, as, reverse female seated left holding cornucopia, AD117-38 .9) Hadrian, as, reverse standing figure, AD117-3810) Hadrian, quadrans, reverse probably rostrum, probably RIC II, 623, AD121-211-17) Asses or dupondii, illegible (7)"

Eighteen Roman sestertii found close together by a metal detector user in the municipality of Gulpen-Wittem (in an area of ca. 1 m2). Two additional Roman coins (an as/dupondius and a coin of unknown denomination) were found within a ten-meter radius and can be part of the same hoard but certainty is lacking. The coins were reported in 2018.
47 de denarii with very poor information on the contents: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

At least 33 denarii (Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius) found in 1940 by gardeners engaged in converting a tennis court into a vegetable patch. Pye reports that the hoard was contained in a pot with a tile lid, since lost, and that one of the finders removed at least 27 of the coins, none of which were recovered. Four further reports of coins from Corton House appear in the Transactions of the Radnorshire Society over succeeding years; whether these were new discoveries at/near the same site or part of the original find is unclear. The original size of the hoard is, therefore, uncertain, and is likely to have been larger than the 33 denarii detailed here.

14 coins (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius, mostly bronzes) were found embedded in fire debris, on terrain M, Handwerkerbau (Fläche 60, Planum 0-1). N.B. Coin 1 (Vespasian) is wrongly described as a denarius in FMRD.
15 sestertii: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
6 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II (AD 161-180)
103 denarii, among which one imitation: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 181).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 350 sestertii of which 250 were too worn to identify. Hahn compiled a catalogue of 107 examples which is given here. A news article mentions a sestertius of Severus Alexander which is not included in Hahn's catalogue which may or may not be part of the hoard.
287 bronze coins: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus for Crispina (Augusta) (AD 178-183).
63 denarii found by metal detecting: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
disposition: Sold; Local museum Olevsk, Ukraine (3 coins)

summary: Six denarii found together on a floor of a Roman edifice from the Dacian kingdom capital of Sarmizegetusa Regia Republic - Trajan (AD 101-102).
disposition: Muzeul Civilizației Dacice și Romane, Deva, Romania

summary: Hoard bought by E.T. Newell in Cairo in Dec. 1923, found near Sakha. It comprised 299 coins: 33 Greek silver coins from the 2nd and 1st c. BC, 261 denarii (Nero to Trajan) and 5 provincial silver issues of Trajan (one Arabian drachm; three drachms of Cyrenaica and one hemidrachm of Cyrenaica).
A hoard of denarii found at Brixworth, in 1892. It is complete except for one denarius of Antoninus Pius of uncertain reverse. Coins range from Vespasian to Crispina.

In 1962 an excavator found a jar with 7 aurei, 1346 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), and 4 Lycian drachms (Domitian - Trajan), while building the foundations of the new building for the paper mill factory at Stockstadt.
disposition: The majority of the find was sent to Aschaffenburg Municipal Museum

summary: 257 denarii found with an amphora: Republic – Commodus (AD 191-192).
Hoard of around 2,000 denarii. 90 denarii entered the University Museum in Kyiv: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Unknown initial number of coins. 1,481 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M I 453-1933

summary: Circa 150 denarii. 100 were studied: Hadrian - Pertinax (AD 193).
28 sestertii in a ceramic vessel: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

In 1955 during ground work at a cemetery children randomly found a Roman hoard with a large quantity of coins. All coins except for the 10 described here (sestertii ranging from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius) were dispersed. The true size of the hoard is unknown.
45 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190-191); silver weight: 106.55 g. (41 coins)
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.no. 6293); Gotlands Fornsal, Visby, Finland A 1922 (inv.nos. A 2090, A 2091)

summary: The hoard was found during excavations and comprised two piles of 20 base silver coins (plated denarii?) from Augustus to Antoninus Pius or Marcus Aurelius.
53 large Roman imperial bronze coins (sestertii?): Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

Originally 5 denarii, 2 preserved: Hadrian, Hadrian (Sabina), Antoninus Pius Antoninus Pius (Faustina I), Didius Julianus (Manlia Scantilla); silver weight: 4.61 g. (2 coins). Not certain that they were found together!
2 denarii found in mound: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius/Faustina II (Diva).
(52) 49 denarii found with a ceramic vessel of Carpic manufacture: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (post AD 141).

The hoard comprised a vessel filled with sestertii, which were shared amongst the finders. After an investigation by the Gendarmarie, 59 were found. In 1980, illegal metal detecting on the site recovered a further 5 coins which are likely to be part of the hoard.
1,300 Provincial bronze coins of Alexandria: . 'Acquired in Egypt by Dattari, who sold it to Milne and Currelly.'
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto.

summary: 116 coins - 3 aurei and 113 denarii - found together during the archaeological excavations
2 denarii of Trajan and Hadrian.
Unknown number of coins found during construction work. Only five denarii are known: Republic, Vitellius, Antoninus Pius (2), Lucius Verus.
disposition: Before World War II some of the coins from the hoard were kept in the collections of the St. Elisabeth Gymnasium in Wrocław (Sankt Elisabet- Gymnasium in Breslau). Lost

summary: 23 denarii found with a money-box: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175-176)
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania

summary: Group of 2 dupondii: Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II (Diva) (AD 175-180).
(c. 260) 77 sestertii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 163-164)
The hoard comprised a small iron safe containing two aureii and a variety of jewellery.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France

summary: (ca. 900) 889 denarii: 46 republican, 843 imperial: Republic - Hadrian (AD 125-128). Found in two vessels.
disposition: Regional Museum of Russe, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1618 (889 coins)

summary: 200 aurei: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
7 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180). Two other coins, one bronze and one bronze of the 4th century were handed together to the museum.
Hoard of 37 coins: 6 republican denarii, 1 imperial denarius, 25 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 4 asses: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-161).

A hoard of 9 provincial coins from Athens (periods VB and VC) and one sestertius of Commodus. The coins were excavated in 1936 in front of the north end of the Stoa of Attalos (grid P 7). When found, several of the coins were stuck together, suggesting that all ten were originally put away in a purse.
(8) 5 sestertii: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 150-151)
Unknown original number of denarii. 32 denarii have been studied: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193).

In 2010 archaeological excavation of the northern part of Tyritake city-site (site XXVIII) a boxlike altar made of limestone tiles was found in Room I. Altar clearing uncovered two golden staters of Bosporus kings Eupator and Sauromates II, which are most likely to have been offerings to Dionysus. Sauromates II’s stater suggests dating offerings to Dionysus to AD 179 or a little later.
64 denarii found in a wall of a glass workshop: Nerva - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised 214 Alexandrian tetradrachms from Claudius I to Hadrian. They were found under a floor surface during the excavation of a Late Roman house.
Around 150 denarii and a drachm. Only 43 coins provide information on issuers: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

295 denarii and 2 sestertii (Mark Antony to Commodus) found on the latest floor level of Room 37. The coins were corroded together and no trace of a container was recovered. It is possible that 6 denarii presented to the British Museum in January 1930 by the Caerleon Excavation Committee may have come from this hoard (BM Register of Coin Accessions, Jan. 1930: Vespasian, 1; Hadrian, 3; Antoninus Pius, 1; Commodus, 1).
322 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 1 aureus, 302 denarii, 18 bronze pieces. Only 242 coins were recovered: Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
78 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Unknown initial number of coins. 183 denarii: Nero - Pescennius Niger (AD 193-194).

A Roman coin hoard consisting of 106 denarii (Republic - Commodus) was discovered in 1908 during the renovation of a grinding mill, 2 km south-west of Unterammergau. The hoard was in earthenware jar, that had apparently been placed between rocks. The coins are now lost.
6 Roman imperial bronze coins. The latest one is a sestertius of Antoninus Pius: Gaius - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

2nd century. Hoard of 8 coins recovered with a frag. of a bronze vessel, possibly its original container. The coins all exclusively 2nd C terminating with issue of Crispina (AD 177-183), though hoard may have been deposited in 3rd C AD.Rudling, D. 1982. The Romano-British farm on Bullock Down. In P. Drewett (ed.) The Archaeology of Bullock Down, Eastbourne, East Sussex.
15 sestertii found in a grave with ceramic objects: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Uncertain whether the coins were found together or single finds. Only four coins were provided with some information.
Group of 15 first and second century copper alloy coins metal-detected from the same field over a period of years between 1990 and 1998.
Unknown originally number of coins. 20 denarii are kept in the Town museum of Târgoviște: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 148-149).
Three coins of Hadrian found in a tomb (1 aureus and 2 denarii), but the information does not look trustworthy and the coins are not preserved.
A hoard of silver and bronze (perhaps also gold) coins. There is only data for two coins of Antoninius Pius.
2 denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found while ploughing.
Over 26 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology, Łódź, Poland (2 coins)

summary: Circa 350 republican and imperial denarii discovered. 79 denarii have been studied: Republic - Trajan (AD 103-111).
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Prahova, Ploiești, Romania (35 coins), inv. nos. 920730-920761; private collection (44 coins)

summary: 86 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 155-156).
Around 200 denarii of which only 8 have provided information on the issuers: Vespasian 1, Trajan 3, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 2.
25 bronze coins of which are know Augustus 1, Hadrian 1, and 1 of the two Faustinae (AD 138-180).

129 bronze coins (120 Dium, 4 koinon of Thessaly, 2 Thessalonica, 1 koinon of Macedonia, 1 Ilium and 1 uncertain), ranging from Claudius to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the west wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to two other hoards (Dion 1998 and Dion 1999). All three hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.

A hoard of 178 Roman denarii, ranging from Marc Antony to Hadrian, found at the bottom of an earthenware jar in 1934, in a field south of Louth, Lincolnshire. Among the coins, one hybrid of Domitian with a reverse of Hadrian (now in the BM).
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: Grup of two denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161); silver weight: 5.52 g.

A probable hoard of 3 sestertii and one 1 denarius (Vespasian and Hadrian) found among charcoal and other occupation refuse in Room 25. Their date range suggests a hoard, but this cannot be said for certain as their exact depositional context was not recorded.

A small hoard of 12 Roman Imperial denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early summer 2020. According to the finder the coins were found in a “small area” and represent “the contents of a purse”. The further fate of the coins is unknown: Trajan (1), Antoninus Pius (4), Marcus Aurelius (4), Commodus (1), unknown (2).
Unknown initial number of coins. 40 denarii entered Museum Collection in Opole in 1973:
disposition: Municipal Museum Opole, Poland (40 coins in 1973)

summary: Funerary find: 2 aurei in a grave: Nero, Marcus Aurelius
disposition: Musée Château d'Annecy, France; Registre des entrées, III, f. 114, nos. 3558-3559

summary: In 1908, 6 denarii (Domitian to Antoninus Pius) were found lying together at the entrance of cellar 208 (in the vicus surrounding the Roman fort).
17 denarii: Titus - Hadrian (AD 117).
25 coins? "Medium-sized hoard. Allegedly Bar Kokhba silver and bronze together with Syrian tetradrachms and Roman denarii" (Mildenberg 1984, 56).

A hoard of 32 Roman imperial denarii (from Trajan to Commodus) was found in April 2018 in Cherkassy region. Information about the hoard was published in three videos on YouTube, in the channel “Aleksander Mercedes w poiske klada”. The hoard was discovered by a group of treasure hunters on April 20, 2018 on ploughed field, at a depth of up to 15 cm. 21 coins and half of a bronze bracelet were collected from the surface of ca. 10-15 square m (the main concentration, 12 coins, in an area of 5x5 m). On April, 24 a sondage was undertaken at the findspot (ca. 3x3 m. with a depth of ca. 20-50 cm), and 6 more coins were found, including one broken into several pieces. On August 31, 2018, one of the finders found another 5 denarii at the site of the main concentration of coins. It is possible that further searches were also made at this site. The fate of the coins in the hoard is unknown. The identification of the coins was based on the photos that were posted in this video.
12 denarii (Hadrian and Antoninus Pius) found among charcoal, animal bone, and other debris inside the furnace next to Turret 1.
17 denarii and 1 aureus: Gaius - Hadrian (AD 121-123).
14 denarii found at a distance of a few hundred meters from each other on both banks of the Sonia River, the tributary of the Sona: Titus - Commodus (AD 185).
10 bronze coins found during archaeological excavations: 5 sestertii, 2 dupondii, 3 asses: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
disposition: History Museum, Svištov, Bulgaria; inv.nos OF 3583-3588; HCF, inv.no. 886-889

summary: Around 418 silver coins: 416 denarii, 2 drachms: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 164-180).
disposition: Muzeum, Koszalinie; Muzeum Zamojskie, Zamość; private collections, Poland

summary: 556 denarii found with a bronze vessel: Trajan - Septimius Sverus (AD 193). Silver weight: 1,694g.

The first 20 (?) denarii from the hoard were discovered by schoolchildren in 1968, eight of them were transferred to the Coin Room of the Belarusian State University. V. Ryabtsevich tried to establish the place where the hoard was found, but to no avail. In the first hoard's publication the village of Žukievičy was named as its location. After that, at the hoard's place, amateurs conducted further searches for it. Separate denarii were found, two of which (Trajan and Antoninus Pius) were transferred by V. Kakareka to the Coin Room of the Belarusian University. The rest of the hoard was discovered by treasure hunters in 2011 near the village of Aliekšycy: 426 denarii and 18 fragments of brooches, which were donated to the Museum of the National Bank of the Republic of Belarus. Later, 10 more coins were transferred there. In total, 446 coins are known from the hoard (Vespasian-Septimius Severus).
disposition: Coin Room of the Belarusian State University (10 coins); Museum of the National Bank of the Republic of Belarus (436 coins)

summary: 15 denarii: Galba - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

Six silver coins minted in Caesarea of Cappadocia: Nerva, Trajan 2, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius. According to Pachomov they are coming from a destroyed burial ground. a plausible hypothesis as Kropotkin (2005) mentioned other similar coins found in graves (p. 267; nos. 1927, 1928, 1944).
disposition: National Museum of History, Moscow, Russia (inv.no. 84974)

summary: Hoard consists of 70 Roman denarii (26 studied, 1 solidus): Vespasian - Didius Julianus (AD 193). Together with these coins were found: a solidus of Constantius II (Nicomedia/Cyzicus/Antioch, AD 340-355) as a pendant, two gold pendants slightly different in size, two belt buckles: one silver and one bronze, and a group of 13 silver pendants from a necklace.

Circa 30 denarii: Republic - Septimius Severus (AD 194-197). Near the denarii, a silver "pendant" was found, a piece of a brown object of unspecified utility, coins from the 15th to the 20th century and sherds of pottery (probably modern). The coins from the hoard were identified based on poor or very poor quality photos.
Hoard of 120 coins: 2 aurei, 118 denarii: Titus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museo de San Isidro, Los Orígenes de Madrid

summary: The hoard of 126 gold aurei contained within the fragmentary remains of a small pot was discovered while searching with a metal detector on land near Didcot, Oxfordshire, in April 1995. Coins range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius Caesar.
Group of 5 coins: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) as, Claudius I as, Nero 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, Hadrian sestertius (AD 117-138).
7 asses: Domitianus - Hadrianus (AD 121-122).
The hoard comprised more than a hundred copper alloy coins of Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and Commodus.
12 denari: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 114-117).
Originally, 55 denarii, 12 preserved: Trajan - Clodius Albinus (AD 193); silver weight: 32.07 g. Two silver rings were found together.

During the excavation of the native British site at Hengistbury Head, over 3000 coins were found lying on the surface and all through the soil. They had evidently been deposited in bundles. Of these over 100 were Roman, the earliest about 91 BC and the latest six coins of Antoninus Pius (138-61 AD). The rest were all British, consisting approximately of 1,300 of the Hengistbury cast type. Of the south-western struck type there were about 1,660. The remainder were various Gaulish, British and Channel Island types with a few new varieties. A coin with EISV on it was the only inscribed specimen.
disposition: British Museum (part); Ashmolean Museum (part); Fitzwilliam Museum (part); Red House Museum, Christchurch (part)

summary: Unknown number of denarii. There is information on four coins: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), Faustina I/II (AD 138-180).
4 denarii: Vitellius, Nerva, Trajan, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (AD 141-160).
(10kg?) 18 denarii: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-183).
Seven aurei found in grave no. 7: Nero 2, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius 2, Faustina II (AD 161-180).
2 denarii of Hadrian
The hoard comprised approximately 10 tetradrachms and 35 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
237 provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144). Two sacks found in a house during excavations.
The hoard comprised 185 coins, deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2013 T096. Other PAS records associated with this hoard: DEV-269707
Unknown initial number of coins. 6 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Vespasian 1, Nerva 1, Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina I 1, Marcus Aurelius 1.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2429

summary: 20 denarii, 15 studied: Trajan – Commodus (AD 189).
Grave find of 4 coins: 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, 1 dupondius, 1 as Trajan to Antoninus Pius (AD 141-161).
5 sestertii ranging from Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 173-174). Part of a larger hoard.
disposition: Narodni muzej, Ljubljana, Slovenia; 5 coins; dispersed.

summary: 200 aurei, only 6 were available for study: Galba, Trajan, Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus.

A number of coin finds were made during controlled archaeological excavation by Wessex Archaeology at the RLE sites Springhead Roman Town (RLE Event Code ARC SPH00) and Springhead Nursery (ARC SHN02) as part of the programme of archaeological works undertaken in advance of the construction of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link (now known as HS1), between 2000 and 2003.

A hoard of at least 60 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) was discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s. The hoard was found in a forest, the coins were collected from an area of 10x10 m (slightly higher was another area of 30x40 m where several coins were also found). 60 coins were collected by treasure hunters during six trips. A fragment of an iron Roman sword blade was found 200 m from the hoard. The coins have a rather bad condition (heavy wear). The further fate of the coins is unknown.
157 denarii were found but details were only provided for 37 coins: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Archaeological Museum in Zagreb (37 coins); dispersed

summary: Four bronze coins, three sestertii and 1 as, were found together in a wall: Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161)

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing at least 11 coins (10 sestertii and 1 dupondius) found during construction work. The pot and 11 coins were given to the Museum Laufen, where, ca. 2014, only these 11 coins could be identified: Domitian (1 coin), Trajan (1 coin), Hadrian (5 coins), Antoninus Pius (1 dupondius), M. Aurelius/L. Verus (1 coins), Commodus (1 coin), Crispina (1 coin).
6 bronze coins: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard comprised a mixed hoard of gold, silver, and bronze deposited in relation to the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Unknown original number of denarii, 69 preserved: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168); silver weight: 194 g.
4 denarii up to Commodus found in an arm purse.

The hoard comprised either a) a ceramic vessel containing several hundred sestertii of Nero to Marcus Aurelius. b) two ceramic vessels found on separate occasions containing 60 and 110 coins respectively.
Four 2nd c. AD coins were found during sharding in Flurdistrikt above the Geybach river.

Discovered during agricultural work near the village, on a field belonging to the peasant Grigory Radzevich. The hoard included 21 denarii (Trajan-Commodus) and silver items (ingot and four rings). The hoard was sent to the Imperial Archaeological Commission in St. Petersburg, where the coins were identified by J. Iversen; then transferred to the State Hermitage
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: The sculptor Zanda of Desulo discovered a deposit of Roman bronze coins, near the church of San Pietro. One of them belongs to Faustina I and one to Lucilla.
Two denarii issued by Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-176) were bought from the same local person.
A hoard of 30 denarii and 1 as (Republic - Trajan) found by the west wall of a plaster layer during an excavation on Reismühler Straße.
Unknown originally number of coins. 68 denarii are kept in the collection of the Library of the Romanian Academy: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Coin Room, Library of the Romanian Academy, Bucharest, Romania (inv.nos. 29069-29136)

summary: 270 coins. Only 10 sestertii are known: Trajan, - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Collection vicar Verstraete, Kortrijk, Belgium (c. 155 coins), in 1846; collection .C. Lefèvre,Brugge, Belgium (10 coins), in 1846

summary: 62 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 134-138).

The hoard was found in the foundation trench of a Gallo-Roman wall. It comprised 43 denarii from Vitellius to Marcus Aurelius as Caesar (AD 148/149). It may originally have been placed in a small box, as fragments of copper-alloy scrap were found in association with the coins.
800 denarii. 274 pieces were studied by V. Haralanov: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
In 1934, 40 denarii and 12 sestertii were found with an urn in a field north of Narcott Lane. The coins range from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius.
The hoard comprised 53 sestertii terminating in issues of Antoninus Pius and 'the young Marcus Aurelius'.
Purse(?) of four sestertii: Trajan 2, Hadrian I 2 (AD 121-122) found near a wall in the area of the civil town.
The hoard comprised 17 silver coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) and 43 bronze coins.
14 Roman bronze coins and one autonomous Histrian coin found in a small ceramic vessel: Hellenistic - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Coin Room, Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 121 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver weight: 322.18 g.
Over 600 sestertii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).

Hoard of 126 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter on the outskirts of Uman in mid-November 2014. Information about the discovery of the treasure and a photo of 53 coins were published on November 16, 2014, on the Ukrainian treasure-hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the treasure was found on November 13, 2014, in the forest on the outskirts of Uman. The coins were dispersed over a small area, and on the first day of the search, four treasure hunters managed to find 62 coins. On the second day, the search was continued by three treasure hunters, they found an additional 32 coins. On November 18, 2015, the same informant reported that a total of 126 coins had been discovered. The further fate of the coins is unknown.

Six (or more?) Roman gold coins found on a field. First, three were found by labourers in 1845: Domitian (1 coin) and Hadrian (2 coins). Then came a report that "two years ago" two aurei of Vespasian had been found in the same field, and probably more, thrown out by the labourers as brass items. In 1860 another gold coin found in the same field was reported. - The 3 aurei found in 1845 were described in detail and documented in sealing wax (lost) and later copied in drawings (preserved).

Ten Roman imperial denarii were found in the vicinity of ancient Olbia, to the west of Adzhigolskaya Balka, near the villages of Dmitrivka and Ivanivka (the exact location is not known). The coins have been identified by V. Stolba and U. Peter from photographs. The cirent location of the hoard is unknown.
8 denarii found on a field: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised 22 bronze coins from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Hoard of circa 700 denarii. Only 350 pieces are known: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
The hoard comprised of 27 aurei from Nero to Hadrian. 26 are identified.
726 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 187-192).
150 coins, of which 10 sestertii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
68 coins: 67 denarii, 1 imitation: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196). Weight: 156 g.
The hoard comprised 2 aurei, more than 400 denarii and some bronze coins and was found in association with a grave: Vespasian Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
175 silver coins: 173 denarii, 1 quinarius and 1 drachm: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Stadtmuseum, Neunkirchen (165 coins), private collection? (10 coins), Austria; lost (unknown no.)

summary: Hoard of 759 bronze coins: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192). Uncertain whether is part of MORSHANSKOYE 1838 hoard (?) or a separate one.
Around 200 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Didius Julianus (AD 193).
disposition: Münzkabinett, Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Germany (2 coins)

summary: 2 denarii: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Regional museum, Chrudim, Czech Republic (now, missing)

summary: 52 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
It comprised 210 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel, notably from Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and one of the Faustinas.
(49) 48 denarii: 35 republican, 13 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 101/102) .

Initially, circa 2,050 coins. Only 1,938 enter in the museum collection: 270 republican denarii, 1662 imperial denarii, 5 drachms, 1 as: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 165-166). Found with a bronze jar.
Hoard of 11 denarii.

81 bronze coins (72 Dium, 3 Thessalonica, 1 koinon of Macedonia, 1 Philippi, 1 koinon of Thessaly, 3 Roman bronzes) ranging from Domitian to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the east wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to two other hoards (Dion 1999 and Dion 2000). All three hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
Found during excavations. Assemblage of 10 aes coins, Domitian to Commodus, in a roadside ditch, spread out over ca. 5x1 metres. The hoard comprised 3 dupondii and 7 asses.

During the construction of the protestant Alumneum (Gesandtstraße) in 1900, remains of a hypocaust system were found. Within the debris a group of 8 coins - 7 aurei and 1 denarius - were recovered, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius. They might have been stored in a wooden box or leather bag. The hoard's deposition is conjectured to have been linked to the Marcomannic Wars.
95 sestertii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 195).
A roll of eight corroded and partly worn AE coins (Trajan to Lucius Verus), found within the group of furnaces north of the west gate (inside the Roman fort), in front of the furnace 5
Unknown originally number of coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Among the coins were recognized those of Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).
The hoard comprised at least 54 silver coins dated between the Roman Republic and Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Around 400 denarii of the 1st-2nd centuries AD. 153 provided information on the issuers: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Tsarist Archaeological Comission, St. Petersburg, Russia (153 coins)

summary: A hoard of about 20-25 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was discovered by treasure hunter in the late 2010s between the villages of Pysarivka and Hrushkivtsi in the Vinnytsia region. The coins were found on an area of ca. 20x20 m and all had the same traces of bronze oxides. The finder did not provide a photo of the coins, but said that among the coins were denarii of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina (I or II?), Marcus Aurelius (including those with the rank of Caesar). The further fate of the coins is unknown.

73 denarii (Vespasian to Commodus) found beneath a millstone by workmen removing "a quantity of loose stones and earth" near a lime kiln in a quarry. A pair of spurs was reportedly found at the same time. RCAHMW states that the precise location of the find is unknown "but there is apparently only one lime kiln on the estate" in a place still known as Limekiln Covert.
disposition: In the collection of T Assheton Smith Esq. M.P. (1849)

summary: A hoard found in a field south of Castlethorpe, comprising 20 denarii and 35 bronze coins, up to Lucius Verus.
52 denarii of Hadrian of only three RIC types: RIC 119, 256, 339 (AD 134-138). Found together with some bits of amber.

Upwards of 600 Roman denarii were found in 1851 in a field that was formerly a deep bog. The coins were all lying close together as if they had been enclosd in a bag. Also found at the same spot were an iron sword and an imperfect silver ornament thought to have been the crest of a helmet. A detailed account of 104 coins is given in 1852 and a further 26, found in a moss at Kirkness (Kinross) in 1851, were reported in 1934 and published in 1939. Coins range from Mark Antony to Septimius Severus.
600 denarii. 361 pieces were examined: Republic - Hadrian (AD 117-138); silver weight: 669.3-1389.9 g.
2830 silver coins: 2827 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 2 drachms: Augustus - Septimius Severus (AD 196-197); silver weight: before restoration: 9,290g; after restoration: 9,075.17g
disposition: History Museum ”Iulian Antonescu” Bacau, Bacau County, Romania

summary: The hoard was found in an ancient vessel and comprised between 500 and 600 bronze coins. Very close by, a large glass urn, pottery and three bronze basins were also found.

Eleven coins found over three private searches; one in 2009, four in 2011 and six in 2012 (described as "being stacked"). The 11 coins are dated from Nerva to Antoninus Pius. It is not certain that all 11 coins are part of a hoard, but it is likely as they have been found within a small geographical area.

Four denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), found at Aitnock fort (an Iron Age fort), situated on the summit of a cliff which rises about 60 feet perpendicularly from the waters of the Rye stream at the south-west angle of Hindog Glen near Dalry in Ayrshire. The coins had been wrapped in some material and were found in a layer of occupation.

A hoard of 111 Roman imperial denarii was found by five treasure hunters in 2013 in Chernivtsi region. Information about the find and photos of some of the coins of the hoard were published by one of the finders on January 20, 2014 on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity. According to the finder, the hoard was found late at night, but there is no more detailed information about the further circumstances of the find. Judging by the information from the treasure hunter, the bulk of the coins in the hoard were denarii of Vespasian, Trajan and Hadrian, although there was also a coin of Galba, several denarii of Nerva, and 10-12 coins of Antoninus Pius and Faustina (I or II). In the photographs posted with the hoard information, there are images of 26 whole and five fragments of denarii (Vespasian, Terva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius) – these were probably some of the coins that the informant found. The further fate of the coins in the hoard is unknown.
The hoard comprised 46 tetradrachms dated between AD 60/1 and AD 118.
13 denarii found in a room of a Germanic house: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
47 denarii. Only 5 coins are kept in the Museum of Assen: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 176)
12 coins: 1 denarius, 11 sestertiiTrajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found 800 m westward from the hoard Koropie 2008 1. Together were found a bronze brooch and a horn shape bronze ring
disposition: Laboratory of Archeology, Historical Sociology and Cultural Heritage, Faculty of Sociology, St. Petersburg State University, Russia

summary: During the excavation of the Antonine Wall fort on the Bar Hill, a hoard of 13 denarii (Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius Caesar) was found at the bottom of a well. Most of them were imitations, 10 of them were cast of pure tin. Only two of the coins, of Mark Antony and of Vespasian, were genuine struck denarii of silver. One coin, of Hadrian, seemed to be of some alloy of copper, and the remaining 10 coins were cast, of almost pure tin, with no trace of alloy. Of these tin coins, five, of Trajan, seemed to have come from the same moulds, and three others, also of Trajan, seemed to have come from the same moulds. It has been suggested that these were shams expressly manufactured for devotional purposes (throwing of money into wells from superstitious motives).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 11 denarii are known: Vespasian 2, Titus 1, Nerva 2, Trajan 3, Hadrian 3.
Large number of silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. The minting period run from 91 BC to AD 254. Only 69 coins are preserved: 1 aureus, 66 denarii, 2 drachms: Republic to Hadrian (AD 119-122).
35 denarii found among stones: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only two coins are preserved
The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing 50 corroded, worn, illegible Roman coins, with the exception being two sestertii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.

6 denarii found in the foundations of a prehistoric house: Trajan - Commodus (AD 191-192); silver weight: 10.46 g. Found together with Bronze fibula, bronze sheet, bronze bar, iron knife, iron mounting, fragment of glass vessel, glass paste bead, amber bead, potsherds.
480 denarii: Republic – Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 155-156).
918 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 916 denarii, 1 drachm, 1mitation denarius: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
A hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 15 coins were documented: Hadrian (Aelius Caesar) - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178). Kropotkin suspected that it may be the same hoard as Sosnitsa.
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (15 coins until 1917)

summary: A hoard of 180 denarii, ranging from Nero to Commodus. 9 denarii (Otho-Commodus) were found in 1938, on Lord Clyde's estate of Briglands, Rumbling Bridge. Subsequent discoveries at the same place were made in 1948-57, two-thirds of the way up the steep left (east) bank of the River Devon, after a coin was found at the opening of a rabbit hole. One further coin was reported in 1972.
Six gold Roman coins found in a burial: Vespasian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 4.
1,446 denarii found during construction activity: Republic - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 177-192).
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (964 coins)

summary: 21 bronze coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) published in am auction catalogue without details on the circumstances of discovery.
Few hundreds, 150 were documented: Republic - Commodus (AD 186-187).
Unknown number of Roman coins. Five denarii were placed in a liturgical cup in Limanowa!
IARCH record for a hoard of 14 denarii. For further details and images see WMID-01F18E. Unpublished catalogue by Richard Abdy.
(90) 27 denarii: 7 republican, 20 imperial: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found in a ceramic vessel.
(c. 215) 199 bronze coins: 194 sestertii, 5 dupondii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 191).
The hoard comprised 45 silver tetradrachms from Claudius I to Antoninus Pius. It is not clear whether the coins represent a complete hoard or part of a hoard.
282 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 222 coins were recovered: Vitellius – Septimius Severus (AD 195).
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest (182 coins); Institute of Archaeology ”Vasile Pârvan”, Bucharest (40 coins)

summary: Unknown number of Roman bronze coins, only 3 pieces are known: Augustus, Nero, Hadrian
The hoard comprised 13 provincial tetradrachms dated between AD 60-61 and AD 107-110.

168 Alexandrian provincial bronze coins: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 148-149). Found in the ground. All drachms, only briefly described. Oldest Vespasian, among the other coins are mentioned "interesting types of Antinous, Sabina, Aurelius Caesar, also some of the rare 'nome' types and few of the famous zodiacal series struck in the eighth year of Antoninus Pius."

The Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Nationale acquired 36 aurei on 17.03.1847 (Reg. C, nos. 1982-2017) and a further 44 on 8.2.1848 (Reg. C, nos. 2117-2160). 79 remain (with one swopped in 1939). The Musée Saint-Jean d'Angers bought 6 aurei on 3.4.1847 and 2 on the 13.06.1847, with fragments of the vase acquired on 04.03.1849 (Reg. I, p. 53-54, no. 209, p. 58, no. 217, p. 74, no. 269). They were stolen in March 1885.
A hoard of 150 denarii found in a ceramic vessel, covered by another ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193).
A hoard containing nearly 100 silver denarii from the period of Trajan and Hadrian was unearthed between Trostadt and Siegritz.
5 denarii from Vespasian (Domitian) to Antoninus Pius (M. Aurelius). Part of a larger hoard, details unknown.
26 denarii found in three separate finds (1921, 1924, and 1946): Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 194).
The hoard comprised 4 tetradrachms, at least 20 denarii, and "a large number of bronze" coins of the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/136).
Unknown number of denarii. Only 4 coins are known: Antoninus Pius 2, one of the Faustinas 1, Lucilla 1.
22 denarii, part of a hoard: Vespasian - Clodius Albinus (AD 193-197).
2469 denarii and provincial silver of which only 210 were recorded - Otho to Antoninus Pius (208 denarii, 2 drachms of Amisus of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius)
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara; Balıkesir museum

summary: Hoard of sestertii found while dredging the harbor: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).

In 1925 a hoard comprising 1081 bronze coins, originally included in a pottery vessel, was found after agricoltural works. Coins inlcuded in this hoard returned to the finders and went missing, except for 1 sestertius of Didia Clara now kept in the Museum Bottacin in Padua. Only a brief report on the coins included in the hoard is now available.

The hoard discovered no later than 1900; the total number of coins is unknown. A city dweller with the surname Shapiro bought 44 coins (Vespasian-Commodus; total weight 127.43 g), of which only eight were identified in the Imperial Archaeological Commission (by E. Pridik) and then were returned to the owner.
Around 1,200 aurei (according to Savio/Cavagna): Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192). Reported to have contained thousands of coins. The main part had been dispersed before the rest was confiscated.
86 denarii: Mark-Antony - Commodus (Crispina) (AD 180-191).
12 bronze coins: 11 sestertii, 1 dupondius/as found stuch together in a layer of fire: Nero - Hadrian (AD 129-130).

IARCH record for a hoard of 30 denarii found between 1985 and 1992. The latest coins are two of Lucius Verus and Divus Antoninus both dated to AD 161 and an undated coin of Faustina II. This might suggest deposition in the earlier part of the reign of Marcus Aurelius. See WMID-1AC648 for full details and images. One of the coins of Trajan is a small fragment.
The hoard comprised an unknown number of coins of which 24 denarii, including 11 Republican issues and 13 imperial issues from Vitellius to Antoninus Pius were recorded.
22 denarii found on a cultivated field: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174).
disposition: Gabinet Numizmatyczno-Sfragistyczny, Zakład Narodowy im. Ossolińskich, Wrocław, Poland

summary: 29 aurei including coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Lucius Verus. Together were found two gold fingerings.
A hoard of unknown originally number of coins. 18 denarii were documented: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).

A small hoard of 10 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian – Commodus (AD 193-211) was discovered by a treasure hunter in March 2021 somewhere in Poltava region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity, March 18, 2021. The finder reported that the coins were discovered “in one pit”. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
Two coins of Antoninus Pius, one Marcus Aurelius and one of Hadrian found in 1725, as part of a large 'parcel' of coins.
Hoard of 200 bronze coins: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only five coins are recorded. Uncertain whether they were found together.
disposition: Museu de Martins Sarmento, Guimarães. Portugal

summary: 272 denarii: Tiberius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 813.04 g
disposition: Complexul Muzeal "Iulian Antonescu", Bacău, Romania; inv.nos. 7008-7236

summary: Around 600 silver and bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 10 denarii were identified. The hoard was lost during WWII: Vespasian 5, Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Antoninus Pius 2, Marcus Aurelius 1.
disposition: School Museum, Brăești, Romania. Today, lost.

summary: 79 denarii found circa 25 m from the Jerzmanowice 2005 hoard and one more denarius found in 2009. Most likely one owner: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
18 denarii were discovered in the vicinity of the village of Raksha. Fifteen were documented: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 192).
41 denarii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) (AD 161)
46 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).

In early June 1958, 368 coins (4 aurei and 363 denarii, 1 Lycian drachm and 1 as) were found near Barway, Soham in Cambridgeshire. Further finds made in 1977, 1989, 1990 and 1991 bring the total to 471 coins, ranging up to Commodus.
disposition: Ashmolean Museum (part); Fitzwilliam Musem (part); British Museum (part); returned to finder (part)

summary: 7 bronze coins: 2 dupondii, 5 asses: Claudius I - Trajan (AD 101-102)
More than 800 originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 441 coins: 406 sestertii, 29 dupondii, 5 asses, 1 AE provincial: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-187).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (443 coins); Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (1 coin).

summary: Hoard of didrachms and drachms of the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. 8 coins have been purchased by the local museum in Zugdidi: 5 didrachms Trajan, 2 didrachms Hadrian, 1 drachm Trajan.
