Hoard of denarii dispersed among locals. 88 denarii entered museums' collections. Six denarii can be entered at coin level: Antoninus Pius 1, Lucius Verus 1, Faustina II 3, Commodus 1.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Warsaw (8 coins), Lublin (60 coins), Poland; Local museum, Lutsk (20 coins), Ukraine.

summary: The hoard comprised between 1,400 and 1,500 'copper' coins from Nero to Antoninus Pius.
735 denarii found with ceramic vessel and a textile bag: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 195). Found together with a silver T-brooch within a Sarmatian settlement.
disposition: Numismatic Collection of the Institute of Archeology, Iași, inv. no. 323370 (the brooch)

summary: 8 aurei: Nero - Antoninus Pius: M. Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 140-161)
11 denarii found with a cooking pot: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-135)
Unknown initial number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 350 coins were basically examined : Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Balaton Museum Keszthely (312 coins); Magyar Nemzeti Muzeum, Budapest (38 coins), Hungary

summary: 453 denarii from Nero to Commodus (AD 180). The latest coin has the reversed inscription as: TR P V IMP IIII COS II P P. The composition of the hoard is described by D. Tacchella (1896) by of number types not by the number of coins (!). There are 224 types: Nero 1, galba 1, Vitellius 1, Vespasian 21, Titus 4, Domitian 9, Nerva 4, Trajan 13, Hadrian 34, Sabina 2, Antoninus Pius 54, Faustina I 23, Marcus Aurelius 30, Faustina II 12, Lucius Verus 6, Lucilla 5, Commodus 1, Crispina 1.
disposition: Some of the coins entered the National Museum in Sofia in 1895.

summary: 15 sestertii of which Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina II 1, Commodus 1 were found by fishermen in a dune.
Circa 300 denarii were discovered while plowing. Denarii of Antoninus Pius and Commodus were mentioned.
Unknown number of denarii. 5 pieces entered the museum collection in Kazanlak: Domitian 1, Trajan 4.
disposition: Museum of History, Kazanlak, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3994-3998

summary: The hoard was discovered in 1993 by Vasily Prigodich (excavator operator), during the digging in a chalk quarry (between the villages of Malyech and Kabaki). The coins were in a hand made pot. In total, the hoard contained 408 (or 409?) coins, but to study preserved only 383 denarii (Vespasian-Septimius Severus) and four barbarian imitations of denarii.
disposition: National Historical Museum of Republic of Belarus

summary: Around 50 bronze coins were found in a money-box. Only 13 coins were recovered: 5 sestertii, 6 dupondii, 2 asses: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) are kept in the National Museum in Ljubljana.
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia (13 coins), inv.no.: 4584-4591; dispersed

summary: 151 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 9 Greek bronzes, 1 provincial bronze and 1 ring: Ptolemaic dynasty - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 166-167). Reported to have been found in an alabaster container. Mixed up with another hoard of over 130 coins not identified.

6 denarii and 1 AE coin, ranging from Domitian to Commodus, found in cellar 207 between 1897 and 1908. These 7 coins of this find were not identified according to inventory number or type and could thus not be separated out from the list of single finds.
ca. 80 sestertii and dupondii, but not all of them are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Over 200 silver coins. 168 are known: 166 denarii, 2 drachms of Lycia: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167).
Only 4 sestertii are known: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Two double pierced coins (aureus - Commodus and an Indian imitation of Marcus Aurelius/Commodus) were found along with modern earring.
Originally 390, 371 preserved: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver weight: 965.17 g.
92 denarii: Vitellius – Commodus (AD 180-183).
12 denarii entered the collection of the Pedagogic High-School in Iași: Vitellius – Hadrian (AD 125-128). Part of the hoards Strunga I and II.
A find of 8 coins of Faustina II, made in the area of Panagia Vrontou in Salamina.

Over 486 silver and bronze coins found in four ceramic vessels. Found 3 m from KRISTENDORF 1. Vessel a: 38 denarii: Mark Antony 2, Nero 1, Vitellius 1, Vespasian 11, Titus 1, Domitian 4, Nerva 1, Trajan 3, Antoninus Pius 5, Faustina I 4, Marcus Aurelius 1, Faustina II 2, Lucilla 1, Commodus 1. Vessel b: 151 sestertii: Galba 1, Vespasian 1, Titus 2, Domitian 2, Trajan 12, Hadrian 23, Antoninus Pius 28, Faustina I 11, Marcus Aurelius 24, Faustina II 13, Lucius Verus 5, Lucilla 7, Commodus 15, Septimius Severus 5, Julia Damna 1, Caracalla 1. Vessel c: 237 bronze coins: Vespasian 1, Titus 1, Domitian 3, Trajan 13, Hadrian 41, Sabina 2, Antoninus Pius 32, Faustina II 11, Marcus Aurelius 56, Faustina II 34, Lucius Verus 6, Lucilla 8, Commodus 24, Crispina 1, uncertain 4. Vessel d: 60 sestertii: Titus 1, Nerva 1, Trajan 3, Hadrian 5, Sabina 1, Antoninus Pius 13, Faustina I 2, Marcus Aurelius 14, Faustina II 11, Lucilla 2, Commodus 4, Crispina 1, uncertain 2.

A hoard of an unknown number of coins. Only three coins entered a museum collection: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius. Another denarius of Nerva comes from the same place, most likely part of the hoard
31 bronze coins: 22 sestertii, 9 dupondii: Trajan - Hadrian
9 bronze coins from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius, most likely a part of a larger find.
Hoard of circa 100 denarii. 18 coins were documented: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 180-192). Weight: 29.86.
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 4 coins were documented: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Commodus.
The hoard was found during the excavation of a Gallo-Roman villa and comprised 6 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus with a tpq of AD.
Hoard of uncertain number of imperial denarii found while metal detecting. 28 coins were presented to the museum: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 191-192).
disposition: Grodno State Historical and Archaeological Museum, Belarus

summary: Hoard of around 200 denarii found with a small ceramic vessel. Only 34 coins were documented: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Historical Museum, Moskow, Russia (inv.nos. 98100-1; 036 658-1; 036 685 - 28 coins); Historical Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (inv.no. 12607/1-6 - 6 coins)

summary: 11 bronze coins: 5 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 2 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-179)
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (11 coins), donations P. De Baeck.

summary: A Roman coin hoard of 80-100 denarii was unearthed in Samenheim. The precise find location and circumstances are not further ascertainable. The bulk of the find is lost. Only 20 denarii, ranging from Nero to Hadrian, now part of a private collection, are preserved. It is possible that these 20 coins may represent the full chronological coverage of the original find.
The coins were found in a glass urn along with a human cremation. Among issuers Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
5 denarii: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver weight: 14.16 g.
Unknown number of antoniniani, among, those of Aurelian and Severina.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria (2 coins)

summary: Concentration of 12 denarii and one drachm of Amisus (Hadrian), found in two adjacent excavations (1988/03 and 1992/42). This could well be a scattered purse or hoard.
(150) 102 bronze coins: 1 imperial, 149 provincial coins: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 866 (102 coins)

summary: Unknown Initial number of coins. 16 bronze coins: 5 sestertii, 11 provincial: Nero - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
4811 denarii and antoniniani, found in one (or two?) urns, in the garden of the school. Coins range from Caracalla to Postumus.
1,088 denarii and antoniniani were found in a copper vessel: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 9221-10309

summary: 70 Roman coins and 3 silver Gaulish coins (possibly a separate hoard?) are said to have been found, in pits and wells, along with many artefacts, but there is no contextual information. From the lists given (see Robertson for details), it might be possible to extract the traces of a hoard of AE coins (possibly with some denarii) to Severus Alexander, partly mixed with a hoard of antoniniani to the Tetrici. There is actually no mention of a pot, so that it is not really certain that it was a hoard, according to Roberston.

A Roman coin hoard was found in the field of a sexton containing more than 100 silver and copper coins, with most of the silver coins made of bad alloy. The sources mention coins of Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Gallienus, Salonina, Aurelian and Probus. Four coins are listed in FMRD, of which a description exists. It can be assumed that the hoard comprised mostly antoniniani of the middle of the third century AD and was buried between 276 and 284 A.D.
The hoard was hidden amongst a pile of Roman tiles and comprised more than 2,000 sestertii. TAF suggests that the large bronze of Gallienus should in fact be identified as a medallion.
Four antoniniani (radiates), that may have belonged to a hoard: Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius for Hostilian (Caesar/Augustus), Gallienus (AD 253-259).
7 antoniniani: Tacitus - Carinus (AD 283-284)
1889 antoniniani, 43 imitations, 6 forgeries and some fragments: Elagabalus - Probus (AD 276-282).

942 coins: 1 aureus (Caracalla) mounted in a necklace, 939 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian to Philip I, and 2 bronze coins (missing today). The hoard comprised gold (600 g) as well and silver jewellery (400 g), a shallow silver dish and a silver salt box.
50 bronze coins, probably, placed in a wooden box with bone hinges: 49 sestertii, 1 as: Trajan - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
288 denarii found in a ceramic vessel within the Carpic settlement: Nero – Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
The hoard was found in a hollow stone and comprised 300 denarii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 211-217).

306 coins: 255 antoniniani (radiates), 50 denarii, 1 sestertius: Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (AD 253-268). Together, were found jewelry: 2 silver rings, 1 pair of gold earrings and 1 gold children’s earring.
16 bronze coins were bought by the museum: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. XXV

summary: This record has been created for the HER record of a hoard of 36 third century Roman coins found in the Waddon New Road, Croydon. The details of this find seem to differ from those associated with Robertson 2000, 235 no. 963: (apparently a fourth century hoard found in 1903) and the tetrarchic hoard of 34 coins found before 1914 associated with Robertson 2000, 251 no. 1047.Seaby's Coins and Medals Bulletin 1961, 234 reports 36 coins found in the Waddon New Road area during the excavation of a cutting between West Croydon and Pitlake in 1814 and in a private collection. Details are unfortunately vague: "All were Antoninianii and the range of dates encompassed only thirty years...Several rulers were represented and all coins with the exception of one originated from the same mint - Rome".
Within an ancient settlement was found a deposit of iron tools. Beneath were discovered 280 silver and bronze coins. The latest one from the mid-3rd century AD. No further information.
The hoard comprised 2151 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Tetricus I (AD 273-274).
During the excavations of 1890, a hoard of 170 bronze coins were discovered: 169 sestertii and 1 provincial bronze: Augustus - Postumus (AD 260-268).
A hoard of 428 denarii dating from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus Thrax (235/236) and one Caesarean drachm of Septimius Severus found at Sulakyurt.
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara, Turkez

summary: Approx. 80 small bronze coins, of which 13 are imitations of Tetricus I, found on a brickyard located between the Lehmstrasse and Am Schlütershof. Apparently, they were contained in a small metal box.

The hoard comprised 180 Provincial bronzes from Nicopolis, found next to a small countryside road, at Phloriada-Valtos, Plakanida, at the border of Aetolia and Acarnania. The list given here follows Calomino.
A hoard of circa 169 provincial coins of Tarsus found on the site of the ancient city ranging in date from Septimius Severus to Trebonianus Gallus.

The hoard comprised a whiteware vessel containing approximately 2,000 'small bronzes.' These are considered to have been antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Postumus). The latest coins (E332,334 and 336) were struck in Cologne in AD 263. Archives of Musée des Antiquités de Rouen: Inventory III, p. 78, no. 2316 (12.06.1912)
Around thirty antoniniani in freshly minted condition, of Gallienus, Macrianus, and other contemporaneous issuers.
The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing at least 313 antoniniani (radiates) radiates: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg; private collection

summary: 138 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian (AD 253-260).
1,325 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Philip I - Probus (AD 276-282).

A hoard of at least 98 antoniniani (the publication is not numbered, but states that the hoard is preserved in its entirety), found by a farmer on the site of ancient Aspledon, on the northern bank of the Copaïs Lake. Acquired by the art historian E. Basserman-Jordan (Munich).
150 coins: 140 sestertii, 10 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus/Gallienus (AD 251-268). A silver patera and a lead weight were discovered together with these coins.
Contents of a little purse. Six denarii Septimius Severus - Caracalla.
The hoard comprised 60 silver coins, almost all of Gallienus (AD 253-268).
Unknown original number of coins. Only one of 25+ coins has been recorded and is known. All the coins are likely to have been denarii or antoniniani (radiates).
2,567 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (Sole) - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Gradki muzej Varaždin (2567 coins); finder (19 coins)

summary: 51 radiates (Volusian to Victorinus) found in the course of excavations at the Cambria House site on the civil settlement outside the legionary fortress at the NW corner. The coins were in the filling of a drain, but it is not clear whether they represent a deliberate deposit or an accidental loss.
11 burned antoniniani: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275). Two lots of 8 (24.09g) and 3 (8.83g) coins.
Unknown originally number of coins. 53 denarii were recovered in two lots: Vespasian – Gordian III (AD 238-244).
52 denarii, 51 antoniniani (radiates), 1 quinarius: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Unknown number of antoniani were found in unknown circumstances. 6 pieces are kept in the museum collection in Ruse: Trebonianus Gallus 1, Valerian I 2, Gallienus 2, Claudius ?? 1.
Circa 700 antoniniani (radiates), 371 recovered; silver weight: c.190.0-874.0 g.
16 denarii and 4 radiates, ranging from Diva Faustina to Philip I

The hoard comprised 1,094 antoniniani (radiates) including issues of Valerian I, Gallienus, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Claudius II, Divus Claudius II, Quintillus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II and Aurelian. Silver weight: 208.4-798.1 g.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 1,500 and 2,000 third century bronzes. 105 of these coins were identified. All were radiates, although it was noted that originally there were a 'certain number' of denarii of Postumus. 100 coins from the hoard were acquired by the Musée de Poitiers. Silver: c.1500-2000 (105) coins; Silver weight: 473.5-2186.5
disposition: Museum of Poitiers; private collections (2 coins); some coins lost

summary: 253 bronze coins: 252 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Vespasian - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).
It comprised 820 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

The hoard comprised 'an earthenware vessel filled with 652 silver and billon coins (denarii and radiates) and 100 bronzes (sestertii and dupondii or asses). The silver and billon coins weighed 3.7kg. A further 186 coins were offered for sale in Rouen in 1971 and appear to be from the same hoard.' The coins were deposited at the Bibliothèque municipale de Rouen, where 168 examples were actually conserved and catalogued by Mme J. Delaporte. Archives Inventory No. 2-653.
disposition: Bibliothèque municipale de Rouen (Archives Inventory No. 2-653)

summary: A hoard of 1167 denarii and 2 antoniniani found in the south-wester of the Hungerbergacker property during spring 1937. FMRD associates the deposition of the hoard with the Alamannic invasions of Raetia in AD 233 and the assemblage is notable for the high proportion of eastern mints. Coins range from the late Republic to Severus Alexander.
disposition: Museum Straubing (ca. half of the coins)

summary: Single finds of 21 Roman coins, Tiberius to Gallienus, found during metal detectorists' surveys on the site of a Roman villa rustica. Some of these might be part of a scattered hoard. Among coins found 1998-2011: 11 antoniniani and 10 denarii, Antoninus Pius to Gallienus (joint reign) and Postumus. 9 of these have been published with full references.
(195) 180 silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 245.1-503.7 g.
Unknown number of bronze coins. 90 pieces entered the museum collection in Pazardzhik: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History, Museum, Pazardhzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2145-2230

summary: The hoard comprised 75 tetradrachms (Nero-Trebonianus Gallus), found in the vicinity of Jerusalem.
disposition: Dispersed, Formerly owned by Dr. Schalit (Jerusalem)

summary: 40 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Hadrian - VAlerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258) found at floor level of a room during excavations of a house.
disposition: 34 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: 8 denarii found stuck together within a necropolis: Elagabalus - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
700 radiates The hoard was bought by H. Rigaux, but doesn't appear to have gone to Lille Museum with the rest of his collection.
4,942 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Elagabalus (AD 222).
disposition: Brukenthal Museum, Sibiu, Romania, 3,500 coins; County Museum, Pitești, Romania, 867 coins; Museum of History, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania, 531 coins; Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania, 44 coins

summary: Unknown initial number of silver coins. 84 coins recovered: Antoninus Pius -Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 25.0-216.1 g.
The hoard comprised 43 tetradrachms and 95 radiates dating to the third century AD.

The hoard comprised 40 sestertii and dupondii or asses from Trajan to Gordian III. They were accompanied by a small copper-alloy figurine. The hoard was found by a worker in a vineyard in a semi-circular niche hollowed out of the rock.
240 denarii (Commodus - Gordian III) were found during renovations of a house in 1933. The coins were to the Ingolstadt museum but lost in 1945.
Unknown original number of coins. Only 10 pieces were recovered: 8 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate), 1 plated denarius: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
Hoard of around 1,000 silver coins. 29 coins are kept in the Joanneum, Graz. According to G. Dembski the coins may rank from Severus Alexander to Gallienus.

At least 18 radiates (Gallienus to Tetricus I) found in the area of Tintern some time around 1872. It is uncertain that these represent the entirety of what might have been a hoard. No further information is available.
The hoard comprised 'a large number of bronze coins, apparently in gold or silver. Fourteen were identified as issues of Aurelian.

10 radiates (Gallienus to Carausius) found along with fragments of a possible bronze container by a farm worker ploughing a field near Plas Nanteos. The coins entered the collection of a local antiquarian and were sold upon his death. No further information is available.

A third century hoard of 99 antoniniani (radiates) interpreted as a savings hoard. Found during development control excavation in advance of building new housing estate: Gordian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
22 Syrian tetradrachms, ranging from Elagabalus to Trebonianus Gallus, found in destruction deposits of Room 9J.
Few hundreds denarii. 14 pieces entered the museum collection in Stara Zagora: Faustina II 1, Septimius Severus 5, Julia Domna 2, Geta 2, Caracalla 3, Maximinus I Thrax 1.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3520-3525

summary: 8 antoniniani ranging from Philip I to Victorinus 8, possibly part of a hoard found in 1935. The coins were found in northern area of Edlington Wood, below Crags.
1058 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius II - Probus (AD 276-282).
18 provincial bronze coins found in a small ceramic vessel. 16 coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2677, 16 coins

summary: Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 156 silver coins: 147 denarii, 9 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 247); silver weight: 198.8-366.5 g.
88 antoniniani (radiates) found by metal detecting. Only 44 pieces were available for study.

The hoard comprises 32 antoniniani (radiates) from Aurelian to Numerian). The first publication by Taracena notes 1 coin of Aurelian and 2 of Numerian. However, Gurt notes 2 examples of Aurelian and 1 of Numerian.
340 denarii: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 202-210).

Hoard of 223 coins: 6 aurei, 217 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269); gold weight: 27.1-30.0g.; silver weight: 59.8-315.7g. Together was found a ring (metal not specified).
The hoard comprised a vessel containing between 1,300 and 1,500 copper-alloy coins from Antoninus Pius to Tetricus I.

A hoard of 907 coins, found in a broken clay pot during building work carried out with a bulldozer: one Parthian drachm (Orodes I), 771 didrachms and 4 drachms of Caesarea in Cappadocia up to Geta, and 131 Roman denarii up to Alexander Severus, as well as one drachm of Caracalla attributed to Petra and dated to AD 211-12 (listed as a coin of Elagabalus from Caesarea by Dundua 2008).
The find consists of 10 late Roman bronze coins (Tetricus, and other Gallic emperors), found in the area of the 'Kulturhaus am Hexenturm'
One barbarous imitation of a Roman gold coin found in a grave together with a denarius of Augustus coin of Caius and Lucius and a plausible drachm of Gotarzes II.
The hoard comprised 32 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Unknown initial number of coins. 169 (but there is evidence only on 161 coins) bronze coins were studied: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 266-267).
3 coins: 1 antoninianus Aurelian, 3 provincial bronzes of Faustina II.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1289-1317

summary: A hoard of 24 provincial coins (ranging from Antoninus Pius to Geta) and 5 antoniniani (Gallienus) were found in a small pocket behind the stage of the theatre in Corinth, at the level of the marble pavement.
56 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 21 silver coins, 35 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2070

summary: 45 silver coins: 3 denarii, 42 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 259-260); silver weight: 57.1-113.3 g
(7 kg) (1200+) 22 coins: 1 denarius, 20 antoniniani, 1 bronze: Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
Circa 95 antoniniani (radiates). Dembski 1977 gives the evidence for 89: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 26.6-117.8g.

1,091 coins placed in a cloth and a ceramic vessel: aureus, denarii, antoniniani (radiates), imitations: Septimius Severus to Diocletian/Maximian I (tpq. AD 297); silver weight: 204.0-2827.6 g. Together were found three silver rings.

14 aureii (13 mounted): Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 204); gold weight 110 g. Found with a bronze pitcher. The content: two crosses; three chains; a brooch; sixty-eight pendants and sixty-four grains of necklace; fourteen coins of Roman emperors of the second-third century, the Antonines mainly, and two bracteates.
797 silver coins: 641 denarii, 156 antoniniani (radiates): Vitellius - Philip I (AD 244-245).
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 34 pieces eneterd the museum collection in Targovishte: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 46

summary: On July 28, 1937, a hoard of 1478 silver and 2 copper coins was found in Rochester Road, St. Anne's, Bristol, in a pit that was being dug for a garage. No trace of any container could be found, though careful search was made. The silver coins were 1476 denarii (Mark Antony to Septimius Severus) and two drachms (Caesarea in Cappadocia and Lycia). Please note that Pearce and Mattingly's coin summary lists 128 denarii of Hadrian and 66 of Faustina I, but the catalogue includes 126 Hadrianic denarii, and 68 denarii of Faustina I.
disposition: British Museum (part); City of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery (part)

summary: 96 denarii found with a ceramic pitcher: Republic – Septimius Severus (AD 201-210).
disposition: History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (91 coins); Cultural room, Ardeoani (4 coins); High-school ”Vasile Alecsandri”, Bacău (1 coin)

summary: 77 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I
32 silver coins: 24 antoniniani (radiates), 8 denarii: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
290 denarii ranging from Marc Antony to Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
Antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard (8 denarii and antoniniani, Elagabalus - Philip I) was found at the bottom of a container during construction work at Heilbronn street.
241 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 67.4-624.3 g.
Eighteen aurei were found in a local earthenware pot. Some of them were pierced.

Approximately 10,000 coins. Information on only 925 pieces, billon Alexandrian. Portion of a hoard in the possession of Louis T. Dilauro, June, 1979. Some 400 additional pieces were said to have been culled at random, and the original size of the whole is said to have been in the range of 10000 pieces.
disposition: Louis T. Dilauro (June, 1979, part of the hoard); 3 in New York, the rest in trade. Detailed list in New York (William E. Metcalf).

summary: (c. 18 kg, 4,062) 1,590 silver coins denarii, antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 5078.8-10559.8 g.

7,426 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 270-271); silver weight: 1783.8-13513.7 g.. It is not clear whether this hoard was part of the deposit found on the site in the nineteenth century, or whether it represents a separate hoard on the same site. The hoard was found during rescue excavations by the Direction des Antiquités Historiques des Pays de la Loire after an individual found coins scattered on the ground surface on several occasions on the site of a Gallo-Roman villa.
The hoard comprised 10 Roman Imperial 'bronze' (i.e. antoniniani?) coins, found in a Roman bath house in the southern part of ancient Pella. The latest were of Aurelian, Florian and Probus.
8 bronze pieces: 6 sestertii, 2 medallions: Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) - Septimius Severus (AD 210).

The hoard was found during the excavation of the fill of a Roman well in a previously unknown area of the vicus and comprised 54 radiates from Gallienus (sole reign) to Tetricus II with a tpq of AD 274. The coins were interpreted as the contents of a purse.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée National d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1990ss-100/10

summary: The hoard comprised 13 sestertii and dupondii from the first century AD to Gordian III, found in a large pithos. They might have been be part of a larger hoard.

The hoard was found deposited in an old wall and comprised 838 antoniniani (radiates). Hucher compiled a catalogue of 810 coins: Trajan Decius - Postumus (AD 260-269). Hucher acquired 351 coins for the Musée du Mans (Manuscript of entries 1863-1909, p. 4 and 5) and the Hospice kept 487 coins.Silver weight: 227.2-1046.5 g.

583 antoniniani (radiates). The precise location is unknown. Based on the high frequency of coins minted in Antioch has been considered a site near this city. Coins: Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The six antoniniani (radiates) were interpreted as representing a purse hoard or being part of a larger deposit.
Unknown number of silver and bronze coins. Two dupondii of Domitian and 5 antoniniani of Gordian III are known.
1,156 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) together with 136 bronze coins found in two ceramic vessels ranging from Trajan to Gallienus.
400 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Carus (AD 282-283).
disposition: Museo Civico di Legnago (16 coins); Museo Civico di Gallarate (239 coins)

summary: (c. 300) 49 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 258-259); silver weight of 63.8 - 128.7 g.
4,887 antoniniani radiates found in a jug in a stone quarry: Elagabalus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
(?) 39 antoniniani: Claudius II -Diocletian (AD 293-294); silver weight: 7.1-12.5 g.

The hoard comprised 31 Roman Provincial coins from Nicopolis from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus, found south of Nicopolis, at Agios Phaneromenes Vathi (Αγιας Φανερωμενης Βαθυ), where one of the three harbours of the city was located. The coins were found in two lots (of 5 and 26 coins), recovered at a few days interval, and both hidden under a tile.
Six or seven? aurei found in grave no. 3: Gordian III 2, Philip I 3 (AD 244-249) and possibly Hostilian 1 with a drachm of Gotarzes II and 3 denarii of Augustus found during excavations.
320 denarii and antoniniani found in a building from the ancient settlement. 22 coins were reviewed: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
7 silver coins: 6 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Republic - Valerianus/Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 253-268); silver weight: 11.8-22.8 g.
disposition: Musée Archéologique de Namur, Belgium (7 coins)

summary: An aureus of Trebonianus Gallus and a gold barbarous imitation of a Roman coin were bought in 1855 by the Coin Cabinet of the Museum in Berlin from a local from Jelenia Góra. No certainity whether the coins were actually found in this town.
disposition: Sammlung des Münzkabinetts in Berlin (17551-[1] coin und 17552-[2] Barbarous imitation. Unknown nowadays location.

summary: Uknown number of silver Roman coins. 1 denarius of Severus Alexander and 2 coins of Gordian III are known.
154 silver coins: 149 denarii, 5 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-239); silver weight: 217.9-454.5 g.
Two provincial coins, minted in Alexandria (Diocletian and Maximian), found on a field in ca. 1900.
2 coins: 1 bronze Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/ Diva Faustina II), 1 antoninianus (radiate) Claudius II (AD 268-270)
A suspicious hoard as there is very confusing information whether there is a hoard or more hoards put together following the excavations in the area of a Romano-Visigothic necropolis:
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: (c. 1000) 88 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani): Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 1251.6-2848.4 g
3456 antoniniani: Valerian I - Carinus (AD 283-285); silver weight: 623.2-4318.9 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv. no. N 326 - N 328

summary: The hoard comprised 180 tetradrachms (Nero-Macrinus), 22 denarii (Septimius Severus-Geta), and 35 bronze coins (Alexander Severus-Philip I). Details for 145 of the coins have been published.
32 silver coins discovered in a small ceramic vessel: 7 antoniniani, 25 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2574

summary: In 1906, a find of 107 small bronzes (radiates) was reported in Treffieux. These are very likely to be part of the same find as those reported by Fabre as being found in a garden in the early 20th century AD. This hoard comprised two lots of 909 and 44 radiates respectively which were studied in 1953 and 1958. Silver: 908, 1 coins; Silver weight: 246.1-1134.0g.
45 silver coins: Republic - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

The hoard comprised 'a lot of bronze and billon coins, of which 83 coins were recovered and give by M. Timbaud to the Musée de Rouen…'it is likely to represent a hoard or a portion of a hoard'; Antoninian dynasty - ; silver weight: 17.6-151.6g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France. Museum Inventory III, p. 61, no. 2157 (donated 17.5.1909)

summary: 114 provincial bronze coins: Antoninus I (Faustina I) - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria; inv.no. inv.no.741-758, 760-766,768-770,772-780, 782-842, 845-855, 982

summary: Over 500 coins were discovered on a parcel by a collector. G. Dembski have seen 68 denarii. Other scholars (Al. Ruske) expressed some doubts about these coins being part of a hoard: Hadrian - Severus alexander (AD 230).
60 antoniniani (radiates) found with remains from a textile bag: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270) in a doctor house.
102 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian and Diocletian (AD 286-287) found in a pile at floor level (along the wall of a room) during excavations of a house.

The hoard was found in a Gallo-Roman cemetery scattered over an area of some metres and comprised an unknown number of coins. 43 were recovered by private individuals and recorded by FMRL: Valetian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
18 coins : 13 denarii and 5 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus for Caracalla (Caesar) - Philip I (AD 244-247).
Hoard of 105 coins of the Bosporan kings: Rhescuporis II, Sauromates I, Cotys II, Rhoemetalces, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III, Cotys III, Sauromates III, Rhescuporis IV, Ininthimeus.
The hoard comprised 5 silver denarii from Septimius Severus to Elagabalus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 9.2g.
In 1959, D. Kienast may have investigated the listed series of coins in art-dealing, which reportedly were picked up as a hoard find in the city area.
61 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Found together with a bronze brooch.
disposition: Regional History Museum Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M IV 8346-8406

summary: The hoard comprised 117 bronze coins dated between Ptolemy I (323-283/2 BC) and Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
3,750 coins, mostly Syrian tetradrachms ranging from Caracalla to Volusian, some antoniniani and a few denarii, found in a destruction layer in the 'Poseidon villa' in Zeugma.
Unknown number of coins found in a ceramic vessel on the area of an a ancient settlement. 85 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2237

summary: IARCH record for a small hoard of 10 radiates. Possibly associated with the Chalgrove II hoard (IARCH-CB9058) but recorded separately due to uncertainty over this association.

The 9 coins (5 denarii, 3 bronzes and 1 antoninianus, to Severus Alexander) was found in 1780 with other relics, in a meadow near Marbach, at the confluence of Neckar and Murr. It is labelled as 'Kollektivfund' in FMRD, not as hoard.
10 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Claudius II to Probus (276-282) found in a grave.
The hoard comprised an amphora containing between 6,000 and 7,000 antoniniani (radiates), mostly of Claudius II, Victorinus, Tetricus I and II. Only 5 coins were identified more closely.
A hoard of 10 antoniniani (Valerian I - Gallienus) found in a destruction deposit of a Roman villa 500 metres from Chaeronea.
244 silver coins: 117 denarii, 127 antoniniani: Nero - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Found in a bronze vessel.

The hoard comprised more than 1,000 antoniniani (radiates) of which 1,038 were acquired by the Musée des Antiquités de Rouen' 'Une pelleteuse heurta' hit the vessel in which the hoard was buried: Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Augustus) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 281.2-1296.6g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France

summary: 67 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III to Diocletian (AD 284-293).
(55) 17 silver coins: 9 denarii, 8 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 21.6-34.1 g.
6 coins: 4 AE and 2 AR; Trajan-Elagabalus, with no further details currently available.
Group of 38 bronze coins: 28 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 7 asses: Nero - Postumus (AD 260-268).
41 coins: 39 denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 57.5-75.2g.
25 provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 238-244). Mints: Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis, Hadrianopolis
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1780 1-25

summary: A hoard of at least 202 radiates. The latest coin in the hoard is radiate of Gallienus (sole reign) from Milan mint dating to AD 262. Mint data exists for this hoard but TAF is not specific enough to allocate mints to rulers. Museum Inventory No: 75-7. Silver: 8, 223 coins; Silver weight: 71.8-592.1
2669 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 721.6-3335.3 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CLVII

summary: A hoard of 3 Roman Provincial coins minted at Thessalonica (2 of Elagabalus, 1 Gordian III), found in grave 35 in the western cemetery of Pella. The grave also contained numerous other artefacts.

A hunter stooping to pick up a hare, noticed 30 Roman coins scattered on the ground surface. Further investigation led to the discovery of another 50 coins, presumably a hoard dispersed by ploughing: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).

The hoard comprised a ceramic jar containing 37 bronze and silver coins dated between 146-139 BC and AD 193-211. The hoard was found in association with the remains of an ancient building, but this was destroyed during construction work.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 2,000 and 3,000 coins. The hoard was immediately dispersed but contained at least 20 radiates of Gallienus and Postumus.
10 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 3.7-11.5 g.
The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing more than 600 denarii from Augustus to Elagabalus (AD 218-222).

A farmer from Unter-Horgen found a hoard while fertilizing a marshy pasture. During this work he saw a number of coins laying next to a vessel in a ditch. The hoard comprised possibly up to 600 coins. The list given in FMRD encompasses 274 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from Antoninus Pius to Marius.

The hoard contained approximately 450 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of Vespasian, Antoninus Pius (?),Marcus Aurelius, Commodus, Julia Paula, Severus Alexander, Balbinus, Gordian III, Philip I, Otacilia Severa, Trajan Decius, Herennia Etruscilla, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina and Postumus. The most abundant were coins of Gordian, Philip I, Gallienus and Postumus. The attribution of coinage to Antoninus Pius is doubtful as the coin described belongs to Caracalla (RIC 277c).
63 coins: 9 denarii, 54 antoniniani: Marcus Aurelius - Trajan Decius (AD 251). Found in the baths.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. no. 743-782

summary: 105 antoniniani (radiates) were catalogued. The catalogue does not specify whether the radiates of Gallienus were of his sole or joint reign: Philip I for Otacilia Severa (Augusta) - Quintillus for Claudius II (Divus).
14 sestertii found in a house: Nerva - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised 6 aurei and silver jewelry. Two of the aurei are mounted in gold frames. The coins are: Antoninus Pius, Caracalla, Julia Domna, Macrinus and 2 of Severus Alexander (AD 234).
disposition: Musée national des Antiquités et Arts musulmans, Alger, (ex Musée Stéphane Gsell), Algeria; inv.nos. 1045 - 1053

summary: (300) 194 Ant: Gordian III - Valerianus I or Gallienus (sole reign ?) Gordian III 52
A hoard of 107 provincial bronze coins (of which 74 were identifiable), found in the Roman barracks at Dura Europos.
The hoard comprised a whiteware ceramic jug contained approximately 2,000 coins of Postumus.
The find of Adlerterrain in 1903 comprised twelve antoniniani and denarii ranging from Maximinus Thrax to Gallienus.

Large numbers of moulds for casting spurious coins, principally antoniniani of the period AD 260-74, have been found at Lyons Court Farm, Whitchurch, near Bristol, in 1891, 1897 and 1960. Coins were found as well, clearly part of a hoard accidentally incorporated into the levelling-material. In 1891, 16 Roman bronze coins were found while cleaning a ditch: Faustina 2, Lucilla 2, Commodus 10, Crispina 1, Postumus 1, associated with large stones, animal bones, and sherds of Samian, Upchurch and rougher pottery. Followed the discovery of a bronze of Commodus, and one of Maximinus. In 1897, additional clay moulds were found and 2 bronze coins oxidised together (Commodus, Septimius Severus). The 1960 finds include a sestertius of Marcus Aurelius and 4 antoniniani (3 Tetricus II and 1 Aurelian).
Hoard of 2,093 coins of the Bosporan kings, Ininthimeus and Rhescuporis V (AD 242-276).

Hoard was found at a brickworks called Les Caves du Roi, between the road from Paris to Calais and Estrées and on the route of the trainline towards Berck. Three sestertii were overstruck upon pieces of Antoninus Pius (1) and Marcus Aurelius (2). Together wuth These coins were found: a coin-die (!); a pickaxe (dolabra); a spearhead.
Unknown orignal number of coins. 72 antoniniani (radiates) were available for study. The hoard was found in two large ceramic vessels.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2,400 denarii with the latest coin being of Severus Alexander (or according to Blanchet, Gordian III).
500 antoniniani (radiates): Probus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 138 were examined and 18 entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Dalgopol, Bulgaria; inv.no. N. 0026/1-18 (18 coins)

summary: 19 denarii found by metal detecting: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
1040 (996) antoniniani (radiates): Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (Ad 271-274); silver weight: 281.8-1299.1g.
100 sestertii found together on an opus signinum floor: Hadrian - Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Augustus) (AD 251-253).
(+38) 38 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 7.9-46.6 g.
41 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Gallienus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274) found in a savings box.

During groundwork a coin hoard of 310 coins was unearthed near the Roman fort of Gunzenhausen. It comprised 308 denarii and 2 antoninianii, ranging from Commodus to Gordian III. Note that FMRD lists 310 coins, but in the summary only gives 309.

53 antoniniani (radiates) were found on Hosenstraße 4-5. They were purchased in 1903. "The coin series is so unified that it seems reasonable to accept it as a small hoard; the state of preservation is especially uniform."

The hoard comprised a total of either 5027 (according to Vlachogianni) or 5044 coins (previous reports). These include radiates from Caracalla to Gallienus and Salonina and 1 Roman Provincial bronze of Augustus from Sparta.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins found in a small ceramic vessel. Y. Youroukova examined 9 pieces: Septimius Severus - Caracalla (AD 211-217).

A hoard of 1925 denarii (Republic - Severus Alexander), found during levelling operations in the area of Bell's Meadow, in Falkirk, ca. 400 m NW of the Antonine Wall, in a vessel of red earthenware. A piece of cloth had been used to protect the mouth of the vessel. A few coins were lost, but all others passed into the hands of the Crown Authorities as treasure-trove. In all, 1925 coins, comprising 1923 denarii, one drachm of Lycia, and one bronze core of a plated denarius, were examined and published in 1934 by G. MacDonald. A new list, based on visual examination of the preserved coins, is given by Robertson, Studia Paulo Naster Oblata (1982). The latter recorded only 1917 coins. The missing coins were 2 denarii of Vespasian, 1 of Domitian, 2 of Trajan, 1 of Antoninus Pius, 1 of Diva Faustina I, and one of Septimius Severus. Recent studies have shown that 3 of the denarii attributed by Sir George Macdonald to Caracalla should be assigned to Elagabalus.
disposition: NMAS, Edinburgh (pot, cloth frag. and most of the 1925 coins)

summary: 745 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 293).
2211 silver coins: 10 denarii, 2201 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius (Diva FaustinaI) - Valerian I (AD 259); silver weight: 2765.1-5725.2g
40 silver coins found in the Roman Forum. The last ones are from Philip I (AD 244-249). No further information.
The hoard comprised an unknown number of silver Roman coins, of which 23 were catalogued: 1 denarius, 22 antoniniani (radiates); silver weight: 29.5-57.9g.
Hoard of 216 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282).
(c. 7-8000) 5103 silver coins: 3 denarii, 5100 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Tetrarchy (AD 294)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium; Archaeological Museum, Arlon, Belgium

summary: 13 antoniniani: Gallienus - Tacitus (AD 276).
A hoard of 50 coins found in a Roman building: 18 antoniniani (radiates), 4 denarii, 3 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 24 provincial bronzes: Antoninus Pius - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
20 antoniniani of Aurelian part of a larger hoard.
140 bronze coins: 130 sestertii, 10 dupondii: Vespasian - Macrinus (AD 217-218).
Unknown initial number of provincial bronze coins. 520 coins have been examined by Dr. Haralanov and 468 described: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1962/1-30 (30 coins)

summary: 42 aurei: Vespasian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258); Gold weight: 237.9 g.
12,000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) - 33 Kilos - found with ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
40 imperial and provincial bronze coins in the museum collection in Shumen: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13629/1-22; 13634/1-18 (40 coins)

summary: A hoard of 299 tetradrachms (Caracalla - Elagabalus) and denarii (Domitian - Severus Alexander) from Dura Europos, found in J 7 W.
Unknown number of gold coins and jewelry: Severus Alexander - Claudius II (AD 2680270)? Together were found silver and gold jewelry, one gold diadem and two gold ingots.
20 antoniniani found in a small ceramic vessel. Some of the coins belong to Philip I.
Seven antoniniani (radiates) found in House 1: Gallienus 6, Salonina 1. The coins were stacked to each other.
Republican to AD 193-221 Silver: 527 coins; Silver weight: 966.2-1890.2g
116 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). The issues are from the mints from Moesia and Thracia, mainly Marcianopolis, Nicopolis ad Istrum and Viminacium

Several thousand Roman coins reported to have been found in 1852. 32 coins, findspot mentioned "Malvaglia" and "Val di Blenio", entered the collection of the Antiquarische Gesellschaft Zürich (AGZ) and have now integrated the collections of the Schweizerisches Nationalmuseum, Zürich. They are probably part of this hoard (32 antoniniani, Aurelian to Diocletian).
disposition: Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (32 coins); the other ones are lost.

summary: The hoard comprised 5 tetradrachms (Trajan-Caracalla) and 1 denarius (Faustina II).

33 Alexandrian tetradrachms and a fragment of a bronze-ring. Found in a wooden jar in the courtyard just in front of a door during excavations of a house. Ranking: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292-293).
Originally 164 coins, only 45 were identified: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetrarchy (AD 299).
This appears to be part of a larger hoard and should not be confused with other hoards from Bavay which were composed of bronze issues. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 10.5-82.7g.
Unknown originally number of coins. Seven coins are known: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 266-267); silver weight: 3.1-7.8 gr.
166 sestertii: Nerva - Postumus (AD 260-269).
444 silver coins found with a bronze vessel: Domitian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Together were found two silver spoons
91 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 18

summary: IARCH record for scattered hoard of radiates (for full details see DOR-5D3543). Another hoard was previously found on the same field in 2013 (2013 T221 'Holt') with an addenda found in 2014 (2014 T962).
Unknown number of coins found in the 1980's. 4 pieces: 2 denarii, 2 antoniniani entered the museum collection in Targovishte: Julia Domna, Philip I, Gallienus.

The hoard comprised 216 coins (without doubt mostly denarii and antoniniani (radiates) and a range of silver vessels, gold and silver jewellery and a copper-alloy figurine. The earliest coin was an aureus of Galba and the latest were issues of Gallienus. The hoard was found close to a mill at a depth of 15 inches. Most of the hoard was acquired by the Musée de Genève. The aureus of Galba was stolen before 1903.
The hoard comprised 12 Roman coins, of which 8 were identified by H. Desaye: Gordian III - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 7.5 g.
A bunch of 12 antoniniani: Claudius II - Probus (AD 276-282).
123 sestertii, ranging from Caracalla to Valerian I.

These coins were found during the excavation of an imperial building. They appear to represent the remains of two separate hoards. The first (A) may have been deposited in the middle of the third century AD (AD 249). The second (B) composed of radiates dates to AD 270 to 275.
The hoard comprised 16 sestertii from Hadrian to Philip I and 25 denarii and radiates from Caracalla to Valerian I (AD 253-260).
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 31 pieces are kept in the Regional History Museum in Vratsa: Septimius Severus - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M VI 9663-9693 (31 coins)

summary: 108 denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 241-243).

A hoard of 46 mostly bronze coins (26 provincial and 20 imperial), ranging from Domitian to Trajan Decius, found scattered on the floor of Villa A, in a destruction layer associated with the Sassanid invasion.

6,263 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Rome (4,921); Viminiacum (4); Milan (340), Ticinum (6); Cologne (44); Trier (38); Lyon (2); Siscia (216); Sirmium (2); Antioch (2); Cyzicus (12); uncertain (4); imitations (1,068): Gordian III - Diocletian (AD 287-289). Found during the laying of electrical cables.
4 antoniniani (Gordian III - Trajan Decius) found during field work.
Although 17 sestertii were found, only 12 were described by Mattingly presumably because 5 were too worn to identify. Found stuck together in the "House of the two hoards".
17 coins: 1 denarius, 16 provincial bronzes: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2491

summary: At least three aes coins (Domitian and Gallienus), along with numerous other finds, including a tombstone, mortarium, glassware, fibulae, and studs, discovered while digging the foundations of the new gaol (now HMP Usk) on the field known as 'Cae Puta'. The two radiates of Gallienus might constitute a hoard, but the addition of the single aes of Domitian throws this into doubt. In lieu of more accurate information concerning their context, it is just as likely that all three are single finds instead of a hoard. Nash-Williams (1928) speculated that the site might have been the location of a fort.
1,587 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
5,056 silver coins found in one or more ceramic vessels: 17 denarii, 5,039 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus (Geta) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 966.5g.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel in a layer of fire. 28 denarii survived: Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) - Gordian III (AD 241-243; silver weight: 44.4-85.4 g.
The hoard comprised between 200 and 300 coins either in or close to a grave: Pupienus - Postumus (AD 260-269).

Found during construction work, no container reported. Located probably in the area of a Roman villa rustica. Hoard of 2,377 radiates: Gallienus (4), Claudius II (2), Divus Claudius (1), Aurelian and Severina (1115), Tacitus (730), Florian (4), Probus (519), Tacitus or Probus (1).
12 silver coins: 1 denarius, 11 antoniniani: Maximinus I Thrax - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258).

A hoard of 4 denarii (including a plated one) and 27 bronze coins (5 Hellenistic, 1 Rhoemetalces and 21 provincial coins), found in grave T4 in Lithochori. Only the latest of the provincial coins are identified.

In 1797, a farmer found many Roman silver coins in a smashed earthenware container, within the celtic enclosure of Oglishofen. Today there are 31 specimens of this find identified in the Maximillian museum, 12 specimens could be added here based on a previously published list.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 20 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 825-844 (20 coins)

summary: 191 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian (AD 274-275) found in a pile at floor level in room during excavations of a house. 1 bronze coin of the Ptolemy V may be regarded as a intruder?

The coins (15 denarii, ranging from Marcus Aurelius to Maximinus, with the probable addition of a further denarius of Septimius Severus) were found together at the southwest foothills of the Lehenbühl, SE of Fridingen.
395 silver coins: 280 antoniniani, 115 denarii: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
25 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) till AD 255-256.
From Elagabalus to Valerian I. Possibly incomplete as only known from antiquities trade: 61 coins; Silver weight: 46.4-156.7g. The hoard is dispersed having been sold in New York in 1980.
The hoard comprised 1 denarius of Severus Alexander and 277 radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus' joint reign with a tpq of 258 to 259.
The hoard comprised 14 radiates from AD 253 to AD 259.
A hoard of 402 silver coins: 31 tetradrachms (Marcus Aurelius - Macrinus), 370 denarii (Nero - Caracalla) and one tridrachm (Trajan) found in two jars at Dura Europos.
+100 coins dating from Philip I to Valerian and Gallienus. No catalogue was made and no further information given about the composition of the hoard.
The hoard was found in an iron cooking pot or 'marmite' and comprised an uncertain number of silver coins and some jewellery, such as 'large finger rings'.
79 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 202-210). "Only 18 coins were found at first, the remainder being recovered when an excavation of the site was carried out the following month."
Indeterminable total number of coins found by remains of an important Roman villa. Among issuers: Gallienus, Tetricus I

In 1873 a hoard was found during peat digging in the Burgau moss. It comprised 7 bronze jars, 3 golden rings, and 40 coins, ranging from Elagabalus to Trebonianus Gallus. All the coins except one were antoniniani. This was probably not the entirety of the hoard.
3,510 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius: Philip I - Aurelianus (AD 270-275)
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 38 sestertii were recovered: Domitian - Valerian I (AD 253-260).

The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing an unknown number of third century Roman coins stuck together with corrosion products. They were found on the site of an Iron Age oppidum. 141 coins: Septimius Severus - Quintillus (AD 270)
The hoard was found by a worker preparing the ground in a vineyard. Silver: 1,328 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-260); silver weight: 360.9-3450.5 g.

The hoard comprised a jar containing more than 7,000 denarii and some radiates. Some contemporary reports suggest that there were as many as 12,000 coins. Hugon suggested that the gaps in types and paucity of the latest issues and the presence almost exclusively of denarii indicated that the hoard was sorted by type and denomination and that originally there may have been further jars. Indeed, in 1943, a further vessel containing 28 denarii was found at the same findspot and is considered to be part of the same hoard.
691 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 284-293). No further details.
Unknown number of antoniniani. 27 coins entered museum collection in Haskovo: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. N 656, N 1039

summary: This hoard comprised 3,727 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of c. AD 265-275.
29 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282).

5 kg of silver coins with issuers from Nero to Severus Alexander. Only 1,350 were recovered, among which: 233 Septimius Severus, 71 Caracalla, 5 Elagabalus, 5 Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); Silver weight: 1764.3-3938.9 g.

A hoard of 97 tetradrachms (Nero–Severus Alexander), 25 denarii, and 1 antoninianus, found in a trench excavation at Gindaros. As no further excavations were done araound that trench, the archaeological context remains so far uncertain.
A hoard of 120+ Syrian tetradrachms dating from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus.

530 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269). Mints: until AD 253 Rome (except for 1 Volusian from Antioch); after 253: 72 Rome, 40 Cologne, 1 Milan, 2 Viminacium, 45 unidentified and for Postumus, 334 Cologne and 7 imitations. Silver: 580 coins; Silver weight: 145.0-295.5 g.
The hoard comprised between 400 and 500 sestertii from Trajan to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238). 92 were acquired by the City Museum of Nevers.
Unknown initial coin number. 28 coins studied from a private collection: Valerian I - Gallienus (sole) (AD 265-266).
Around 800 denarii found with a copper alloy vessel: Vitellius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
The hoard comprised 'a lot of 62 double sestertii of Postumus (AD 260-268). They were sold to a dealer in Rouen who claimed they had been found in Eu.
Sometime before 1869, somewhere in the vicinity of Nantes, a hoard comprising several hundreds antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and Tetricus II was discovered.
+8 kg, c. 2000 (515) antoniniani (radiates): Valerian - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: c. 541.0-2499.0g (after Hobbs).
Unknown initial number of coins. 20 silver coins: 19 antoniniani, 1 denarius: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-247); silver weight of 25.1-49.1 g.
70 coins found with a leather bag: 22 denarii, 47 antoniniani, 1 provincial bronze: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Radnevo, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 28-97

summary: The hoard comprised 353 radiates from Caracalla to the joint reign of Valerian and Gallienus with a terminus post quem of AD 257. The alloy of the two latest coins (RIC 241, 377) is described by FMRD as extremely good which is taken as an indication that these coinsmust date from the beginning of the joint reign of Valerian and Gallienus (AD 253), and not AD 257 as suggested in RIC. FMRD therefore gives the terminus post quem as 253 and sees a relationship between the deposition of the hoard and the incursions of the Germans the same year.
disposition: Stadtmuseum Ludwigshafen (but some coins are lost)

summary: In 1981 a hoard of 159 Antoniniani of the last third of the third century (Gallienus - Diocletian, and Gallic Empire) was unearthed during excavations of the Institute for Pre- and Early history of the University of Johannes Gutenberg at Mainz. The hoard was found in a cellar.
It had been discovered in two earthen vessels. It comprised of 137 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Only 97 are now recorded: Pertinax - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
The hoard comprised 586 bronze coins: Augustus-Philip I (AD 244-249).
645 denarii, 1 gold necklace and other artefacts. 154 coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: 29 antoniniani, 125 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Valerian and Gallienus/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. IX

summary: 3 coins: Vitellius sestertius, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) denarius, Philip I antoninianus (radiate) (AD 244-245).
403 antoniniani (radiates) and 34 imitations: Valerian - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
79 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
Uncertain total number of coins. 138 coins: 6 antoniniani, 7 silver coins, 3 sestertii, 122 provincial bronzes: Trajan - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-260); silver weight: 5.8-31.6 g.
Hoard of circa 100 coins. Only two pieces are known: Claudius I sestertius, Caracalla provincial bronze minted in Serdica.

In 1911 a container with Roman coins was found by Italian workers during excavation works for the Welzheim railway station. The precise find location could not be determined. The hoard was dispersed, but 277 coins reached the Stuttgart Museum, and 379 coins in a private collection were also documented. In total, 670 coins are listed in FMRD. Coins range from the Late Republic to Severus Alexander. They are mostly denarii, with a few antoniniani and 4 aurei.
disposition: Local museum, Welzheim, Germany; private collection

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing 550 3rd century ADcoins including issues of Gordian III and Philip I.
872 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver weight: 632.6-2244.5g
48 antoniniani: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 16

summary: Over 137 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 136 denarii, 1 drachm: Republic – Severus Alexander (AD 228-231).
disposition: History Museum, Târgu Neamț (24 coins); Local Museum, Târpești (44 coins)

summary: Around 30 coins found with ceramic vessel. 16 were recovered: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar)/Domitian - Severus Alexander (AD 231-235).
disposition: Civiche Raccolte Numismatiche di Milano, Italy

summary: Hoard of circa 1,200 'large bronzes' found with a large ceramic vessel: Trajan - Aemilian (AD 253). The largest number of coins belonged to Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Philip I and Philip II. Rare issues of the emperors Pertinax, Clodius Albinus, Gordian I and II,
The hoard comprised 391 bronze coins from Hadrian to Trajan Decius. The denominational composition of the hoard was not further described.
87 bronze coins: 2 imperial, 85 provincial: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv. no. 3635 (87 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vase containing 73 antoniniani (radiates) (or 60 according to Blanchet) from Gallienus to Probus.
369 bronze coins: 368 sestertii, 1 as: Nero - Postumus (AD 260-261).
This hoard of twenty three coins was found in 1928, and it consists mostly of cast imitations of the second-century aurei. Many of them are mould-linked.
75 denarii and 3 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Antoninus Pius to Gordian III (AD 241-243).
25 denarii found on the east wing of the north facing gate: Galba - Caracalla (Julia Domna) (AD 214).
Around 1,200 antoniniani (radiates) found with amphoras on a shipwreck. 229 coins were studied: Gallienus (sole) - Maximian I (AD 284-293).
Two radiates (Gallienus and Victorinus) found along with a gold ring beneath a stone in the valley side around Blaen-cwm-Pennant near Llangynog. No other information is available.

The hoard comprised more than 1,000 (?) coins, which were either bronzes or radiates. 72 coins were preserved in Auzances. The bronzes were extremely worn and sometimes illegible. 62 were sestertii and 7 dupondii or asses, although TAF does not assign denomination by emperor.
The hoard comprised 'approximately 120 Roman bronzes, principally sestertii, of which many were very crudely manufactured 'trés frustes'.
Possible part of a larger hoard. Only 4 antoniniani (radiates) are known; silver weight: 5.0g.
(c. 200) 40 silver coins: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249); Silver weight: 46.4-91.3 g.

Four aurei and jewelrey: Trajan Decius - Gallienus (sole) found with a copper vessel. Some of the objects were taken by the finder. According to the finder, Near the vessel was a stone in a vertical position.
disposition: Institut d'Archéologie de Bucarest; Musée National d'Histoire de Bucarest; dispersed

summary: NA
113 coins: Claudius I - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). No information on the denominations or other issuers.

The hoard comprised approximately 1,200 sestertii 'of 25 emperors, caesars and empresses' from Vespasian to Gordian III, mostly in a corroded or worn condition. There was also a single unworn bronze of Postumus
54 antoniniani (radiates) found near a wall of a building (Principia?) from the legionary fortress: Gordian III - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
27 silver coins of unknown denomination and issuer. According to the NUMIS the tpq is around AD 250.

The hoard comprised a gold necklace and 20 copper-alloy coins from Commodus and Caracalla. The archive report questions whether this deposit represents a horad but does not provide any further explanation.
370 coins: 12 denarii, 358 provincial bronzes: Marcus Aurelius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
200 gold staters of the Bosporan kings found on the banks of the Mortvyy Donets River: Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.
58 tetradrachms of Alexandria, 1 bronze coin: Vespasian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 294-295). Found in a heap beneath the floor of a passageway during excavations of a house.
disposition: 57 in Ann Arbor, the rest in Cairo

summary: A hoard containing, thus far, 121 denarii. The first coins were found in the 1950's, and the rest through excavation and metal detectoring until 2017.
Unknown number of bronze coins. 44 provincial coins have been noticed from mints of Lower Moesia and Thrace: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 193-2244).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CLXXXII (7 coins)

summary: 43 kg = +8,000 silver coins: denarii and antoniniani: Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 258)

A hoard of 402 denarii and antoniniani (Antoninus Pius - Trebonianus Gallus) was unearthed on a property in the Mangelhausen district of Wiesbach. The coins were originally contained together with a golden finger ring in an earthenware jug.
(247) 162 silver coins: 65 denarii, 97 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 266-267).
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (161 coins, 1 fragment of container)

summary: The hoard comprised 93 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus with a tpq of AD 282.
30 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 17

summary: 1 denarius and 903 radiates (Maximinus I to Victorinus) found by a metal detectorist at Craig-y-Saeson Farm. Decayed fragments of a possible pewter container were found alongside the coins. No more precise depositional or contextual information is available. Eight coins are counterfeit. Seven are of Postumus, whose coinage in now recognised to have been promptly imitated. The other, of Philip I, is a competent creation of good weight, but stands out on account of its style
disposition: National Museum Cardiff (103); Newport Museum (40); private collections (761)

summary: 7 coins: 4 denarii, 2 sestertii, 1 bronze found a in a layer of fire: Antoninus Pius - Severus alexander (AD 222-228).
298 provincial bronze coins found within the ruins of an ancient settlement: Commodus - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria, inv.no. 3634 (262 coins - 218 were stolen)

summary: A hoard of 432 Roman silver coins (denarii and some antoniniani), ranging from Commodus to Trajan Decius, found in the summer of 1895 during draining works at Brickendonbury, south of Hertford. The coins lay partly in a small recess cut in the virgin clay, and partly in the soil above.
7 sestertii found together in a very good state of preservation inside an urban villa: Maximinus I Thrax - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
90 silver coins: 36 denarii, 54 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius - Valerian I (AD 257); silver weight: 114.7-196.4 g.

c.50 loose coins and concreted mass weighing 1.8kg· The hoard probably consists of c. 400 ish coins which have corroded into a single concreted mass - the single block weighs approximately 2 kilos and there are another c. 50 loose coins.An organic container was thought likely - traces of leather were found.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2,507 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Aurelian (AD 270-275); weight: 6,100 kg.
The hoard was found in 1880. It comprised 150 radiates, from Gordian III to Postumus. Only 123 are now recorded.
863 Roman silver coins (Republic - Severus Alexander) found in a leather bag contained in an earthenware vessel on the royal estate of Einsiedel in 1859, in a drainage ditch.

A hoard of 16 denarii (Vespasian - Caracalla), found in 1832, approx. 20 min from the so-called stone bridge between Rhede and Borken, on a field in Vardingholt. The coins were sold in 1843 at auction in Münster.
The hoard comprised coins from Gallienus to Probus. There are some doubts on the real number of coins from this hoard!

70+ AR and AE. The coins found in the period 1828-1833 are partly derived from the hoard and partly from discovered complexes. The coins from the complexes may not be included to the coin loss from Voorburg. A total of circa 200 pieces. Coins (81-269): Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus, Commodus, Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Elagabalus, Severus Alexander, Julia Mamaea, Gallienus, Postumus.
disposition: Royal Museum of Antiquities, Leiden, Netherlands

summary: An urn of antoniniani (radiates) found between Sizzano and Fara. Only two coins are known of Philip I and Claudius II, as being donated to the museum in Fara.
disposition: Museo dal Sig. Luigi Spagnolini di Fara (on the May 10, 1886; donation record no. 723 (3)

summary: The hoard comprised 64 barbarous radiates of Postumus, Victorinus and Tetricus I and 26 unstruck flans. They were found during the excavation of a cave, not far from Berdorf. The presence of several identical coins and unstruck flans suggests that there was a forger's mint somewhere in the vicinity.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg (84 coins); private collection (5 coins)

summary: On discovery, most of the find was melted down and therefore it is difficult to establish the exact content of the deposit. It is reputed to have included 30,000 gold and silver coins. Buried around AD 260. Together were found eight silver statuettes and one silver plate remain from the original treasure.
disposition: Department of Greek and Roman Antiquities, The British Museum, London, United Kingdom; Musée des ursulines à Mâcon (copies of the statuettes)

summary: The hoard was found in 1989 in a field near Chalfont St Peter. The coins were contained in four pots, of which pots I, II and III were buried close together, and pot IV at a distance of four metres. The total number of coins in the hoard was 6,682: 15 bronze coins, 45 denarii, 2511 antoniniani of the Central Empire, 3560 antoniniani of the Gallic Empire, 197 irregular coins, and 354 uncertain coins.
disposition: British Museum (part); Bucks. County Museum, Aylesbury (part)

summary: 17 antoniniani (radiates) found in the wall plaster of a domestic building: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 5.6-20.3g.
A hoard of 13+ Roman coins (Caracalla - Gallienus), found after 1850 during house construction in Cottbus.
2 denarii: Elagabalus, Severus Alexander for Orbiana (Augusta).
About 2000 antoniniani and 4 aurei up to AD 270.
The hoard comprised c. 3/4000 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

296 AE radiates to AD 286. The coins were 1.5ft below the plough soil with no visible signs of a container. A circular, corroded stud with a narrow band and possible inscription was also discovered with the hoard. This is believed to be Medieval or post-Medieval and, as such, is not considered part of the hoard. A farthing (Seaby, 3992) was also found with the coins during conservation.Addenda of 618 coins found in 2104 added here.

149 Roman provincial silver and bronze coins found with a bag during archaeological excavations: 10 silver coins (4 didrachms, 6 drachms) of Caesarea in Cappadocia, ranging from Hadrian to Septimius Severus; 139 bronze provincial coins of Trapezus, ranging from Commodus (?, or Septimius Severus?) to Philip I (certainly AD 244/5, as this is the last time Trapezus produces coins). Authors disagree on the identification of the coins of Trapezus. These are badly preserved and were never published in detail. The list given here follows Kropotkin, as given in Depeyrot's translation. Golenko has a slightly different breakdown, including the mention of 4 coins of Clodius Albinus, allegedly from Trapezus. Kapanadze and Golenko also list 7 coins of Commodus, though these were grouped with Septimius Severus as uncertain by Kropotkin. The list provided in Tsotelia / Depeyrot 2010 does not offer further clarifications.
Over 100 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates), and a bronze clasp. Among these coins were identified issuers such as Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Philip I.
The hoard comprised approximately 1,000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Philip I.

The hoard comprised 'a large quantity of 3rd century coins, of which 39 were given by M. Richard to the Musée de Laval (Mayenne): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 12.5-46.8g. Three coins, Severus Alexander, Maximinus I Thrax and Saloninus are lost.
The hoard comprised between 400 and 500 radiates: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) for Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

Over 4,500 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 293 -294) found in a room (same rooms as KOM AUSHIM A51, A100, A115, A118, A119), stored on the floor, during excavations of a house.
The hoard was found in a burial and comprised 8 coins of Balbinus and other contemporary emperors and a small gold chain with double pendant.
26 bronze coins. Among them, 1 billon coin of Alexandria for Diocletian.
About 2000 antoniniani were discovered in unknown circumstances. No further Information.

A hoard of 11 provincial coins (Thessalonica, Pella, Dium, the koinon of Macedonia) ranging from Marcus Aurelius to Gordian III, found in a grave, part of a vast necropolis in the eastern part of Veroia.
269 bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel during metal detecting: 252 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 13 asses: Domitian - Postumus (AD 260-261).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel 64 sestertii and 77 denarii or antoniniani (radiates) from Vespasian to Valerian I and Gallienus. There was also one gold finger ring and one silver finger ring. Hobbs estimates a silver weight between 22.3g and 197.1g
The hoard comprised a ceramic container, the characteristics of which are unknown which contained 667 sestertii, one dupondius from Vespasian to Gordian III and one Provincial bronze of Hadrian.
disposition: Museo Arqueologico Provincial de Alicante, Spain

summary: 200 coins were discovered. Among them coins of Philip I.
48 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).

The hoard comprised 'a vessel filled with approximately 26 kilos of Roman coins, principally of bronze. 78 examples were identified from a total of between 500 or 600.' The hoard was discovered under a tree in the Rouvray forest, in the Mare-du-Puits canton. Silver: c. 5-600 (6) coins; silver weight: c.151.2-1603.4 g.
disposition: Museé de Rouen (Inv. III, 2, p. 54, no. 1909)

summary: 117,000 ”bronze coins of the 3rd century”, weighing about 38 kg, buried in a pit sealed by tiles. Probably, they were intended for re-minting.
disposition: Institut national de recherche archéologique préventive

summary: 175 antoniniani entered museum collection in Kardzhali: Gordian III - Philip I (AD 244-249). No further information.
A hoard of 6 Roman Provincial coins (Thessalonica and Pella) ranging from Julia Domna to Philip I, found in the remains of a Roman building.
45 coins found by the farmer Peder Madsen in 1850. The hoard was found collected without a preserved container. The coins were found bundled together beneath a big stone.
Hoard found during ploughing, 200 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
1,013 silver coins: 1 plated denarius, 1,012 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) - Aurelian (AD 270-275). The table of hoard structure indicate 1,010 coins.

The hoard comprised one silver coin and 18 bronze coins dating from the 3rd c. AD, found close to Metsovo (BCH 1939). Touratsoglou mentions 18 sestertii (Maximinus Thrax - Gordian III), next to 1 denarius / antoninianus, with the find spot Anthochori. No further information available.
The hoard comprised 160 Roman bronze and billon coins from Severus Alexander to Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The hoard was found in 1973 during archaeological program. The archaeologists discovered 45 kg of sestertii, in 12 rolls in a wood box. It comprised c. 1980 sestertii from Philip I - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Gallienus) (AD 253-268).
16 gold staters of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 460 silver coins. Auvray mentions Gordian III, Philip, Trajan Decius, Volusian, Trebonianus Gallus and Valerian. In 1834, Pesche compiled a more complete catalogue. His source (although he does not acknowledge it) appears to be a manuscript held by the Sociétè d'Agriculture which describes Roman coins found in the city of Le Mans and its environs. Pesche adds to his catalogue coins of Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus, Lucilla and Pupienus. It is not clear whether these coins are part of the hoard. Silver: c.460 (1, 173) coins; silver weight: c. 576.7-1295.1g.

Unknown originally number of coins. 88 pieces were available for study: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282). I. Pereira Rodriguez suggests that this hoard is one and the same with a poorly recorded hoard known only as coming from 'Serra, Portugal'.
disposition: Museu Municipal de Santiago do Cacém (Sintra), Portugal

summary: 2,236 silver coins: 415 denarii, 1,821 antoniniani (radiates): Commodus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

Six coins were found together with the artefacts of this hoard: Domitian bronze coin, Trajan (1 sestertius, 1 dupondius), Hadrian 1 sestertius, Antoninus Pius 1 dupondius, Postumus 1 antoninianus (radiate).
