The Chaourse Treasure is made up of 39 objects in total, all of which are silver apart from five small vessels and a silvered bronze mirror. There are four large serving platters; one of which has the swastika in its central medallion, another has a gilded figure of the Roman god Mercury holding his caduceus flanked by a ram and a cockerel. In addition, there are plain silver drinking cups, various jugs, two large situlas one of which has an acanthus-scroll frieze, shallow plates, hemispherical bowls (one of which was used for washing hands), flanged and fluted bowls (some with engraved decoration of animals amid floral patterns), some mirrors, an ornate strainer with floral and geometric designs, a statuette of the deity Fortuna and a pepper-pot in the shape of an African slave-boy. (Wikipedia)
Circa 585 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III to Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 176.4-730.3g.
Total amount of coins is unknown. The hoard contains 1 denarius and 236 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
The hoard comprised 25 sestertii from Hadrian to Valerian I (AD 253-260).

On the site of a Roman temple or shrine (?) in a field: 30 coins, significantly limited to the inner recessed area. The number joined by corrosion suggests the possibility of a disturbed hoard. They are mainly debased antoniniani covering the same period as the hoard found during the last century. Undated. Late 3rd century AD
313 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
A hoard of 13 provincial coins of Athens (period VI), excavated in 1934 near a late wall, north of the Tholos. Their burial has been ascribed to the sack of Athens by the Herulians.
89 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Gordian III to Aemilian.
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 50 coins were seen: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
84 sestertii and 1 forgery: Trajan - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
The hoard comprised 39 bronze coins dated between the reigns of Herod Philip (4 BC - AD 34) and Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard comprised 70 antoniniani (radiates) imitations of Tetricus I and II.

This hoard of 64 denarii and antoniniani (Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius) was found in 1846 «Im Lustgarten». The entire hoard arrived in the private collection of Großherzog Leopold, but could not be traced after that.
190 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 170 provincials: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 211-257

summary: (5 or 6 kg. coins, c.1500 coins?) silver coins, 16 recovered: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 21.5-34.9 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2499; 16 coins

summary: Hoard of 166 denarii (512.94 gr.) found stack together: Vespasian - Septimius Severus. It was found within the settlement of Chernyakov culture.
56 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Probus (AD 276-282).

The hoard comprised between 300 and 400 Roman coins, stuck together with corrosion products: Gallienus (sole) - Allectus (AD 286-293). Approximately 80 coins were destroyed during cleaning. Just over 220 coins were identified by A. Deville. In 1846, a further 4 or 5 argentei (?) and 40 antoniniani (radiates) said to be from the same hoard were noted by Joseph Curt. In 1862, Charles Roach Smith published an aureus from a Continental mint (RIC 621) from the Warne Collection which was reputed to be from the same hoard. The stated provenance for this coin should be treated with some caution. The nummus of Constantine I is also an intruder.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités, Rouen; Muncipal Library of Rouen; Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Natinoale, the Musée de Boulogne-sur-Mer, the British Museum (fewer than 10 coins), the Ashmolean Museum (fewer than 3 coins

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 3 provincial bronze coins are known: 2 Caracalla, 1 Philip I
The hoard was found in an iron box deposited under a mosaic depicting Bacchic themes and contained 40 coins of Gordian III to Postumus. The denominations of the coins were not specified.
Few hundreds silver coins. 467 silver coins were reovered: Nero – Elagabalus (AD 218-222). No further details.
disposition: Bruckenthal Museum, Sibiu (420 coins); National History Museum, Bucharest (47 coins)

summary: 2,382 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 644.1-2976.5 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (110 coins and fragments and casts); collection Meire, in 1950

summary: (c.700) 601 bronze coins: 598 sestertii (+ imitations), 2 dupondii, 1 as: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 262).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (37 coins); in 1959, 13 private collectors: 564 coins

summary: The hoard originally comprised 50.591 antoniniani: Gordianus III - Maximian I ( AD 293). Almost the whole hoard was acquired and now 45.873 coins are kept in the Museo di Castelvecchio, Verona. This find is extensively published. 168 kilos.
disposition: Verona, Museo di Castelvecchio, 45873 coins; otherwise dispersed

summary: Chappée and the Vicomte d'Elbenne bought two lots of coins (approximately 2,000) which were sold as part of a hoard weighing 20kg. They were found in a ceramic urn in a field next to the station in Sillé-le-Guillaume or in Rouessé-Vassé or in Mayenne (Voutré or Sainte-Suzanne). The Musée du Mans has preserved a manuscript note related to a lot of 583 coins weighing 1,453g and quantifying these coins by emperor: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
441 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

The hoard comprised several hundred coins of which only 150 were catalogued. They included a dupondius of Marcus Aurelius, a denarius of Plautilla, a few denarii and radiates of Caracalla, Geta, Elagabalus and Maximinus, numerous radiates of Gordian III, as well as Philip I, Trebonianus Gallus, Aemilian, Valerian I and II, Saloninus, Salonina, numerous examples of Gallienus, and some of Postumus.
(8-10 kg) 36 antoniniani (radiates) of Claudius II, Aurelian, Tacitus, Florian, Probus, Carinus, Magna Urbica, Numerian, Diocletian, Numerian (AD 293-294)
Circa 2,000 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

Six denarii "fairly close together, possibly a small purse hoard. Not possible to obtain details of 2 of these, but the remaining 4 consists of: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius for Faustina II, Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
The hoard comprised 12 bronze coins dated between AD 225-253.
631 Roman imperial bronze coins: Trajan (Plotina) - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 572 worn sestertii of the second century to Gordian III.
Hoard of 44 bronze staters of the Bosporan king, Rhescuporis V (AD 242-252).

A hoard of approximatively 400 silver coins discovered within a ceramic vessel, comprising a large majority of denarii (Trajan - Severus Alexander) and some Cappadocian drachms (up to Caracalla). The hoard was dispersed. Different accounts exist of its content, with Dundua 1979 publishing the 377 coins in the National Museum in Tbilisi (12 Cappadocian drachms and 365 denarii) and Zograf 1945 listing 417 coins (10 Cappadocian drachms and 407 denarii).

The hoard was found during the excavation of the courtyard of House L in Insula 27 at Colonia Ulpia Traiana. It comprised 5 denarii of Maximinus dating to AD 235-236. The excavation archives provide no further details about the circumstances of discovery.
The hoard comprised 135 sestertii from Vespasian to Postumus with a tpq of AD 260.

The hoard comprised 29 coins, ranging from Hellenistic times (?) to Philip. This includes coins of Athens and Cnossus, as well as Roman sestertii, dupondii and asses. Hadrian, Severus Alexander and Gordian III are also mentioned. The hoard was found beneath the foundations of a building, under a slab of stone.

1043 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Diocletian (AD 285-286). The emperors represented include: Valerian, Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Divus Claudius II, 'Imp. Gallo', Aurelian and Probus. However, the original number of coins was ca. 3.840.
disposition: Museu de Arqueologia e Numismática de Vila Real, Spain

summary: 17 antoniniani (radiates); Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).

The hoard comprised 500-600 provincial bronze coins of Byblus, Berytus, and Sidon, found while digging for construction stones, found in a 'cavity' (Höhlung) close to Beirut. Coins range from Macrinus to Severus Alexander, most of which minted in Berytus and Sidon.
A hoard of 233 Alexandrian tetradrachms, ranging from Nero to Philip, found 1968 in Abu al-Gud, in the vicinity of Luxor.
4 coins (Claudius II - Tetricus), found in a garden in Gehrden.
The hoard comprised 43 sestertii from Commodus to Gordian III (AD 241-243).
600 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269). Found close to the hoard ETTELBRÜCK 1889. Silver: 592 coins; Silver weight: 161.1-740.3g.
8 silver coins: 2 denarii, 6 antoniniani: Maximinus I Thrax - Trajan Decius (Etruscilla) (AD 249-251).

A mixed hoard of denarii, some sestertii and a few antoniniani, ranging from Hadrian to Trajan Decius. It was found in soil dug out during building work in Niederlahnstein (Weiherstraße). The hoard, which was partly dispersed, might have comprised 200 coins or more, but a description of only 142 exists.
(c. 200) 112 coins: 110 antoniniani (radiates), 2 bronze copies: Postumus (AD 268); silver weight: c.53.5 g.
(c. 7 kg) 300 silver coins: Hadrian - Maximian I (A284-293); silver weight: 56.7-852.5 g.
The hoard comprised 381 radiates from Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus and was found under a complete Roman tile. The coins were acquired by the City Library of Bourg.
The hoard comprises 102 antoniniani (radiates).
disposition: Museu de la Porciúncula, Palma, Spain

summary: 53 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Severus Alexander (AD 223).
54 antoniniani (radiates) found in a wall with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised 215 radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus with a tpq of AD 268.
disposition: Brodsko Posavlje Museum, Slavonski Brod, Croatia

summary: 116 silver coins: 4 denarii, 112 antoniniani: Caracalla-Diocletian (AD 292).
179 antoniniani (radiates) and 2 forgeries (antoniniani): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Unknown number of bronze coins. 5 pieces were examined: Caracalla - Elagabalus.
497 bronze coins: 496 sestertii, 1 provincial coin: Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Venezia (252 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 26 coins, mostly large bronzes. 13 coins were broken. The others bear the portraits of Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucilla. The 4 bronze coins of Postumus are cast and middle size (AD 264-265?).
disposition: Musée Saint-Jean, Angers, France (Reg. II, p. 184, no. 453 bis.)

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 275 sestertii and dupondii or asses, arranged in piles from Domitian to Gordian III. Two thirds of the hoard were unidentifable because of a thick layer of corrosion products. The hoard was found in a wood on the Tesnières wood in the roots of an oak tree. Fragments of the ceramic vessel and part of the hoard were acquired by the Musée du Mans
NMR record of 6 coins of Probus found in a field at Seaham and given to the Newcastle Society of Antiquaries. No further details.

The hoard was found in a large iron pot and comprised approximately 29 kilos (close to 120 marcs) of Roman silver coins. The coins were denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from the reign of Septimius Severus to Gallienus and Postumus. Cochet suggested purely hypothetically that this hoard was found in Saint-André-Sur-Cailly.
445 silver coins probably buried directly in the soil: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallu (AD 251-253).

A hoard of 39 antoniniani (Gordian III and Philip I) was discovered by a treasure hunter in the middle of November 2017 in Khmelnytskyi region. Information about the hoard and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on November 14, 2017. There is no additional information about the conditions of hoard find. The further fate of the coins is unknown.

summary: Found during construction work, partially supervised by an archaeologist, in the ruins of a Roman rural building; 15 sestertii, Antoninus Pius to Philipp I, found together with shards possibly of a container. The hoard has been interpreted as a 'Bauopfer' or foundation deposit.

The hoard comprised a white ceramic vessel containing 84 or 85 worn sestertii of Augustus to Trajan Decius. In 1901, a further 5 dupondii and asses of Vespasian, Trajan, Hadrian and Faustina I were found, as well as a worn sestertius and a potin Iron Age coin depicting a horse surmounted by lyre. It is likely that these coins formed part of the earlier hoard.

The hoard was found in a large ceramic vessel. Within the vessel were five corroded blocks of coins, each coated with very hard clay. Two thirds of the hoard was cleaned (except for 2 blocks weighing 5.5kg) and it appears that there were approximately 1,500 coins (bronzes and radiates). Between 200 and 250 coins were of the emperors between Augustus and Gallienus. The others were of Aurelian, Probus and Diocletian. The hoard was found by a farm labourer.
The hoard comprised a copper-alloy patera or pan containing 700 denarii from Augustus to Maximinus, a silver intaglio finger ring and an unspecified amount of gold jewellery.

The hoard comprised 1,016 coins (1,015 antoniniani-radiates and 1 denarius). The hoard was discovered by two workmen on a building site, less than 50 metres from the Gallo-Roman baths, in an earthenware pot that got broken. The Hôtel de Ville d'Allonnes has preserved 386 coins from the hoard.

see EMMERSWEILER A (ID 16729) for details.

During the excavation of Roman fort at Reculver, a rectangular sunken room, poss. the strong room of the principia & sacellum, was excav., 23 ft 10 in. long & 20 ft wide. It had a thin skin floor of white mortar, covered in a deposit 6-12 in. deep of loam, mortar, painted wall plaster & domestic refuse, incl. pottery. It also produced frags. of 2 stone inscriptions from commemorative tablets, 6 iron arrowheads, & 21 coins of Antoninus Pius to Constantine II, with 14 from period AD 260-293. The rubble layer above contained mortaria, roof tile & box tile frags, & may represent collapsed roof, & this layer produced another 4 coins of Postumus of AD 268.Philp, B. 2005. The Excavation of the Roman Fort at Reculver, Kent. Kent Monographs 10. Kent Archaeol. Rescue Unit, pp. 44-45

The aureus of Caracalla entered the collection of General Gazan and the aureus of Macrinus, the collection of Dr Verville. Both were later bought by the Cabinet des Médailles (BN Inv. 1161 & 1215 = Monuments d'or et d'argent Nos. 154-155) without any mention of their findspot.

summary: Three accounts of the discovery exist, but all give different details and there is no other contemporary authority which could be used. Both brass coins (possibly including coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina) and minimi were found in 1869 and have been assumed to be part of one and the same hoard. The three accounts of the range of the first brass gave either Severus Alexander, Gallienus or Maximian as the last emperor represented, and it is now impossible to be certain which account is correct. In 1935, C.H.V. Sutherland examined 105 radiate minims from this hoard. These proved to be exactly similar to the 317 radiate minims which were acquired by Sir Arthur Evans at Bristol some years before, along with 6 regular antoniniani (NC, 1934, 92-103) [no. 804]. Dr. Sutherland therefore concluded that these 317 and 105 radiate minims all came from the Whitchurch hoard. The 6 regular antoniniani may or may not have come from the same find. They were of Victorinus (3) and Tetricus II (3). With the 317 minims, were a rough lump of copper and a piece of sheet metal. The 422 minims copied the following prototypes: Gallic Empire types (249), types of Claudius II (23), miscellaneous types (150). The large brass may have been collected together, to be melted down to make into radiate minims.

In 1958 a small collective find of 18 antoniniani ranging from Aurelian to Carinus Caesar was unearthed in a ditch during excavations conducted by the commission for archaeological exploration of late antique Raetia.

(+485) 472 silver coins: 106 denarii, 366 Septimius Severus - Gallienus with a tpq of AD 257/258. The coins were minted at Antioch (5 coins), Milan, Rome and Viminacium but data concerning the number of coins from each mint was not recorded. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 598g to 1241.7g. The coins were accompanied by eight pieces of jewellery: a tubulus, part of a chain; a conical tubulus, part of a chain; the fragment of a bracelet; a fragment of a bracelet; three parts of the coil of a bracelet; a piece of semi-circular sheet-metal, part of a chain.

The coins were found in a stone sarcophagus along with some ashes. They comprised coins dating from the reign of Augustus (Altar of Lyon) to the reign of Maximinus (of Thrace?). The coins were found during the demolition of a tumulus.

The hoard was found in a small square cairn created with Roman tiles stuck together with red Roman cement and was surrounded by numerous stone sarcophagi. It comprised 87 sestertii from Vespasian to Gordian III and an oculist's stamp inscribed with the name C. TITTIVS BALBINVS.

Hoard found during railway construction work, probably from the area of the site of a Roman villa rustica. It comprisesd at least 2114 coins, but no more than 2300. An upturned bowl made of white metal under which coins lay. Some of the coins were bound together into one chunk by oxidation. 192 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Caracalla to Valerian I (AD 257). Together gold jewelry was found: two pinheads connected by a chain, a pendant decorated with base emeralds and an onyx cameo. Apparently, the jewelry had been in a now rotted wooden box. This assumption is supported by fittings found near the jewelry and a broken bronze key. The circumstances of discovery indicate that the casket was not originally buried.
Approximately 130 silver coins, the majority of which were denarii, of which only a small proportion were identified.

summary: 3rd century. Roman fort at Watercrook S of Kendal was excav by Potter in 1975-5. In square stone guard chamber to NE gate of fort, one charcoal rich layer sandwiched in between two occupation layers/phases of use contained a 'large quantitity of objects' incl. pottery, bronze finger ring, arrowhead, calthrops, iron lock & building fittings, a surgical probe, & 4 coins close together. These dated to post-AD 268-273, & were of Claudius II, radiate copies of Victorinus, & Tetricus I. T.W. 1979. Romans in North-west England. Excavations at the Roman Forts of Ravenglass, Watercrook, and Bowness-on-Solway, pp. 158-160, figs. 60-61.

He also described reverse types but does not match them with their obverses. The last coins are 115 SAECVLI FELICITAS issues of Postumus (Elmer 593). It was found within 7 or 8 metres of Hoard ÉTAPLES 1840 1 during archaeological excavations directed by L. Cousin.

The hoard was found in a black ceramic vessel placed within a pit lined with four tiles. It comprised approximately 4,000 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Tetricus I and II. Issues of Gallienus and Claudius II were the most numerous. A small portion of the hoard including 103 coins were catalogued.

The hoard comprised 57 radiates recovered by excavators from the Touring Club de France in 1966. To these it is possible to add another 40 coins of the same date found at the same findspot in 1899 and likely to be part of the hoard. The hoard was found on two separate occasions. The first coins were found in 1899. The circumstances of their discovery are unknown. A second group of coins were then discovered during an archaeological excavation in 1966. Silver: 9, 48 coins; Silver weight: 2.7

10 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III 4, Philip I 5, Trebonianus Gallus (Volusianus Augustus) 1 (AD 251-253). Weight coins: 35.74 g. Found together with two silver bracelets and two Anchor type silver brooches and one bronze ring. Weight jewelry: 186.83 g.

Hoard found in a bronze pot during the removal of a fence. It comprised more than 1,100 radiates, mainly from the Gallic Empire (Postumus, at least 763 coins). Bought by J. J. Wilhelm Bachofen-Burckhardt, Basel, but some coins dispersed in trade (ca. 100 coins). In 1925, his heirs sold 472 coins to the Swiss National Museum. Then, in 1941, they sold the container and the remaining coins to the Historisches Museum Basel.
42 bronze coins: Antoninus Pius - Caracalla (AD 215).
disposition: Collection J. De Bast (42 coins), in 1808

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 105 pieces entered the museum collection in Popovo and Targovishte: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Popovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 306 (92 coins); History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 689 (13 coins)

summary: 186 denarii, ranging from Vitellius to Severus Alexander, found compacted together during building work on the Augustusplatz. A few coins were lost.
Unknown initial number of coins. Based on the diameter it is assumed they were sestertii. 51 coins were examined: Hadrian - Postumus (AD 260-268).
Found in a pitcher, the coins were placed in a textile bag. 936 coins: 14 denarii, 922 antoniniani (radiates): Commodus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
disposition: Institut national de recherches archéologiques préventives, Paris, France

summary: The hoard comprised 25 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Allectus and was found in a Gallo-Roman cemetery.
229 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Museum of Pavia, Coin Room (inv.nos. 4.54, 4.59, 4.82, 4.101-4.866 not always in sequential order)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 Roman coins including denarii, dupondii, asses and radiates terminating in a single issue of Postumus.
Hoard of 96 gold staters of the Bosporan kings: Cotys II, Rhoemetalkes, Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III, Cotys III.
The hoard comprised a glass cup -'coupe de verre' - containing 20 antoniniani (radiates) of Postumus and Tetricus I.
7 bronze coins finds found in excavations: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. no. 59/1-5

summary: 462 coins, mostly provincial issues of Caesarea in Cappadocia (150 coins) and imperial bronzes (130 coins), other bronze provincial issues and some imperial silver, closing with Gordian III, found in a deposit associated with the mid-third-century destruction of Zeugma.
286 denarii and 7 bits of gold found with a ceramic vessel using as lid another ceramic vessel: Republic - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235).

22 aurei, mostly fragmented and some of them holed: Gordian III - Trajan decius (AD 251); gold weight: 33.97g. The hoard contained fragments of 22 aurei. The total number of fragments amounted to 28 pieces. From these fragments a whole coin, ¾ of a coin and half of a coin could be reconstructed. The rest of the fragments contained the individual parts of the remaining aurei. All coins were in very good condition, with shiny, not worn surface. The fragments of nine coins had holes. Ann iron sword and a gold jewelry were found together with the coins. In the area of a burial ground from the Wielbark Culture, among the graves. Under a layer of dark humus appeared in the bright sand four recesses of 5cm diameter in a semicircle with a diameter of about 50 cm (rests of rings). Each recess contained a larger amount of gold coins cut into quarters.
(53) 50 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard originally comprised an undetermined amount of antoninianii. Only 20 coins of Aurelian belonging to this hoard are now kept in a private collection.

A hoard of provincial coins (Samos, Pergamum, Smyrna, Clazomenae, Metropolis and Nysa; Gordian III - Gallienus), seen in commerce in Athens, coming from Samos. 16 coins are listed, but 21+ are mentioned in the heading.
19 antoniniani (radiates) of Aurelian. Unpublished.

Two antoniniani (radiates) of the brothers Macrianus II and Quietus, placed on either side of the head of the deceased, and a coin (pierced) of Caracalla minted at Paphos, placed over the chest. Burial cave.

During excavation of a ditch in front of the Spickelstraße house 3 a hoard of denarii, ranging from Nero to Alexander Severus, was unearthed in 1958, from which 640 specimens were salvaged and could have been transferred to the Kempten Heimatmuseum. It is not sure that all coins are preserved. 2 antoniniani are also listed.

A hoard of 265 provincial bronze coins (of which 202 were identifiable), found at Dura Europos in a room of the Roman barracks (like hoard 15, though nothing indicated that these were part of the same hoard).). Many of the coins were badly preserved. 63 illegible coins were are not listed in Bellinger's Final report.
The hoard comprised 19 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 255-257 and AD 271-272.
The hoard comprised a small copper-alloy vessel containing 7 antoniniani (radiates) or imitations of Tetricus I. It was found hidden under a large stone slab.
1,764 coins, probably antoniniani (radiates), found with two ceramic vessels: Valerian I - Diocletian and Maximian I (AD 284-293).
84 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian I nd Gallienus (AD 260); silver weight: 24.2-151.3 g.
Unknown initial number of silver coins. antoniniani recovered: 1 Gordian III, 3 Tranquilina (AD 238-241).
1 denarius and 350 antoniniani (radiates) found in the neighborhood (ca. 100m) of another hoard (99 antoniniani): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-268).
57 billon: Hadrian - Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 264-265) found as an unprotected heap on the floor of an underground room during excavations of a house. Range: Hadrian - Gallienus (AD 260-268).
disposition: 37 in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: The hoard is composed of 10 poorly preserved Antonine bronzes. It was found during three archaeological(?) surveys of Noires-Terres in the Bois-en-Ardres in February 1980, at the end of 1981 and in early 1982) and interpreted as the remains of a dispersed hoard, as they were all found in the same place.
The hoard includes 6 denari and 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Philip I (AD 103-247) kept in a private collection.
The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing 700 silver and billon coins (denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - MArius (AD 269).
336 antoniniani (radiates) found in Szeskszárd at an uncertain location: Valerian I and Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270)..
32 antoniniani (radiates) belonging to a purse: Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (AD 270).
disposition: Museum Lauriacum - Museum der Stadt Enns, Austria

summary: 24 provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; inv.nos. 67360-67382

summary: Scarce Information on a hoard, in which circa 20 antoniniani depict portarits of seven emeperors between AD 238-268 from Gordian III to Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Museum of Sain-Sulpice, France, but no records of them in the registers.

summary: The hoard comprised 'approximately 510 ancient coins including Iron Age Gallic coins and approximately 500 denarii and antoniniani (radiates).' The hoard was immediately dispersed in Rouen. The hoard poses some problems of interpretation. The wife and son of the finder claimed that the coins were discovered in an ancient shipwreck, whereas Gaillard saw them as 'a precious collection of Roman coins gathered together by generations of citizens from Juliobona'

A small hoard of 25 Roman aurei and their imitations. This hoard was never published, however, according to Berghaus it contained two genuine issues and 23 cast imitations of Roman aurei, which prototypes can be dated from Lucius Verus to Septimius Severus. More than a half of them show evidence that they were made of the same moulds.

The hoard comprised 152 coins of which 128 were studied by Dancoisne. There were 12 sestertii and 116 denarii and antoniniani (radiates), although Dancoisne does not specify which coins are which! The hoard was found by workmen by the side of the river: -116 coins; silver weight: 34.0-336.1g.
The hoard comprised 2,118 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Aurelian with a tpq of AD 270 to 275.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1991-214/1 - jug; 2:1 - 2120

summary: 40 silver coins: Nerva - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
2,239 coins: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 2,181 sestertii, 6 dupondii, 1 as, 47 cast sestertii: Republic - Valerian and Gallienus (AD 254-256); circa 50 kilos.
disposition: Gabinetto Numismatico di Milano, Italy (inv.nos. M.0.9.22769-M.0.9.25007)

summary: An unpublished hoard of 3 provincial coins (Dium, Thessalonica and the Koinon of Macedonia) and 4 blanks, from a building within the city.
Circa 3000 antoniniani (radiates) with portraits of Gordian III, Philip I, Otacilia Severa, Philip II "and other emperors and empresses of the 3rd century".
(?) 112 silver coins: 17 denarii, 95 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 257-258); silver weight: c. 875.6-1818.9 g
disposition: Town Museum Marienmont, Morlanwelz-Marienmont, Belgium (109 coins)

summary: More than 1000 silver coins (Trajan - Postumus), found while establishing a water ditch on a field. The composition of the hoard is difficult to reconstruct, see FMRD for details.
The only data published on this hoard indicates that it comprised 800 antoniniani (radiates) dating from the reigns of Gordian III to Gallienus (AD 260-268).
9 bronze coins, date, grave: Gaius - Quintillus (AD 270).
Over 20 denarii. No further information.
167 silver coins: 39 denarii, 128 antoniniani: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CXLI

summary: In 1837 six silver coins and one copper coin were unearthed in an arable field between Dambach and Hammerschmiede, in the vicinity of the Dambach Roman fort. The six silver coins were denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Julia Mamaea. The copper coin was an antoninianus of Carinus, that was probably not part of the hoard and has not been listed here.
The hoard comprised 335 antoniniani (radiates) dating between the reigns of Valerian and Claudius II.
disposition: Dispersed in trade. Recorded at the British Museum.

summary: Approximately 800 antoniniani (radiates) were recovered of which 750 were recorded: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
disposition: Museu de Arqueologia e Numismática de Vila Real, Portugal

summary: Hoard of around 150 denarii: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235).
disposition: Statistical commission, Penza (in 1889); the high-school, Penza, Russia; old collection D. Ya. Samkvasov

summary: Unknown initial number of coins bronze vessel. 2,090 silver coins: 2,076 denarii, 13 antoniniani , 1 provincial: Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231); silver weight: 2891.3-6458.6 g.
disposition: Museum of Roman and Dacian Civilisation Deva, Romania (2064 coins), National History Museum of Transylvania Cluj-Napoca, Romania (15 coins), Victor Bratu Collection Bucharest (11 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised '20 denarii [actually, antoniniani (radiates)] of Gordian III, Philip I, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian (?), Gallienus and Postumus.
Three Roman hoards found in Stonea. This hoard comprises 22 denarii ranging up to Severus Alexander.
Unknown number of silver coins found on a field where a grave was found: 1 denarius Augustus, 1 antoninanus (radiate) Gordian III. A brooch was found withe coins. No further Details on it.
23 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: 10 denarii, 11 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2678, 23 coins

summary: 43 silver coins: Vitellius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 61.6-125.1 g.
1,739 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: c. 541.0-2499.0 g.
Breakdown of mints is given suggesting that full breakdown is given in articles. Silver: 1406 coins; Silver weight: 40.1g
3,598 antoniniani (radiates) of which 3,032 are imitations: Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
ca. 1500 to 2000 coins, but only 528 are identified: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

More than 1,000 pieces were found, of which nearly 700 were brought to the museum. Due to corrosion products on the coins, only about 100 of the coins were identified. There were problems of identification and classification and therefore it is not possible to date the latest coin in the hoard. However, several coins had the legend GALLIENVS AVG suggesting a date range of AD 260 to 268.
It is alleged that more than 3 kg of coins were found. 34 denarii: Galba - Elagabalus (AD 218-222); silver weight: 67.2-111.4 g.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 coins, of which 196 were identified by A. Fillioux. The rest of the coins were small bronzes (radiates) of Gallienus, Salonina, Valerian-Saloninus and of Postumus, for the most part worn or copies. The latest coin of Postumus (E. 593) dating to AD 269. Silver: 1, 193+ coins; Silver weight: 54.9-502.2+
1,124 denarii: Nero - Macrinus (AD 217-218).
A suspicious hoard as there is no evidence for the conditions of discovery, except one note in a local newspaper: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (Plautilla (AD 202-205).

The hoard comprised 53 Roman bronze coins (sestertii?) from Galba to Elagabalus. A coin of Maximian I was also found but this is thought to have been a stray loss, rather than being part of the hoard.
The hoard was found in a cemetery and comprised 339 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Diocletian (AD 293).
Originally 460 coins - denarii and antoniniani (radiates), of which 459 were documented: Titus - Valerian I (AD 253-259).
Circa 2,000 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani from Vespasian to Trajan Decius. Mostly, Gordian III and Philip I. Found in a ceramic vessel.

The hoard comprised 773 aurei - 18 coins were already missing in 1874 - from Claudius I to Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar) with a tpq of AD 205-207 and was found in association with a staircase, presumably part of a Roman building or cellar. There are at least 3 different catalogues giving different totals of coins and it is likely that on discovery several coins were retained by the workmen who discovered the find. The Cabinet des Médailles acquired 15 coins from the hoard, for which RIC level data is available. Hobbs estimates a gold weight of approximately 8520.6 to 9239.4g.
135 sestertii found in a cooking pot covered by a plate: Domitian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 236-238).
Fifteen aurei were found during diggings at Vinukonda, in the old fort.
51 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and II (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised an unknown number of small radiates (officials or imitations?), from Victorinus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
It is not clear whether this hoard forms part of the hoard found within the well in 1869 (See 5528). The vessel contained between 141 and 144 bronze coins from Augustus to Postumus.
Around 50 antoniniani were discovered. Coins were issued by Gordian III, Philip I, Philip I for Otacilia Severa, and Valerian I (AD 253-259).

The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 3,258 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271). The coins of Postumus (and some imitations) made up a quarter of all the coins studied. The hoard was found during ground levelling works close to the walls of a farm; silver weight: 880.6-5928.0 g.

Over 3,000 antoniniani (radiates) (8 kg) found with a amphora-like vessel. The largest number of coins belongs to Postumus. Other issuers: Valerian I, Gallienus, Salonina. An Alexander is mentioned among issuers, Severus Alexander (?).
45 bronze coins: 44 sestertii, 1 dupondius: found together in an edifice hypotetically identified as of collegium augustales: Domitian 0- Maximinus I THrax (AD 236-238).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Municipal de Cartagena, Spain

summary: On an area of 3 sqm were found 22 silver coins: 2 denarii, 20 antoniniani of Philip I, beside a bronze lamp.
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 102 coins entered the museum collection in Kazanlak: 1 denarius, 101 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Unknown number of imperial and provincial bronze coins. 36 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13328/1-35 (35 coins)

summary: Five denarii: Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla), Septimius Severus, Elagabalus (AD 218-222).

The hoard was found inside a vessel, apparently made of iron. The total number of coins found seems to be 90, although some reports detail at least 107. The coins were all bronze issues measuring between 25 and 35mm in diameter: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Monedas conservadas en el Museo Arqueologico, Etnografico e Historico, Vasco, Spain (5 coins)

summary: There were 914 antoniniani (radiates) in the hoard. The obverse details for each coin were not recorded and it is not possible to assign the coins to mints. Although Mira (1995-7, 137) gives the total number of coins as 914, only 905 are accounted for in the catalogue.

The assemblage comprised 20 'small bronzes' (Tacitus and Probus) assumed to be antoniniani (radiates) dating to the end of the third century AD. Blanchet considered the find to be a small hoard. TAF suggests it might be a purse hoard. The hoard was found during demolition of an old building.

One of three coin hoards found in a villa on Eighteen Acre Field, all buried just before the end of the 3rd c. AD. 114 coins lying in a kind of trench, below the bottom of the opening near the stoves, ranging from Gallienus to Carausius.

During a violent storm in 1991, coins and many other artefacts dating from the Roman Empire, such as pottery vessels and bronze weights, were washed up from the seabed a short distance from the ancient city of Camarina on the most south-easterly point of Sicily. Among issuers: Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II.
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Camarina, Italy

summary: 27 sestertii found together in a room from a Roman building considered to shave served as a warehouse.
1,312 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 249.3g.
382 coins. 332 coins in the museum in Vidin: Galba - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 438-463 (today, less than 300 coins)

summary: Hoard of 66 bronze staters of the Bosporan king, Rhescuporis V (AD 242-267).
49 coins: 3 silver and 46 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2100-2148 (49 coins)

summary: Approximately 500 sestertii from Flavian issues to Valerian I found during the construction and landscaping of the military stadium in Cherchell. The hoard was dispersed immediately after discovery, with many being sold to Italian collectors, but some of the coins were acquired by the Collection Bouchereau in Algiers.
The hoard comprised 13 sestertii from Trajan to Severus Alexander.
19 antoniniani (radiates) of the period Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259); silver weight: 5.6-13.4 g.

The hoard comprised 2 silver coins and 39 bronze coins. They were identified by Moreau de la Ronde who noted that they were all coins from the reign of Gallienus. The silver coins obviously date to before AD 260.
Hoard of 17 silver coins, comprising 7 denarii (Elagabal to Maximinus) and 10 radiates (Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus)

The hoard was found in a vessel and contained between 200 and 300 coins of Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Philip, Otacilla, Trajan Decius, Herennia Etruscilla, Hostilian, Trebonianus Gallus, Valerian, Valerian II, Mariniana and Salonina.
Group of 2 coins found with an urn: Maximinus I Thrax bronze, Gordian III antoninianus (radiate) (AD 238-244).
Only 303 antoniniani (radiates) are identified. The exact findspot is not known, but it is possible that it comes from Oudenburg, Gistel or Torhout: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard comprised 3 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and II, placed in a pile in the foundations of the wall of a Gallo-Roman villa. It has been interpreted by TAF as a foundation deposit.

From 57 coins found on the excavated area, according to B. Prokisch 24 coins may have been part of a hoard: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-259). A gold bracelet was found with these coins.

Hoard 8 was found on 18 Nov. 1932 and hoard 9 on 22 Jan. 1933. Both were under the floor of the same room, just west of the South-West Tower of the Citadel and certainly part of the same deposit. it comprised 2,821 coins and 11 illegible ones, including one AE of Seleucus III, one tetradrachm of Philip Philadelphus, 2 denarii (Severus Alexander) and 2,817 provincial bronze coins from a large variety of mints (Domitian - Decius).
34 silver coins: 14 denarii, 20 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The wooden box contained pieces of silverware and various Roman artefacts. The finder sold the jewellery to the Imperial Library, today the National Library. The coins were dispersed; 1,450 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). The hoard consists of: 8 gold necklaces, pearls or semi-precious stones; 5 gold rings; 6 silver rings; 1 ivory styllus; 1 silver ingot; 1 gold roll of wire; hollow gold fingers (plectrum); a stone statuette of Aesculapius; several rings with intaglio; 2 silver hearts and 1 necklace pendant with a gold coin.
It comprised c. 150 sestertii. 145 had been studied from Trajan to Gordian III.

A hoard of 68 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from Titus to Trajan Decius. The exact provenance is unclear, but coins were found in Ladenburg. Only two thirds of the coins could be traced in the collections of the Baden-Baden museum.

A hoard of 12 provincial coins of Gordian III and Tranquillina (Thessalonica and Edessa), found during the excavations of a farmhouse in ancient Lete (preceding the construction of the Egnatia motorway) and linked to the Gothic invasions of the middle of the 3rd c. AD.

A hoard of 16 antoniniani (Julia Domna - Gallienus), found in the shop II of the Stoa of Attalos, on the agora of Athens. The tpq for the hoard is given by the archaeological context, which corresponds to the the sack of Athens by the Heruls.

A hoard of 162 provincial coins, 27 of which were illegible. The remaining ones were: 134 coins from Sinope (Antoninus Pius - Valerian & Gallienus) and 1 from Trapezus (Gordian III). The hoard was found in a burnt and shattered container in the remains of a Roman villa, on the northern side of the Sinope peninsula.
Around 25 kg = 7,656 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
"A considerable large quantity" of coins of "middle bronzes", all of Postumus (AD 260-268). Four
c. 1200 silver coins: 1 denarius and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269).

The hoard comprised one vessel containing a harness fitting and 800 copper-alloy and silver coins of Commodus, Pertinax, Septimius Severus, Albinus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Plautilla, Geta, Macrinus, Elagabalus, Julia Paula, Julia Maesa, Julia Soaemias, Severus Alexander, Julia Mamaea, Orbiana, Gordian I, Pulpienus, Balbinus, Gordianus III, Philip I, Philip II, Otacilia Severa and Herennius Etruscus.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing 700 'pewter coins imitating denarii of Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla and Geta'.

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO B)
summary: Hoard in grave, 13 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus/Aurelian (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270-275).

The hoard comprised 'a ceramic vessel containing more than 300 middle bronzes. They were of Marcia Severa, the young Gordian, Gordian II. They were all different, but all base silver.' It is clear that the coins were radiates, although it is possible that there may have also been some denarii if the identification of coins of Gordian II is correct. The hoard was found by a labourer.
Over 248 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gordian III - Gallienus (sole)(AD 260-268).
disposition: Museum of Vojvodina, Novi Sad, Serbia (230 coins), Vl. Macković collection Novi Sad, Serbia (18 coins) - 1982

summary: The hoard comprised 15 sestertii of Faustina I to Valerian I.
A leather bag full of coins was found ca. 1920 on the Oberer Zahlbacher Weg. 160 coins got into private hands and could be recorded.
190 antoniniani, probably, part of Sushina 2: Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
60 silver and bronze coins found by workers 19 provincial bronze coins were aquired by the Varna Archaeological Society: Gordian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Unknown initial number of coins. 29 provincial bronze coins are known: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
(c. 400) 322 antoniniani/radiates: Trajan Decius - Gallienus (AD 257-258); silver weight: 87.9 - 401.5g+
disposition: National Museum Ljubljana, Slovenia (227 coins); Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (95 coins); dispersed

summary: The discovery of gold jewellery, objects and coinage in the Lava Gulf off the coast of Corsica is reputed to have begun in the nineteenth century after a chance find by a coral fisherman. 41 aurei or multiples of aurei first appeared on the antiquities market in 1956 (35 aurei and 6 multiples) followed by further discoveries in 1971 and in 1985. It is reputed to have included between 400 and 600 aurei and multiples of aurei of Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus and Aurelian, jewellery and gold finger rings which were melted down, a gold dish with a medallion of Gallienus at its centre, and possibly a gold statuette.

The hoard comprised more than 30 'large bronze Roman coins. TAF speculates as to whether it is an entire hoard or part of a larger hoard. Found in a gravel quarry.32 coins were donated to the museum by M. Caille: Trajan - Postumus (AD 260-69).
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France. Inventory: III, 2, p. 78, no. 2005 (5.11.1908).

summary: Hilltop settlement. The hoard was found during metal detectorists' surveys next to many single finds. It comprised ca. 50-60 antoniniani (ca. Claudius II to Postumus), which were partly melted down and fused into a lump. A few types are visible: PAX AVG, MARTI PACIFER(O) and FELICITAS AVG.
Unknown number of silver coins. 29 coins entered the museum collection in Targovishte: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
34 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 33 silver coins, 1 provincial bronze: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) - Valerian I and Gallienus (Valerian I) (AD 253-260).
117 coins entered museum collection Yambol: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2409/0-65/, 2435/0-40/, 2547/0-7/, 2663/0-3/

summary: 7 aurei: Carinus - Maximian (AD 286-294) and jewelry, bracelets and rings.
disposition: Numismatic Department of the Hungarian National Museum (Inv.no. 62.1946), Budapest, Hungary

summary: A group of 14 Roman provincial bronzes of Pontic cities (Zela, Amasia, Comana, Sebastopolis), now in the Ankara museum, and judging from its composition, probably found nearby Zela. All coins were minted in the year 205/206, under Septimius Severus.
Originally 539 silver coins, 535 pieces recovered: denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

The hoard was found in a wooden box measuring 30cm by 30cm which was hidden in a cavity under a large stone. It comprised 6 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip, Gallienus and Divus Valerian II (AD 253-260).

In 1897 a hoard of silver coins was discovered a little south of the Ladenburg/Keplerstraße junction. Only half of the coins are known, because the others were sold to America. The list given here includes a Greek coin, and 129 denarii and antoninini (late Republic to Postumus).

74 coins found with a Roman bronze jug: Vespasian - Valerian I (AD 256-257). Together were found: an Almgren 157 fibula, five bracelets, a pendant and two silver ingots on silver. The discovery has been interpreted as a silver craftsman hoard.
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Prahova, ploiești, Romania (inv.nos. 72696-72766)

summary: 933 denarii and 2 antoniniani (radiates) spanning from Mark Antony to Maximinus I (AD 235-238).
2,060 silver coins: 1,849 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 209 antoniniani (radiates), 1 drachm: Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-252).
disposition: History and Archaeology Museum Constanța, Romania

summary: The hoard was found in a Roman theatre and comprised 1,065 coins. 12 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I. 1,053 blanks and 6 rejected blanks.
381 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
43,433 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 274-275); silver weight: 11726.9-54290.3 g

The hoard comprised 64 'bronze' coins from Caracalla to Gallienus. The denominational composition of the hoard is not given. It was found in the South Stoa. In front of shop XX was a strosis covered with a thick layer of burned debris. In this charred stratum, within the storeroom, were found the iron fittings of a money box containing the hoard.
The hoard comprised about 4,000 coins of Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius II, Aurelian and Probus in a vessel. There may be two hoards.

The hoard comprised a Samian ware vessel filled with radiates. Although they were immediately dispersed amongst the group of workmen who found them, M. Le Pesant was able to examine 176 of the coins: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Sixty of the coins and a fragment of the base of the vessel were acquired by the Musée d'Évreux. Silver weight: 215.2-408.4 g.
8 coins: 5 double sestertii, 2 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Antoninus Pius - Postumus (AD 261-269).
(9.5 kg; 2,358 coins) 2317 silver coins: Nero - Trajan Decius (AD 250); silver weight: 2671.9-6683.8 g
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; 2024 coins; inv. nos. 125- 282; 921 1-630

summary: Unknown initial number of bronze coins. 24 pieces are kept in museum of Lovech: 1 sestertius, 23 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
The hoard comprised 12 bronze coins, 5 of which have been identified.
51 coins: 50 sestertii and 1 as with 2 fibulae found in a looted Roman building
44 coins found in a grave in Lefkohori, Langada in 1970. The coins included one denarius (Marcus Aurelius) and 43 provincial coins (Thessalonica, Edessa, Dium, Pella, Stobi, koinon of Macedonia).
30 kg of coins: Valerian I, Gallienus, Vlaudius II, Tetricus I. 369 have been seen by D. Nony: Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Unknown number of coins. 14 provincial bronze coins entered museum collection in Nesebar: Antoninus Pius - Caracalla. Mints: Augusta Traiana, Philippopolis, Hadrianopolis, Serdica, Anchialus
disposition: History Museum, Nesebar, Bulgaria; inv.no. XI

summary: The hoard comprised 39 radiates of Gallienus and Salonina, found in the Euripides / Peristeria cave, on the south of the island of Salamis.
11 coins discovered in a burial consisting in 1 denarius of Augustus, 5 drachms of Gotarzes II, 1 aureus of Commodus, and 4 aurei of Caracalla.
Few hundreds denarii found in a ceramic vessel. Only 16 pieces recovered: Marcus Aurelius - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231); silver weight: 28.8-66.0 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2146-2154

summary: Aureus of Trajan Decius found together with and a denarius imitation.
134 silver coins: 6 denarii, 128 antoniniani: Hadrian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259-260); silver weight: 166.1-340.8 g.
49 coins were discovered near an ancient settlement during archaeological excavations: 31 antoniniani, 17 denarii, 1 provincial bronze: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
37 sestertii: Hadrian - Elagabalus (AD 221-222).

14 bronze coins, ranging from Caracalla to Philip, found in a clay vessel in the destruction layer of a building in the north section of the Agora. More than 100 bronze (provincial, judging from those ill. in fig. 4 in AEMTh 18, 2004, p. 382) coins were also found in the same layer.
2,191 silver coins found with an urn: 2147 denarii, 44 antoniniani (radiates): Mark Antony ´- Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238); silver weight: 3112.7-7821.9g.
disposition: Salzburg Museum Carolino Augusteum (41 coins); Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien, Austria (10 coins)

summary: Circa two kilos of coins and jewelry (2 bronze bracelets). For years it has been considered that Janapole and Dargeliszkie were two separate hoards. 14 bronze coins are hosted in the Museum "Alka" in Telšiai: Severus Alexander - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Hoard of 1,000 silver coins: Trajan - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235). 8 coins are documented.
(316) 214 silver coins: 23 denarii, 191 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 261); silver weight: 112.2-779.3 g.
8 provincial bronze coins issued under Gordian III by Edessa (6 coins) and either Edessa or Carrhae (2 coins).
727 denarii and antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no.8442-9165

summary: 17 provincial bronze coins of Caracalla found in a ceramic vessel: Serdica 13, Deultum 2, Philippopolis 1, Pautalia 1.
